119TH CONGRESS S. 2296
1ST SESSION
AN ACT
To authorize appropriations for fiscal year 2026 for military
activities of the Department of Defense, for military
construction, and for defense activities of the Depart-
ment of Energy, to prescribe military personnel strengths
for such fiscal year, and for other purposes.

21 ‘‘operational demonstration’’ means a land-based or

23 representative form, fit, and function.

3 (a) IN GENERAL.—Not later than 180 days after the

5 Air Force shall submit to the congressional defense com-
6 mittees a comprehensive roadmap detailing the planned
7 force structure, basing, modernization, and transition
8 strategy for the bomber aircraft fleet of the Air Force
9 through fiscal year 2040.
10 (b) ELEMENTS.—The roadmap required by sub-
11 section (a) shall include the following:
12 (1) A detailed schedule and rationale for the
13 planned divestment of B–1 bomber aircraft, includ-
14 ing location-specific retirements, infrastructure dis-
15 position, and mitigation of any resulting capability
16 gaps.
17 (2) A transition plan for the operational field-
18 ing of B–21 bomber aircraft, including basing deci-
19 sions, training and sustainment plans, operational
20 concepts, and anticipated initial operational capa-
21 bility and full operational capability timelines.
22 (3) A strategy for integrating units of the Air
23 National Guard and the Air Force Reserve into B–
24 21 bomber aircraft operations, including planned
25 force structure, association, training, and mobiliza-
26 tion models.
†S 2296 ES

63
1 (4) An update on—
2 (A) modernization efforts for B–52 bomber
3 aircraft, including engine replacement, radar
4 upgrades, and digital integration efforts; and
5 (B) the expected service life and mission
6 profile of B–52 bomber aircraft through the
7 2050s.
8 (5) A detailed timeline with key milestones for
9 each of the elements described in paragraphs (1)
10 through (4), including programmatic decision points,
11 resourcing requirements, risk assessments, and co-
12 ordination with other components of the Air Force
13 Global Strike Command and the Air Combat Com-
14 mand.
15 (c) OBJECTIVE.—The roadmap required by sub-
16 section (a) shall support a deliberate and balanced transi-
17 tion to a modernized, dual-capable bomber aircraft force
18 that ensures long-range strike capacity, survivability, and
19 deterrence in both nuclear and conventional mission sets,
20 with a minimum of 100 B–21 bomber aircraft as directed
21 by prior Acts of Congress.
22 (d) FORM.—The roadmap required by subsection (a)
23 shall be submitted in unclassified form, but may include
24 a classified annex.

SEC. 135. PLAN FOR OPEN MISSION SYSTEMS OF F–35 AIR-
21
CRAFT.
22 (a) IN GENERAL.—The Secretary of Defense shall
23 develop a plan to establish an open mission systems com-
24 puting environment that is controlled by the Federal Gov-
†S 2296 ES

67
1 ernment on the F–35 aircraft of the Department of De-
2 fense.
3 (b) ELEMENTS.—The plan required under subsection
4 (a) shall do the following:
5 (1) Enable the portability of software applica-
6 tions between the F–35 aircraft, the F–22 aircraft,
7 and the Next Generation Air Dominance initiative of
8 the Air Force.
9 (2) Enable the integration of new open mission
10 system software, or changes to existing open mission
11 system software, with minimal integration work re-
12 quired by the prime contractor of the air vehicle.
13 (3) Eliminate or minimize aircraft airworthiness
14 impacts due to software changes within the open
15 mission systems computing environment.
16 (4) Enable the rapid upgrade of onboard proc-
17 essors.
18 (5) Leverage a Federal Government reference
19 architecture.
20 (6) Ensure control by the Federal Government
21 over the airworthiness and security processes, as well
22 as ownership by the Federal Government of the open
23 mission system technical documentation and data
24 rights.
†S 2296 ES

68
1 (7) Be capable of connection to all relevant air-
2 craft apertures sufficient to meet current and future
3 combat requirements, including cockpit connectivity
4 via ethernet.
5 (8) Leverage modern commercial software lan-
6 guages and techniques necessary to support reliable,
7 high-throughput, and low-latency use-cases.
8 (9) Be applicable across all blocks and variants
9 of the F–35 aircraft.
10 (c) REPORT.—
11 (1) IN GENERAL.—Not later than July 1, 2026,
12 the Secretary of the Air Force shall submit to the
13 congressional defense committees a report that in-
14 cludes the plan required under subsection (a).

16 graph (1) shall be submitted in unclassified form,

SEC. 217. WESTERN REGIONAL RANGE COMPLEX DEM-
21
ONSTRATION.
22 (a) DEMONSTRATION REQUIRED.—The Secretary
23 shall carry out a demonstration of a joint multi-domain
24 kinetic and non-kinetic testing and training environment
25 across military departments by interconnecting existing
†S 2296 ES

94
1 ranges and training sites in the western States to improve
2 joint multi-domain training and further testing, research,
3 and development.
4 (b) USE OF EXISTING RANGES AND CAPABILITIES.—
5 The demonstration carried out pursuant to subsection (a)
6 shall use existing ranges and range capability, unless ca-
7 pability gaps are identified in the process of planning spe-
8 cific demonstration activities.
9 (c) ACTIVITIES.—The demonstration carried out pur-
10 suant to subsection (a) shall include the following:
11 (1) Electromagnetic spectrum operations.
12 (2) Electromagnetic warfare.
13 (3) Operations that blend kinetic and non-ki-
14 netic effects.
15 (4) Operations in the information environment.
16 (5) Joint All Domain Command and Control
17 (JADC2).
18 (6) Information warfare, including the fol-
19 lowing:
20 (A) Intelligence, surveillance, and recon-
21 naissance.
22 (B) Offensive and defense cyber oper-
23 ations.
24 (C) Electromagnetic warfare.
25 (D) Space operations.
†S 2296 ES

95
1 (E) Psychological operations.
2 (F) Public affairs.
3 (G) Weather operations.
4 (d) TIMELINE FOR COMPLETION OF INITIAL DEM-
5 ONSTRATION.—In carrying out subsection (a), the Sec-
6 retary shall seek to complete an initial demonstration,
7 interconnecting two or more ranges or testing sites of two
8 or more military departments in the western States, sub-
9 ject to availability of appropriations, not later than one
10 year after the date of the enactment of this Act.
11 (e) BRIEFING.—Not later than 180 days after the
12 date of the enactment of this Act, the Secretary shall pro-
13 vide the congressional defense committees a briefing on—
14 (1) a phased implementation plan and design to
15 connect ranges and testing sites in the western
16 States, including the initial demonstration required
17 by subsection (d);
18 (2) how the design architecture of the plan is
19 in alignment with recommendations of the 2020 De-
20 partment of Defense Electromagnetic Spectrum Su-
21 periority Strategy; and
22 (3) how the design architecture will support
23 high-periodicity training, testing, research, and de-
24 velopment.
25 (f) DEFINITIONS.—In this section:

SEC. 219. ADVANCED ROBOTIC AUTOMATION FOR MUNI-
9
TIONS MANUFACTURING.
10 (a) PROGRAM REQUIRED.—The Secretary of the
11 Army shall carry out a program to support the maturation
12 and expansion of robotic automation capabilities for muni-
13 tions manufacturing at government-owned, contractor-op-
14 erated production facilities.
15 (b) OBJECTIVES.—The objectives of the program
16 under subsection (a) shall include the following:
17 (1) The design and integration of inherently
18 safe, scalable robotic load, assemble, and pack
19 (LAP) systems for munitions production.
20 (2) The demonstration of increased throughput
21 and production capacity, while reducing manual han-
22 dling of energetic materials.
23 (3) The development of cyber-hardened data in-
24 frastructure for secure integration of factory-floor
25 operations with enterprise systems.
†S 2296 ES

98
1 (4) Support for workforce upskilling and train-
2 ing in robotics, automation, and advanced manufac-
3 turing technologies.
4 (5) The evaluation of applicability across mul-
5 tiple munition types and organic industrial base
6 sites.
7 (c) COORDINATION.—In carrying out the program
8 under subsection (a), the Secretary of the Army shall co-
9 ordinate with the Joint Program Executive Office Arma-
10 ments and Ammunition and other relevant components of
11 the Department of the Army.
12 (d) BRIEFING.—Not later than March 1, 2026, the
13 Secretary of Defense shall provide the congressional de-
14 fense committees a briefing on the program carried out
15 under subsection (a). Such briefing shall cover—
16 (1) the progress made under the program;
17 (2) lessons learned; and
18 (3) recommendations for the wider adoption of
19 robotic automation technologies within the defense
20 industrial base.

SEC. 221. CATALYST PATHFINDER PROGRAM.
9 (a) ESTABLISHMENT.—Not later than January 1,
10 2027, the Secretary of the Army shall establish a soldier-
11 inspired innovation program—
12 (1) that creates partnerships between oper-
13 ational units of the Army and leading national re-
14 search universities to provide a unique platform for
15 university-based researchers and small businesses to
16 collaborate directly with soldiers on cutting-edge ap-
17 plied research and development; and
18 (2) to integrate soldiers into the early-stage
19 problem identification process and include them in
20 the solution development process to ensure technical
21 solutions are meeting soldier needs and enhancing
22 lethality.
23 (b) DESIGNATION.—The program established pursu-
24 ant to subsection (a) shall be known as the ‘‘Catalyst
25 Pathfinder Program’’ (in this section the ‘‘Program’’).
†S 2296 ES

124
1 (c) ACTIVITIES.—In carrying out the Program, the
2 Secretary shall—
3 (1) establish activities at all active-duty divi-
4 sions of the Army to accelerate the incorporation of
5 soldier insights into capability development;
6 (2) establish policies that streamline collabora-
7 tion between soldiers, Army Futures Command, and
8 academic institutions;
9 (3) establish a governance board that includes
10 representatives from the research, development, test,
11 and evaluation, acquisition, requirements, industry,
12 and academic communities;
13 (4) promote transition of successful Program
14 projects to Army programs; and
15 (5) implement an adaptive experimentation
16 force capability to support technology experimen-
17 tation activities throughout the solution development
18 cycle
19 (d) TREATMENT OF PROGRAM.—The Program shall
20 be treated as a research, development, test, and evaluation
21 activity in the Army’s input to the Future Year Defense
22 Program.

11 this section referred to as ‘‘NEPA’’) and replace those di-
12 rectives with a new directive with uniform guidance that
13 the military departments and other agencies of the De-
14 partment of Defense must implement.
15 (b) ELEMENTS OF NEW NEPA DIRECTIVE.—The
16 new directive required under subsection (a) shall ensure
17 that all components of the Department of Defense comply
18 with the requirements under NEPA, including the up-
19 dated guidelines established under title III of division C
20 of the Fiscal Responsibility Act of 2023 (Public Law 118–
21 5; 137 Stat. 38).

1 menting the NEPA directive established under subsection
2 (a) and ensuring the timely execution of all reviews re-

23 water distribution system or the Secretary has successfully

†S 2296 ES

1 polyfluoroalkyl substances to meet or exceed both Federal

SEC. 321. SURFACE SHIP SUSTAINMENT AND READINESS.
6 (a) IN GENERAL.—In accordance with this section,
7 the Secretary of the Navy shall implement processes to
8 improve the materiel condition and combat readiness of
9 Navy surface ships maintained and repaired at private
10 shipyards by ensuring a stable and responsive industrial
11 base capable of meeting operational and combat surge de-
12 mands.
13 (b) REQUIREMENTS AND AUTHORITIES.—
14 (1) TYPE COMMANDER LEADERSHIP.—
15 (A) DESIGNATION.—The Secretary of the
16 Navy shall designate type commanders as the
17 primary authorities for surface ship mainte-
18 nance.
19 (B) RESPONSIBILITIES.—Type com-
20 manders designated under subparagraph (A)
21 shall—
22 (i) lead the sustainment of surface
23 ships;
24 (ii) oversee all maintenance and repair
25 activities at private shipyards; and
†S 2296 ES

154
1 (iii) be responsible for setting prior-
2 ities, approving contracts, and ensuring
3 fleet readiness.
4 (C) REGIONAL MAINTENANCE CENTERS.—
5 The Secretary of the Navy shall ensure that re-
6 gional maintenance centers act in a supporting
7 role under the direction of type commanders.
8 (2) DECISION-MAKING BY KEY PERSONNEL.—
9 (A) IN GENERAL.—For each ship under-
10 going maintenance at a private shipyard, the
11 project manager, the port engineer, and the
12 ship commanding officer—
13 (i) may jointly decide what work is
14 done during the maintenance period, in-
15 cluding the ability to adjust priorities with-
16 in agreed budgets and schedules; and
17 (ii) shall report directly to the type
18 commander concerned.
19 (B) CONTRACTING OFFICERS.—Con-
20 tracting officers shall support the decisions de-
21 scribed in subparagraph (A)(i) by managing
22 funds and contracts.
23 (3) STABLE WORKFORCE AND INFRASTRUC-
24 TURE.—The Secretary of the Navy shall provide a
25 stable, predictable workload to private shipyards and
†S 2296 ES

155
1 other critical suppliers through a multi-year, multi-
2 ship contract by ship class—
3 (A) to allow the shipyard and other critical
4 suppliers to maintain a stable workforce;
5 (B) to promote investment in the necessary
6 facilities; and
7 (C) to prevent layoffs and rehiring cycles
8 that reduce efficiency.
9 (4) SHIP-SPECIFIC ASSIGNMENTS.—The Sec-
10 retary of the Navy shall ensure that specific ship-
11 yards shall have multi-year contracts for specified
12 ships for repeated maintenance work to improve
13 knowledge of ship condition and accelerate repairs,
14 with excusable deviations such as homeport changes.
15 (5) COLLABORATIVE PLANNING.—The Sec-
16 retary of the Navy shall ensure that shipyards, alter-
17 ations installation teams (when assigned), and Navy
18 teams, including project managers and port engi-
19 neers, work together in continuous maintenance ac-
20 tivities to plan maintenance and ensure realistic
21 schedules and priorities.
22 (6) ROLES FOR LARGE AND SMALL SHIP-
23 YARDS.—The Secretary of the Navy shall ensure
24 that—
†S 2296 ES

156
1 (A) criteria for multi-year awards place
2 heavy emphasis on strong teaming between
3 large and small shipyard businesses;
4 (B) large and small shipyards establish
5 multi-year teaming relationships and work in
6 both the planning and execution phases of
7 scheduled availabilities and emergency repairs;
8 and
9 (C) small shipyards have guaranteed work
10 percentages and planning responsibilities.
11 (7) PARTS AVAILABILITY.—The Secretary of
12 the Navy shall establish rotatable pools and procure
13 spare parts ahead of time to create a pool of parts
14 that can be quickly used for repairs.
15 (8) TRAINING.—The Secretary of the Navy
16 shall train program managers and port engineers for
17 specific ship classes prior to assigning such individ-
18 uals to complex maintenance availabilities.
19 (9) FUNDING FOR WORKFORCE AND FACILI-
20 TIES.—The Secretary of the Navy may allocate
21 funds annually to private shipyards to sustain a
22 minimum workforce and maintain repair facilities, in
23 such amounts and under such conditions as the Sec-
24 retary determines appropriate.
†S 2296 ES

157
1 (10) SMALL BUSINESS REQUIREMENTS.—The
2 Secretary of the Navy shall issue guidance to ad-
3 dress set-aside requirements for small businesses
4 that enables the roles for large and small shipyards
5 described in paragraph (6).
6 (c) IMPLEMENTATION FLEXIBILITY.—In carrying
7 out this section, the Secretary of the Navy may—
8 (1) determine specific methods, contract types,
9 funding levels, and operational details consistent
10 with the requirements and authorities under this
11 section; and
12 (2) adapt existing processes or develop new ap-
13 proaches to carry out such requirements and au-
14 thorities.
15 (d) REPORT REQUIRED.—Not later than 180 days
16 after the date of the enactment of this Act, the Secretary
17 of the Navy shall submit to the congressional defense com-
18 mittees a report detailing the following:
19 (1) How the Navy will implement the require-
20 ments of this section, including with respect to the
21 roles of type commanders, regional maintenance cen-
22 ters, project managers, port engineers, ship com-
23 manding officers, and contracting officers.
†S 2296 ES

158
1 (2) The planned funding approach for work-
2 force stability, shipyard assignments, and spare
3 parts procurement.
4 (3) A timeline for initial implementation, in-
5 cluding any pilot programs, and full deployment
6 across all regional maintenance centers.
7 (4) Metrics to measure success, such as on-time
8 completion of maintenance, cost control, and readi-
9 ness improvements.
10 (e) DEFINITIONS.—In this section:
11 (1) PORT ENGINEER.—The term ‘‘port engi-
12 neer’’ means the technical expert on a ship’s condi-
13 tion who advises on repairs and standards.
14 (2) PROJECT MANAGER.—The term ‘‘project
15 manager’’ means the individual responsible for over-
16 seeing a ship’s maintenance period.
17 (3) REGIONAL MAINTENANCE CENTER.—The
18 term ‘‘regional maintenance center’’ means an orga-
19 nization of the Navy that supports ship maintenance
20 in a specific region, such as in Norfolk, Virginia,

23 (4) SHIP COMMANDING OFFICER.—The term
24 ‘‘ship commanding officer’’ means the commanding
†S 2296 ES

1 officer of a Navy surface ship undergoing mainte-
2 nance.
3 (5) TYPE COMMANDER.—The term ‘‘type com-
4 mander’’ means the flag officer in charge of a sur-

8 (f) SUNSET.—This section shall terminate on Janu-

SEC. 322. TECHNOLOGY ENHANCEMENT FOR SURFACE
11
SHIP MAINTENANCE.
12 (a) IN GENERAL.—The Secretary of the Navy shall

16 on an expedited timeline to enhance readiness, reduce
17 costs, and address delays in maintenance and repair activi-
18 ties.

20 PROCESSES.—In carrying out subsection (a), the Sec-
21 retary of the Navy shall prioritize qualification of the fol-
22 lowing:
23 (1) Automated weld inspection for robotic weld
24 defect detection.
†S 2296 ES

160
1 (2) Real-time sustainment monitoring for sen-
2 sor-based health tracking.

6 repairs.
7 (5) Robotic tank inspection for confined space
8 condition assessments.
9 (6) Additive manufacturing for on-demand 3D-
10 printed parts.
11 (7) Augmented reality support for augmented
12 reality-guided repairs.
13 (8) Cold spray repair for metal surface restora-
14 tion.
15 (9) Predictive maintenance algorithms for arti-
16 ficial intelligence-driven failure prediction.
17 (10) Automated nondestructive testing for
18 robotic material evaluation.
19 (11) Autonomous underwater vehicles for hull
20 inspection submersibles.
21 (12) Digital twin technology for virtual ship
22 modeling.
23 (13) High-pressure waterjet cleaning for rust
24 and paint removal.
†S 2296 ES

161
1 (14) Modular maintenance platforms for stand-
2 ardized repair setups.
3 (15) Smart coatings for self-healing, anti-foul-
4 ing surfaces.
5 (16) Laser ablation for laser-based surface
6 preparation.
7 (17) Drone-based inspection for uncrewed
8 structural surveys.
9 (18) Electrochemical corrosion mitigation for

11 (19) Smart pigging for internal pipe

1 (2) EVALUATION.—The Secretary of the Navy

SEC. 324. REQUIREMENTS FOR DEPARTMENT OF DEFENSE
4

5
AIRPORTS.
6 (a) RISK MITIGATION.—The Secretary of Defense
7 shall require all aircraft of the Department of Defense
8 that operate near commercial airports to be equipped with

11 use of such technology.

13 MINISTRATION.—The Secretary of Defense shall develop
14 a program for sharing aviation safety data for aircraft of
15 the Department of Defense, to include near misses and
16 mishaps, with the Federal Aviation Administration.

19 after the date of the enactment of this Act, the Sec-
20 retary shall submit to the Committees on Armed
21 Services of the Senate and the House of Representa-
22 tives a report on the number of near misses that air-
23 craft of the Department have had with commercial
24 aircraft during the 10-year period preceding such
25 date of enactment.
†S 2296 ES

170
1 (2) ANNUAL REPORT.—Not later than one year

4 submit to the Committees on Armed Services of the
5 Senate and the House of Representatives a report on
6 the number of near misses that aircraft of the De-
7 partment have had with commercial aircraft during
8 the previous fiscal year.

10 section shall include, with respect to each near miss
11 covered under the report, the following:

13 near miss.

17 erating procedures, or policy, as appropriate,

SEC. 326. PROHIBITION ON CLOSURE OF ARMY ORGANIC
20
INDUSTRIAL BASE SITES.
21 (a) PROHIBITION.—The Secretary of Defense shall
22 not take any action to close, mothball, divest, deactivate,
23 or otherwise render inoperable any facility that is part of
24 the organic industrial base of the Army, including any
25 depot, arsenal, ammunition plant, manufacturing center,
†S 2296 ES

172
1 or facility of a center of industrial and technical excellence,
2 unless—
3 (1) a similar or replacement facility has already
4 been created; and
5 (2) the action is authorized—
6 (A) in accordance with the provisions of
7 this section; or
8 (B) pursuant to an Act of Congress.
9 (b) SCOPE.—The prohibition in subsection (a) applies
10 to all facilities operated or maintained as part of the or-
11 ganic industrial base of the Army, whether Government-
12 owned and Government-operated or Government-owned
13 and contractor-operated.
14 (c) EXCEPTION FOR SAFETY.—
15 (1) IN GENERAL.—The Secretary of Defense
16 may suspend operations or limit access to a facility
17 covered by this section if such action is necessary to
18 address an imminent threat to the health and safety
19 of personnel or to mitigate substantial environmental
20 hazards.
21 (2) REPORT REQUIRED.—The Secretary of De-
22 fense shall submit to the congressional defense com-
23 mittees a report that describes any action taken
24 under paragraph (1) not later than 15 days after
†S 2296 ES

173
1 the date on which such suspension of operations or
2 limitation of access is initiated.
3 (d) NATIONAL SECURITY WAIVER.—
4 (1) IN GENERAL.—The Secretary of Defense
5 may waive the prohibition under subsection (a) if the
6 Secretary determines that such a waiver is necessary
7 to address a critical national security interest of the
8 United States.
9 (2) NOTIFICATION REQUIRED.—Not later than
10 30 days prior to exercising the waiver under para-
11 graph (1), the Secretary shall submit to the congres-
12 sional defense committees—
13 (A) a written notification of the intent to
14 waive the prohibition;
15 (B) a detailed justification for the waiver,
16 including an assessment of the national security
17 interest at stake;
18 (C) an evaluation of potential impacts to
19 the readiness, industrial base capacity, and
20 surge requirements of the Army; and
21 (D) a description of any mitigation meas-
22 ures to be implemented.
23 (e) REPORTS REQUIRED.—
24 (1) IN GENERAL.—Not later than 120 days
25 after the date of the enactment of this Act, and an-
†S 2296 ES

174
1 nually thereafter for five years, the Secretary of the
2 Army shall submit to the congressional defense com-
3 mittees a report on the status of all facilities in the
4 organic industrial base of the Army.
5 (2) ELEMENTS.—Each report required by para-
6 graph (a) shall include—
7 (A) a list of all facilities in the organic in-
8 dustrial base of the Army and the operational
9 status of each facility;
10 (B) any planned changes in mission, work-
11 load, or operating status of each facility;
12 (C) any planned investments or divest-
13 ments that may affect the capability or capacity
14 of any such facility; and
15 (D) a description of any action by the Sec-
16 retary of Defense taken pursuant to subsection
17 (c) or (d) during the one-year period preceding
18 submission of the report.
19 (f) DEFINITIONS.—In this section:
20 (1) MOTHBALL.—The term ‘‘mothball’’ means

16 of Defense shall require that the following oversight mech-
17 anisms are included in the final contract agreement:
18 (1) The prime contractor shall submit to the

20 terms and conditions of each subcontract agreement
21 related to capacity, performance, and compliance
22 with the contract requirements, which shall include
23 the following:
†S 2296 ES

194
1 (A) The guaranteed capacity of each sub-
2 contractor (including location, volume, and peak
3 season commitment).
4 (B) Performance metrics and service level
5 agreements applicable to each subcontractor.
6 (C) Provisions for monitoring and enforc-
7 ing subcontractor performance.
8 (D) Termination clauses and penalties for
9 noncompliance.
10 (E) Data sharing and security require-
11 ments.
12 (2) Each subcontractor shall provide to the
13 prime contractor, upon request, certifications and
14 copies of training completion relating to compliance
15 with requirements under the contract.
16 (3) The prime contractor shall submit to the
17 Secretary regular performance reports on its sub-
18 contractors, including metrics related to on-time
19 pickup, on-time delivery, damage claim rates, cus-
20 tomer satisfaction, and compliance with contract re-
21 quirements.
22 (4) The prime contractor shall submit to the
23 Secretary a subcontractor management plan out-
24 lining its processes for selecting, monitoring, and
25 managing subcontractors, including a description of
†S 2296 ES

195
1 how the prime contractor ensures subcontractor
2 compliance with all applicable laws, regulations, and
3 contract requirements.
4 (5) The prime contractor shall maintain a ro-
5 bust risk management plan that addresses potential
6 disruptions to the subcontractor network, such as fi-
7 nancial instability, natural disasters, or labor dis-
8 putes.
9 (6) Not less frequently than monthly, the prime
10 contractor shall submit to the Secretary the subcon-
11 tractor rating system used by the prime contractor,
12 with current scoring results under such system.
13 (7) The prime contractor shall submit to the
14 Secretary the subcontractor rates for each move
15 under the contract.
16 (8) The prime contractor shall establish clear
17 escalation procedures for addressing subcontractor
18 performance issues, including steps for resolving dis-
19 putes, implementing corrective actions, and termi-
20 nating non-performing subcontractors.
21 (9) The Federal Government shall be permitted
22 to audit subcontractor records with reasonable notice
23 to the prime contractor.
24 (10) The contract shall incorporate a fixed-price
25 contract line item number for monthly overhead,
†S 2296 ES

196
1 separating it from the rates associated with the costs
2 of moves.
3 (11) The prime contractor shall establish a
4 database that the Secretary can access on a real-

SEC. 514. NATIONAL GUARD PERSONNEL DISASTER RE-
4
SPONSE DUTY.
5 Chapter 3 of title 32, United States Code, is amend-
6 ed—
7 (1) by redesignating section 329 as section 330;
8 and
9 (2) by inserting after section 328 the following
10 new section:
11 ‘‘§329. Active Guard and Reserve duty: disaster re-
12 sponse duty
13 ‘‘(a) DISASTER RESPONSE AUTHORITY.—When a
14 Governor has declared an emergency due to a disaster, the
15 Secretary of Defense may authorize the Governor to direct
16 National Guard personnel serving under section 328 of
17 this title to perform duties in response to, or in prepara-
18 tion for, such disaster.
19 ‘‘(b) REQUIREMENTS.—The disaster response duty
20 described in subsection (a)—
21 ‘‘(1) may be performed to the extent that the
22 performance of the duty does not interfere with the
23 performance of the member’s primary Active Guard
24 and Reserve duties of organizing, administering, re-
†S 2296 ES

233
1 cruiting, instructing, and training the reserve com-
2 ponents; and
3 ‘‘(2) shall not exceed 14 days per person per
4 calendar year unless the President has declared a
5 disaster under title IV of the Robert T. Stafford
6 Disaster Relief and Emergency Assistance Act (42
7 U.S.C. 5170 et seq.).
8 ‘‘(c) LIABILITY.—A member described in subsection
9 (a) is not an instrumentality of the United States with
10 respect to any act or omission in carrying out a disaster
11 response duty pursuant to this section. The United States
12 shall not be responsible for any claim or judgment arising
13 from the use of National Guard personnel under this sec-
14 tion.
15 ‘‘(d) DEFINITIONS.—In this section:
16 ‘‘(1) The term ‘disaster response duty’ means
17 duty performed by a member of the National Guard
18 at the direction of the Governor of the State and
19 pursuant to an emergency declaration by such Gov-
20 ernor in response to a disaster or in preparation for
21 an imminent disaster.
22 ‘‘(2) The term ‘State’ means each of the several
23 States, the Commonwealth of Puerto Rico, Guam,
24 and the United States Virgin Islands.’’.

11 Force Academy do not permit a person whose sex is male

17 or activity that is designated for women or girls so long
18 as no female is deprived of a roster spot on a team or
19 sport, opportunity to participate in a practice or competi-
20 tion, scholarship, admission to an educational institution,
21 or any other benefit that accompanies participating in the
22 athletic program or activity.

18 fense; and

8 under section 1008(b) of title 37, United States Code, the
9 Secretary shall—
10 (1) develop a methodology to compute rates of

19 2027 for a minimum of 10 military housing areas.

9

OF THE ARMED FORCES STATIONED OVER-
11

12 (a) IN GENERAL.—The Secretary of Defense shall es-
13 tablish a program to provide Government-funded trans-
14 portation for unaccompanied members of the Armed
15 Forces from designated overseas locations to the members’
16 homes of record, or to other locations of comparable or
17 lesser cost, in accordance with this section.
18 (b) ELIGIBILITY.—Transportation under this section
19 may be provided to a member of the Armed Forces who—
20 (1) is assigned to an overseas duty location des-
21 ignated by the Secretary for purposes of this section;
22 (2) is serving an unaccompanied tour of at least
23 24 consecutive months at such location, including
24 any authorized extensions; and
†S 2296 ES

295
1 (3) is otherwise eligible in accordance with im-
2 plementing regulations prescribed by the Secretary.
3 (c) TRANSPORTATION MODE.—Transportation under
4 this section may be provided using military air in accord-
5 ance with established space-available policies or through
6 commercial air travel, as determined appropriate by the
7 Secretary.
8 (d) LIMITATIONS.—The Secretary may prescribe lim-
9 itations on the number of authorized trips per overseas
10 tour, and may restrict travel during certain periods at the
11 beginning or end of such tours.
12 (e) IMPLEMENTATION.—The Secretary shall pre-
13 scribe regulations to implement this section, including the
14 designation of eligible overseas duty locations and speci-
15 fied destinations.
16 (f) ADDITIONAL LIMITATIONS.—Transportation pro-
17 vided under this section shall be subject to applicable re-
18 strictions, including compliance with the Department of
19 Defense Foreign Clearance Guide, and limitations on the
20 use of Government travel cards for any leisure-related ex-
21 penses.

2

3
CARE PROGRAMS.
4 (a) IN GENERAL.—Not later than January 1, 2027,
5 the Comptroller General of the United States shall con-
6 duct a study on the structure and execution of the casualty
7 assistance and long-term care programs of the Armed
8 Forces.
9 (b) ELEMENTS.—In conducting the study required by
10 subsection (a), the Comptroller General shall assess op-
11 tions—
12 (1) to improve the standardization of the selec-
13 tion and management of casualty assistance officers
14 across the Armed Forces, including standardized
15 tour lengths similar to military recruiters;
16 (2) to improve the standardization, quality, and
17 proficiency of training for casualty assistance offi-
18 cers across the Armed Forces in requisite policies,
19 procedures, and knowledge of entitlements, benefits,
20 and financial obligations surviving families may en-
21 counter;
22 (3) to develop a Defense-wide survivor contact
23 registry allowing surviving families to voluntarily
24 provide contact information to ensure periodic check-
25 ins with surviving families during significant mile-
†S 2296 ES

300
1 stones following the death of a member of the
2 Armed Forces; and
3 (4) to develop an integrated Defense-wide long-
4 term care program for surviving families, modeled
5 on the Army’s Survivor Outreach Services, that pro-
6 vides information about survivor entitlements and
7 access to expert case managers and counselors.
8 (c) REPORT REQUIRED.—Not later than 180 days
9 after completing the study required by subsection (a), the
10 Comptroller General shall submit to the Committees on
11 Armed Services of the Senate and the House of Represent-
12 atives a report that includes—
13 (1) the results of the study;
14 (2) recommendations relating to the options as-
15 sessed under subsection (b); and
16 (3) a plan for implementing those recommenda-
17 tions.

20 (a) DEMONSTRATION PROGRAM REQUIRED.—Not-
21 withstanding section 1104 of title 10, United States Code,
22 the Secretary of Defense shall seek to establish a dem-
23 onstration program to expand partnerships between cov-
24 ered medical facilities of the Department of Defense and
25 the Department of Veterans Affairs.
†S 2296 ES

314
1 (b) PURPOSE.—The purpose of the demonstration
2 program under subsection (a) is to increase case volume
3 for graduate medical education programs of the Depart-
4 ment of Defense.
5 (c) PARAMETERS.—In seeking to establish a dem-
6 onstration program under subsection (a), the Secretary of
7 Defense shall make efforts to ensure the following:
8 (1) Credentialing and privileging of medical
9 personnel as necessary to work in any covered med-
10 ical facility.
11 (2) Expedited access to installations of the De-
12 partment of Defense for the purpose of providing
13 medical care under the demonstration program to
14 non-Department of Defense beneficiaries.
15 (3) Inclusion of ‘‘in-kind’’ or non-cash payment
16 or reimbursement for expenses incurred under the
17 demonstration program.
18 (d) ANNUAL BRIEFING.—Not later than December 1,
19 2026, and annually thereafter, the Secretary of Defense
20 shall provide to the Committees on Armed Services of the
21 Senate and the House of Representatives a briefing on the
22 implementation of this section.

24 section, the term ‘‘covered medical facility’’ means—
†S 2296 ES

315
1 (1) a medical facility of the Department of De-
2 fense with a certified graduate medical education
3 program; and

5 Veterans Affairs.

7 tember 30, 2032.

2

3

4 (a) RECOMMENDATIONS REQUIRED.—The Secretary
5 concerned, in consultation with each of the States

9 retary of Labor, shall develop recommendations to improve
10 the transition of medics under the jurisdiction of the Sec-

15 (a), the Secretary concerned shall—
16 (1) identify any barriers—
17 (A) to improving the ability of the Sec-
18 retary concerned to determine and communicate
19 how the military credentials and experience of
20 a medic separating from the Armed Forces
21 translate to credentialed civilian employment in
22 health care occupations;

24 among the Armed Forces of military medic cre-
25 dentials and experience and the alignment of
†S 2296 ES

319
1 such credentials and experience to credentialed
2 civilian employment in health care occupations;
3 (C) that exist to ensuring members of the
4 Armed Forces with military medic credentials
5 and experience have earned the equivalent civil-
6 ian credential prior to separation from the
7 Armed Forces in addition to receiving their
8 military credentials;
9 (D) to the increased establishment and up-
10 take of accelerated or bridge programs to assist
11 separating members of the Armed Forces in
12 translating military credentials and experience
13 into civilian health care credentials and employ-
14 ment;
15 (E) to increasing the availability and ac-

17 SkillBridge program established under section
18 1143(e) of title 10, United States Code, in the

14 and experience in health care;

SEC. 716. IMPROVEMENT OF PROVIDER DIRECTORY ACCU-
5
RACY FOR SPECIALTY CARE PROVIDERS
6
UNDER THE TRICARE PROGRAM.
7 (a) IN GENERAL.—By not later than five years after
8 the date of the enactment of this Act, the Director of the
9 Defense Health Agency (in this section referred to as the
10 ‘‘Director’’) shall ensure that the accuracy of the provider
11 directory under the TRICARE program for all specialty
12 care provider types reaches an average accuracy across all
13 specialty care providers of not less than 70 percent.
14 (b) MEASUREMENT OF ACCURACY.—Average accu-
15 racy under subsection (a) shall be measured biannually
16 and shall be disaggregated by provider type for each spe-
17 cialty care provider group.
18 (c) INCLUSION IN CONTRACTS.—The Director shall
19 ensure that each managed care contract under the
20 TRICARE program includes requirements that the man-
21 aged care contractor comply with the accuracy require-
22 ment under subsection (a), including by requiring each
23 such contractor to—
24 (1) conduct comprehensive outreach campaigns,
25 to include electronic and non-electronic means, and
†S 2296 ES

324
1 mass email campaigns to network providers pro-
2 viding—
3 (A) information relating to T–5 Contract
4 penalties associated with inaccurate provider di-
5 rectory information;
6 (B) resources; and
7 (C) direct links for providers to update
8 their directory information;
9 (2) make it a condition of joining the
10 TRICARE network managed by such contractor for
11 providers to validate their provider directory infor-
12 mation not less frequently than quarterly;
13 (3) ensure that when providers file for reim-
14 bursement, such providers are prompted to review
15 and verify their directory accuracy; and
16 (4) create a mechanism by which beneficiaries
17 under the TRICARE program can report provider
18 directory inaccuracy to the contractor.
19 (d) OTHER METHODS.—The Director shall carry out
20 any other methods that the Director finds useful for the
21 improvement of provider directory accuracy.
22 (e) TESTING OF DIRECTORY INFORMATION.—Not
23 less frequently than quarterly, the Inspector General of
24 the Department of Defense shall conduct random tests,
25 encompassing all specialty care provider types, of the accu-
†S 2296 ES

325
1 racy of information relating to specialty care providers
2 contained in the provider directory under the TRICARE
3 program.
4 (f) REPORTS AND BRIEFINGS.—
5 (1) IN GENERAL.—Not later than one year
6 after the date of the enactment of this Act, and an-
7 nually thereafter, the Director shall submit a report
8 and provide a briefing to the Committees on Armed
9 Services of the Senate and the House of Representa-
10 tives on progress towards reaching the average accu-
11 racy target required under subsection (a).
12 (2) ELEMENTS.—Each report under paragraph
13 (1) shall include, at a minimum, the following:
14 (A) A description of the techniques that
15 are most effective in improving accuracy of pro-
16 vider directories.
17 (B) An identification of the authorities or
18 tools that the Defense Health Agency lacks for
19 improving such accuracy.
20 (C) An identification of challenges specific
21 to each specialty care provider type that limit
22 such accuracy.
23 (D) An assessment of the impact of efforts
24 of the Defense Health Agency towards improv-
25 ing such accuracy on providers either leaving
†S 2296 ES

326
1 the TRICARE program or on the willingness of
2 non-network providers to join the TRICARE
3 program.
4 (g) COMPTROLLER GENERAL REVIEW.—Not later
5 than one year after the date of the enactment of this Act,
6 and annually thereafter, the Comptroller General of the
7 United States shall—
8 (1) conduct a holistic review of provider direc-
9 tory accuracy under the TRICARE program to
10 measure the progress of the Director towards meet-
11 ing the requirement under subsection (a); and
12 (2) submit to Congress a report on the review
13 conducted under paragraph (1).

SEC. 718. PROVISION OF HEALTH CARE SERVICES AT FORT
2
LEONARD WOOD, MISSOURI.
3 (a) ASSESSMENT.—The Secretary of Defense, in con-
4 sultation with the Secretary of the Army, shall conduct
5 an assessment of the adequacy of health care services
6 available to covered beneficiaries under the TRICARE
7 program located at Fort Leonard Wood, Missouri.
8 (b) ELEMENTS.—The assessment required by sub-
9 section (a) shall include the following elements:
10 (1) An evaluation of the ability of the local area
11 to provide adequate access to care for the covered
12 beneficiary population surrounding Fort Leonard
13 Wood.
14 (2) An evaluation of potential impacts to access
15 and quality of care for such beneficiaries if the Gen-
16 eral Leonard Wood Army Community Hospital were
17 to be realigned, downgraded, or have its scope of
18 services reduced.
19 (3) An evaluation of the ability to establish ad-
20 ditional partnerships with the Department of Vet-
21 erans Affairs for the provision of health care service
22 at the General Leonard Wood Army Community
23 Hospital.
24 (4) Such other matters as the Secretary con-
25 siders relevant for determining the continued viabil-
†S 2296 ES

330
1 ity of the General Leonard Wood Army Community
2 Hospital.
3 (c) PROHIBITION.—The Secretary of Defense may
4 not close, downgrade, or reduce the scope of care offered
5 by the General Leonard Wood Army Community Hospital
6 unless—
7 (1) the Secretary—
8 (A) completes the assessment required by
9 subsection (a) and delivers such assessment to
10 the Committees on Armed Services of the Sen-
11 ate and the House of Representatives; and
12 (B) certifies to the Committees on Armed
13 Services of the Senate and the House of Rep-
14 resentatives that any such changes would not
15 reduce or degrade the health care services avail-
16 able to covered beneficiaries and the local com-
17 munity; and
18 (2) the Chief of Staff of the Army certifies to
19 the Committees on Armed Services of the Senate
20 and the House of Representatives that there will be
21 no degradation of medical readiness of units as-
22 signed to Fort Leonard Wood as a result of any
23 changes to the status of the General Leonard Wood
24 Army Community Hospital.

4
SEARCH PLAN.
5 (a) PLAN.—Not later than 90 days after the date on

14 scribe—

18 linked to—
19 (A) military readiness;
20 (B) joint force requirements; and

24 section 1072(7) of title 10, United States
25 Code);
†S 2296 ES

332

7 fense;

9 Projects Agency;
10 (C) the United States Army Medical Re-
11 search Institute of Infectious Diseases;
12 (D) the Chemical and Biological Defense
13 Program; and
14 (E) the Defense Threat Reduction Agency;

16 military medical research community—

†S 2296 ES

SEC. 723. PILOT PROGRAM ON WASTEWATER SURVEIL-
2
LANCE SYSTEM OF DEPARTMENT OF DE-
3
FENSE.
4 (a) PILOT PROGRAM REQUIRED.—Commencing not
5 later than 180 days after the date of the enactment of
6 this Act, the Secretary of Defense shall carry out a pilot
7 program under which the Secretary shall develop and im-
8 plement a comprehensive wastewater surveillance system
9 at not fewer than four installations of a military depart-
10 ment at which the Secretary seeks to improve the testing,
11 identification, and analysis of usage of covered drugs and
12 to identify the prevalence of infectious diseases among
13 members of the Armed Forces at the installation (in this
14 section referred to as the ‘‘pilot program’’).
15 (b) TECHNOLOGIES AND DATA SYSTEM USED.—In
16 carrying out the pilot program, the Secretary shall ensure
17 the system developed and implemented under subsection
18 (a) is comprised of appropriate technologies and a uniform
19 data system across the Department of Defense.
20 (c) MINIMUM REQUIREMENTS.—In carrying out the
21 pilot program, the Secretary shall establish, at a min-
22 imum—
23 (1) at least one wastewater surveillance system
24 for monitoring of use of covered drugs at one instal-
25 lation; and
†S 2296 ES

338
1 (2) at least one wastewater surveillance system
2 for monitoring of infectious diseases at one installa-
3 tion.
4 (d) DURATION.—The pilot program shall be carried
5 out during a two-year period beginning on the date of the
6 commencement of the pilot program.
7 (e) REPORT.—Not later than 90 days after the termi-
8 nation of the pilot program, the Secretary shall submit
9 to the congressional defense committees a report that in-
10 cludes the following:
11 (1) A summary of the findings from the waste-
12 water surveillance system under the pilot program.
13 (2) Recommendations for interventions or policy
14 changes based on trends observed under the pilot
15 program.
16 (3) An assessment of the effectiveness of the
17 pilot program in enhancing force health protection
18 and readiness.
19 (f) COVERED DRUG DEFINED.—In this section, the
20 term ‘‘covered drug’’—
21 (1) except as provided in paragraph (2), means
22 a drug included on schedule I or schedule II estab-
23 lished under section 202 of the Controlled Sub-
24 stances Act (21 U.S.C. 812); and
25 (2) does not include a drug that—
†S 2296 ES

339
1 (A) was newly included on such schedule I
2 or schedule II;
3 (B) was previously approved under section
4 505 of the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic
5 Act (21 U.S.C. 355); and
6 (C) received such approval not later than
7 20 years before the date of the enactment of
8 this Act.

10 (a) DEFINITION.—Section 1737(a) of title 10, United
11 States Code, is amended by striking paragraph (4) and
12 inserting the following:
13 ‘‘(4) The term ‘portfolio acquisition executive’
14 refers to the member of the acquisition workforce re-
15 sponsible for the overall management of require-
16 ments, programming, and acquisition of defense ac-
17 quisition capabilities. These capabilities are assigned
18 by the service acquisition executive or component ac-
19 quisition executive. The portfolio acquisition execu-
20 tive has direct control over all necessary officials and
21 functional support, including the ability to provide
22 input into performance evaluations, to the maximum
23 extent practicable. This authority provides them with
24 all necessary authority to develop, procure, and sus-
25 tain military capabilities. For purposes of managing
†S 2296 ES

355
1 requirements, the portfolio acquisition executive is

5 service acquisition executive or component acquisi-
6 tion executive. The Secretary of Defense shall ensure
7 a minimum of non-statutory guidance and approvals
8 issued by officials external to the portfolio acquisi-
9 tion executives.’’.

11 (a) IN GENERAL.—Section 4401 of title 10, United
12 States Code, is amended to read as follows:
13 ‘‘§4401. Definitions
14 ‘‘In this chapter:
15 ‘‘(1) The term ‘authorized third party’ means
16 an entity approved by the Department of Defense to
17 access developer resources for integration or
18 sustainment.
19 ‘‘(2) The term ‘industry standards’ means wide-
20 ly adopted technical standards or protocols from rec-
21 ognized organizations.
22 ‘‘(3) The term ‘machine-readable format’ means
23 a format that can be easily processed by a computer
24 without human intervention.
25 ‘‘(4) The term ‘major system component’ —
†S 2296 ES

368
1 ‘‘(A) means a high-level subsystem or as-
2 sembly, including hardware, software, or an in-
3 tegrated assembly of both, that can be mounted
4 or installed on a major system platform through
5 modular system interfaces; and
6 ‘‘(B) includes a subsystem or assembly
7 that is likely to have additional capability re-
8 quirements, is likely to change because of evolv-
9 ing technology or threat, is needed for inter-
10 operability, facilitates incremental deployment
11 of capabilities, or is expected to be replaced by
12 another major system component.
13 ‘‘(5) The term ‘major system platform’ means
14 the highest level structure of a system that is not
15 physically mounted or installed onto a higher level
16 structure and on which a major system component
17 can be physically mounted or installed.
18 ‘‘(6) The term ‘modular open systems approach
19 (MOSA)’ means a system design approach using
20 modular systems, enabling innovation and competi-
21 tion in the development, sustainment, or upgrade of
22 weapon systems.
23 ‘‘(7) The term ‘modular system’ refers to a
24 weapon system or weapon system component that—
†S 2296 ES

369
1 ‘‘(A) is able to execute independently with-
2 out relying on the execution of other specific
3 systems or components;
4 ‘‘(B) can communicate across component
5 boundaries and through modular system inter-
6 faces; and
7 ‘‘(C) functions as a module that can be
8 separated, recombined, and connected with
9 other weapon systems or weapon systems com-
10 ponents in order to achieve various effects, mis-
11 sions, or capabilities.
12 ‘‘(8) The term ‘modular systems interfaces’
13 means a shared boundary between modular systems,
14 defined by various physical, logical, and functional
15 characteristics, such as electrical, mechanical,
16 fluidic, optical, radio frequency, data, networking, or
17 software elements, that is free of proprietary restric-
18 tions and documented via a machine-readable for-
19 mat, including—
20 ‘‘(A) software-defined interface syntax and
21 properties, specifically governing how values are
22 validly passed to and received;
23 ‘‘(B) definition of the relationship between
24 the delivered interface and interfaces available
†S 2296 ES

370
1 in the repositories established pursuant to sec-
2 tion 4403 of this title; and
3 ‘‘(C) test cases, including example code,
4 demonstrating the proper use of the modular
5 systems interface.
6 ‘‘(9) The term ‘operational data’ means govern-
7 ment-owned data generated by or necessary for sys-
8 tem operation, maintenance, or enhancement.’’.

SEC. 805. ALTERNATIVE TEST AND EVALUATION PATHWAY
22
FOR DESIGNATED DEFENSE ACQUISITION
23
PROGRAMS.
24 (a) AUTHORITY.—The Secretary of Defense shall
25 issue guidance to establish an alternative test and evalua-
†S 2296 ES

376
1 tion (T&E) pathway for certain Department of Defense
2 acquisition programs to enhance agility, accelerate deliv-
3 ery of capabilities, and ensure data-driven decisionmaking,
4 while maintaining independent oversight of evaluation out-
5 comes.
6 (b) ALTERNATIVE TEST AND EVALUATION PATH-
7 WAY.—The Secretary of Defense shall establish an alter-
8 native test and evaluation pathway for covered programs
9 that includes the following requirements:
10 (1) For each covered program, the military de-
11 partment concerned, through its service test activi-
12 ties, shall—
13 (A) design and execute a unified test and
14 evaluation strategy that aligns developmental
15 testing (DT) and operational testing (OT) to a
16 single set of test objectives that build system
17 understanding throughout the test program to
18 more effectively support capability delivery
19 within rapid prototyping and iterative updates
20 with early and continuous operational feedback;
21 (B) develop and execute a test data strat-
22 egy, updated as needed, that includes—
23 (i) collection of raw data from system
24 components during test events and oper-
25 ational activities, including submission of
†S 2296 ES

377
1 industry derived data from their develop-
2 ment and testing evolutions;
3 (ii) evaluation criteria to assess the
4 mission effects and suitability of the sys-
5 tem based on the data to be collected, in-
6 cluding from live-fire test events, if appli-
7 cable;
8 (iii) a process for independently vali-
9 dating industry test results, if needed;
10 (iv) provision of resources for auto-
11 mated data collection, storage, and access;
12 and
13 (v) automated analytics tools to assess
14 performance trends, reliability, and main-
15 tenance needs;
16 (C) incorporate, to the maximum extent
17 practicable, best practices such as—
18 (i) hardware-in-the-loop testing to
19 validate system integration;
20 (ii) continuous data collection from
21 prototypes and fielded systems to refine
22 designs and update lifecycle costs;
23 (iii) test subsystem prototypes
24 throughout system development to assess
†S 2296 ES

378
1 their contribution to the mission effect of
2 the fielded system; and
3 (iv) integration of supporting or com-
4 plementary data from digital twins or
5 other model-based systems engineering
6 tools;
7 (D) define general test and evaluation ob-
8 jectives and data needs while allowing detailed
9 execution plans to evolve based on test results
10 and emerging requirements, avoiding rigid mile-
11 stone-driven schedules; and
12 (E) ensure all raw test data and associated
13 analytics are owned by the government, stored
14 in accessible repositories, and available to au-
15 thorized Department entities, including the Di-
16 rector of Operational Test & Evaluation
17 (DOT&E), throughout the program lifecycle.
18 (2) Covered programs under this pathway shall
19 be exempt from—
20 (A) the requirement to develop and submit

22 under Department of Defense Instruction
23 5000.02 or other policies, provided a unified
24 test and evaluation strategy and data strategy
†S 2296 ES

1 under subparagraphs (A) and (B) of paragraph
2 (1) are implemented;
3 (B) milestone-specific operational test

8 (C) any other test and evaluation docu-

21 (4) include in its annual report to Congress

9 TION.—Upon completion of an experiment, prototype, or

1 (2) incurred to pay a financing entity.
2 (b) DEFINITIONS.—In this section:
3 (1) The term ‘‘covered activity’’ means an activ-
4 ity taken by a prime contractor or subcontractor—
5 (A) to manage an inventory of completed
6 products or components used in production;
7 (B) to improve inventory management of
8 products or components necessary for
9 sustainment or maintenance;
10 (C) to materially expand the capacity of
11 production or sustainment and maintenance
12 through capital expenditures; or
13 (D) to carry out any other purpose identi-
14 fied by the Secretary of Defense.
15 (2) The term ‘‘financing costs’’ means interest
16 on borrowings, bond discounts, and costs of financ-
17 ing and refinancing capital.
18 (3) The term ‘‘financing entity’’ means any cor-
19 poration, limited liability company, partnership,
20 trust, or other organization that is created under
21 Federal or State law and that, as part of its regular
22 business activities, extends credit, loans, or other
23 forms of financing to other persons or entities, pro-
24 vided that such legal entity is not owned by, con-
†S 2296 ES

386
1 trolled by, or under common control with the person
2 or entity receiving such financing.

SEC. 834. UNINSURABLE RISK ON CERTAIN CONTRACTS.
6 (a) CONSIDERATION OF RISK OF LOSS.—The Sec-
7 retary of Defense shall ensure that due consideration is
8 given to a contractor for equitable adjustments resulting
9 from the loss of work in process on a covered contract.
10 (b) LIMITATIONS.—Considerations limiting the con-
11 tractor’s assumption of the risk of loss in subsection (a)
12 shall not apply to loss caused by the willful misconduct
13 or lack of good faith on the part of any of the contractor’s
14 directors or officers, managers, superintendents, or other
15 equivalent representatives.
16 (c) DEFINITIONS.—In this section:
17 (1) COVERED CONTRACT.—The term ‘‘covered
18 contract’’ means any classified, fixed-price type con-
19 tract, entered into with the Department of Defense
20 on or after the date of the enactment of this section
21 where, due to the classified nature of the underlying
22 program—
23 (A) the contractor cannot get a third-party
24 commercial insurance provider to insure the
25 work in process; or
†S 2296 ES

402
1 (B) the third-party commercial insurance
2 provider cannot process the contractor’s claim.
3 (2) LACK OF GOOD FAITH.—The term ‘‘lack of
4 good faith’’ has the meaning given the term in sec-
5 tion 252.228–7001 of the Department of Defense
6 Supplement to the Federal Acquisition Regulation,
7 or any successor regulation.
8 (3) WILLFUL MISCONDUCT.—The term ‘‘willful
9 misconduct’’ has the meaning given the term in sec-
10 tion 252.228–7001 of the Department of Defense
11 Supplement to the Federal Acquisition Regulation,
12 or any successor regulation.
13 (4) WORK IN PROCESS.—The term ‘‘work in
14 process’’—
15 (A) means an item at any stage of produc-
16 tion or manufacture at any time from the initi-
17 ation of contract performance until delivery to
18 and acceptance by the government; and
19 (B) specifically includes a ‘‘covered air-
20 craft’’ as that term is defined in section
21 252.228–7001 of the Department of Defense
22 Supplement to the Federal Acquisition Regula-
23 tion, or any successor regulation.
24 (d) CONFORMING REGULATIONS.—Not later than
25 120 days after the date of the enactment of this Act, the
†S 2296 ES

403
1 Secretary of Defense shall revise the Department of De-
2 fense Supplement to the Federal Acquisition Regulation
3 to conform with the changes made by this section.

6 PRICES.—Chapter 271 of title 10, United States Code, is

8 ‘‘§3709. Reporting of increases above specified prices

13 ‘‘(1) 25 percent above the price specified in the

15 or service the previous calendar year; or
16 ‘‘(2) 50 percent above the price paid for such
17 a product or service 5 years earlier.

19 tion, the term ‘covered contract’ means a cost-reimburse-

SEC. 836. INSTRUCTIONS FOR CONTINUED OPERATIONAL
22
READINESS.

†S 2296 ES

405
1 ‘‘§4664. Instructions for continued operational readi-
2 ness
3 ‘‘(a) REQUIREMENT TO DELIVER INSTRUCTIONS.—
4 (1) The Secretary of Defense (referred to in this section
5 as the ‘Secretary’) may not enter into a contract or agree-
6 ment for the procurement, sustainment, or subsequent
7 modifications of covered defense equipment unless the con-
8 tract or agreement requires that the contractor deliver, or
9 offer as a negotiated price option, Instructions for Contin-
10 ued Operational Readiness (‘ICOR’) to the Secretary upon
11 delivery of the equipment.
12 ‘‘(2) The Secretary may grant an exception to para-
13 graph (1) if the product support strategy and associated
14 business case analysis for the covered defense equipment
15 indicates that the Government does not have a justified
16 need for ICOR, consistent, when applicable, with section
17 3771 of this title.
18 ‘‘(3) The contractor shall deliver the ICOR to the De-
19 partment of Defense (referred to in this section as the
20 ‘Department’) and provide the Secretary with the rights
21 to diagnose, maintain, and repair the covered defense
22 equipment.
23 ‘‘(4) The Secretary shall withhold payment to the
24 contractor under the contract or agreement until the Sec-
25 retary accepts the ICOR as complete under subsection
26 (c)(2).
†S 2296 ES

406
1 ‘‘(5) When ICOR are required to be delivered under
2 a contract or agreement, the Secretary shall ensure that
3 updated ICOR data is required as necessary in subsequent
4 contracts or agreements or included as priced options to
5 reflect modifications in data deliverables.
6 ‘‘(b) CONTENTS OF INSTRUCTIONS FOR CONTINUED
7 OPERATIONAL READINESS.—A contractor for covered de-
8 fense equipment shall include in the ICOR, at a minimum,
9 data that is necessary for operations, maintenance, instal-
10 lation, and training, form fit, and function data, and any
11 additional data required for operational readiness, which
12 may include—
13 ‘‘(1) recommended methods, techniques, inspec-
14 tions, processes, procedures, maintenance manuals,
15 service bulletins, diagnostic procedures, proprietary
16 systems, special tooling, special testing procedures,
17 and equipment necessary to maintain, repair, and
18 sustain the covered defense equipment in a condition
19 for safe and effective operation, including diagnostic
20 protocols, troubleshooting guides, and overhaul in-
21 structions, consistent with the maintenance practices
22 of the contractor or those of the authorized mainte-
23 nance providers of the contractor;
24 ‘‘(2) an operational limitations section (‘OLS’)
25 that includes mandatory schedules for replacement
†S 2296 ES

407
1 of life-limited components, inspection intervals, and
2 other sustainment requirements critical to equip-
3 ment reliability and safety, approved by the Sec-
4 retary;
5 ‘‘(3) engineering drawings, schematics, soft-
6 ware, and wiring diagrams;
7 ‘‘(4) a complete list of replacement parts, com-
8 ponents, and specialized equipment required for
9 maintenance and repair, including part numbers,
10 specifications, and sources, to ensure availability to
11 authorized maintenance providers;
12 ‘‘(5) procedures for documenting maintenance
13 actions, life-limited component replacements, and
14 compliance with the OLS, including standardized
15 formats for maintenance logs to ensure traceability
16 and verification of operational readiness; and
17 ‘‘(6) clear identification of maintenance infor-
18 mation essential for safe operation, distinguished
19 from non-safety-related service enhancements, to fa-
20 cilitate compliance with operational readiness re-
21 quirements.
22 ‘‘(c) SUBMISSION, ACCEPTANCE, AND UPDATES.—(1)
23 A contractor shall submit the ICOR to the Secretary as
24 a contract deliverable prior to equipment delivery or within
25 a timeframe specified by the contract.
†S 2296 ES

408
1 ‘‘(2) The Secretary shall review and accept the ICOR,
2 verifying that they provide sufficient information to main-
3 tain the operational readiness of the equipment.
4 ‘‘(3) In accordance with design changes and contract
5 modifications approved by the Secretary and in a manner
6 that is in accordance with subsection (a), the contractor
7 shall deliver updates to the ICOR for approval by the Sec-
8 retary whenever modifications, upgrades, safety issues, or
9 new sustainment requirements are identified.
10 ‘‘(d) MAINTENANCE AND REPAIR PROVIDERS.—A
11 contractor shall not impose restrictions on the use of the
12 ICOR by authorized maintenance providers of the Depart-
13 ment, including requirements to use only contractor-sup-
14 plied parts, unless such restrictions are explicitly approved
15 by the Secretary as necessary for safety or operational re-
16 liability.
17 ‘‘(e) CONDITIONS FOR ALTERNATIVE MAINTENANCE
18 AND REPAIR.—(1) Notwithstanding restrictions approved
19 by the Secretary pursuant to subsection (d), the Secretary
20 may authorize alternative maintenance or repair actions
21 for covered defense equipment, if any of the following con-
22 ditions are met:
23 ‘‘(A) A program cannot reasonably obtain suffi-
24 cient data to maintain operational readiness.
†S 2296 ES

409
1 ‘‘(B) The contractor fails to deliver complete
2 and current ICOR.
3 ‘‘(C) The contractor cannot deliver required
4 parts, repairs, or ICOR within a timeframe that
5 meets operational needs, as defined by the Secretary,
6 resulting in unacceptable readiness degradation.
7 ‘‘(D) The contractor discontinues support for a
8 component or software critical to the equipment’s
9 operation without providing a viable substitute or
10 sufficient ICOR to enable sustainment of the equip-
11 ment by the Department.
12 ‘‘(E) An urgent operational or logistical cir-
13 cumstance, such as wartime conditions, active com-
14 bat, or disrupted logistics, necessitates immediate re-
15 pair or part production to maintain mission readi-
16 ness.
17 ‘‘(F) The Secretary determines alternative
18 maintenance or repair actions would result in signifi-
19 cant cost savings.
20 ‘‘(2) If an alternative action is authorized under para-
21 graph (1), the Secretary may—
22 ‘‘(A) issue a written determination citing the
23 relevant condition described in paragraph (1), in-
24 cluding evidence of contractor practices that prevent
25 delivery of or restrict license rights to the ICOR in
†S 2296 ES

410
1 a manner that may impede competition, consistent
2 with antitrust laws; and
3 ‘‘(B) authorize data delivery for the alternative
4 action.
5 ‘‘(3) If time permits, the Secretary shall notify the
6 contractor if any of the conditions described in paragraph
7 (1) are met and shall provide the contractor with not more
8 than 30 days to address the issue before the alternative
9 action is taken.
10 ‘‘(4) Alternative maintenance or repair actions may
11 include, but is not limited to, reverse engineering, use of
12 existing technical data, fabrication of parts by the Depart-
13 ment or third-party providers, or advanced manufacturing,
14 as necessary to restore operational readiness. This provi-
15 sion does not restrict the ability of the Secretary to employ
16 these practices in other contexts.
17 ‘‘(f) CONTRACTOR RESPONSIBILITIES.—(1) A con-
18 tractor shall ensure the ICOR contains sufficient informa-
19 tion to maintain the operational readiness of the equip-
20 ment, including updates to address safety or performance
21 issues and necessary information on systems or compo-
22 nents produced by subcontractors.
23 ‘‘(2) A contractor shall promptly notify the Secretary
24 of any safety-related deficiencies in the ICOR and provide
25 corrected materials at no additional cost.
†S 2296 ES

411
1 ‘‘(3) If a contractor fails to comply with the require-
2 ments of this section, the Secretary may withhold contract
3 payment, enforce contract penalties, take corrective ac-
4 tion, reduce contractor performance ratings, or exclude
5 the contractor from future contracts or agreements with
6 the Department.
7 ‘‘(g) OVERSIGHT.—(1) The Secretary shall establish
8 procedures to verify contractor compliance with the re-
9 quirements of this section, including periodic audits of the
10 content and availability and maintenance of ICOR.
11 ‘‘(2) The Secretary shall maintain a centralized re-
12 pository of ICOR for covered defense equipment, acces-
13 sible to maintenance providers authorized by the Sec-
14 retary, to ensure consistent application.
15 ‘‘(h) REPORT.—Not later than one year after the
16 date of the enactment of this section, and every year there-
17 after, the Secretary shall submit to the congressional de-
18 fense committees a list of the items designated as excluded
19 commercial items to which the requirement to deliver
20 ICOR does not apply.
21 ‘‘(i) DEFINITIONS.—In this section:
22 ‘‘(1) The term ‘covered defense equipment’
23 means any system, subsystem, or component pro-
24 cured by the Secretary, including aircraft, ships,
25 ground vehicles, electronic systems, and other sys-
†S 2296 ES

412
1 tems, that require contractor-provided maintenance
2 or repair data to ensure operational readiness, ex-
3 cluding any excluded commercial items.
4 ‘‘(2) The term ‘excluded commercial item’
5 means an unmodified product customarily used by
6 the general public or by nongovernmental entities or
7 sold, leased, or licensed to the general public and
8 maintained under standard commercial practices, as
9 designated by the Secretary.
10 ‘‘(3) The terms ‘Instructions for Continued
11 Operational Readiness’ and ‘ICOR’ mean contractor-
12 provided technical data, software, and other infor-
13 mation, including maintenance instructions and
14 manuals, operational limitations, parts identification,
15 record-keeping procedures, safety-related provisions,
16 engineering drawings, schematics, software, service
17 bulletins, wiring diagrams, diagnostic procedures,
18 and other data or information necessary to maintain
19 and repair covered defense equipment in a condition
20 for safe and effective operation.’’.

SEC. 848. PROHIBITING THE PURCHASE OF PHOTOVOLTAIC
4
MODULES OR INVERTERS FROM FOREIGN
5
ENTITIES OF CONCERN.
6 (a) IN GENERAL.—None of the funds authorized to
7 be appropriated or otherwise made available by this Act
8 may be used to enter into a contract for the procurement
9 of photovoltaic modules manufactured by a foreign entity
10 of concern (as defined by section 9901(8) of the William
11 M. (Mac) Thornberry National Defense Authorization Act
12 for Fiscal Year 2021 (15 U.S.C. 4651(8)).
13 (b) WAIVER AUTHORITY.—The Secretary of Defense
14 may waive subsection (a) if the Secretary—
15 (1) determines that there is no alternative
16 source of photovoltaic cells, modules, or inverters
17 other than from a foreign entity of concern;
18 (2) determines there is no national security risk
19 posed by the use of photovoltaic cells, modules, or
20 inverters manufactured by a foreign entity of con-
21 cern; and
22 (3) submits a certification of such determina-
23 tion in writing to the congressional defense commit-
24 tees not later than 30 days before entering into a
25 contract described under such subsection.
†S 2296 ES

429
1 (c) LIMITATION.—
2 (1) IN GENERAL.—Subsection (a) shall apply
3 only to contracts regarding the direct procurement
4 by the Department of Defense of photovoltaic mod-
5 ules or inverters and shall not apply to contracts in-
6 volving any third party financing arrangements, in-
7 cluding energy savings contracts and those involving
8 privatized military housing or assets that enhance
9 combat capability.
10 (2) DELAYED EFFECTIVE DATE FOR ASSETS
11 THAT ENHANCE COMBAT CAPABILITY.—The prohibi-
12 tion under subsection (a) shall not apply to assets
13 that enhance combat capability for a period of one
14 year following the date of the enactment of this Act,
15 in order for the Department of Defense to determine
16 alternate supply chains for such assets.
17 (d) EXEMPTION FOR CERTAIN ACTIVITIES.—The
18 prohibition under subsection (a) shall not apply if the op-
19 eration, procurement, or contracting action is for the pur-
20 poses of intelligence, electronic warfare, and information
21 warfare operations, testing, analysis, and training.

SEC. 849B. REPORT ON UNITED STATES BOOT INDUSTRIAL
2
BASE AND BERRY AMENDMENT COMPLIANCE.
3 (a) REPORT REQUIRED.—Not later than 90 days
4 after the date of the enactment of this Act, the Secretary
5 of Defense shall submit to the congressional defense com-
6 mittees a report on the United States boot industrial base,
7 including a comprehensive plan for the Department of De-
8 fense to fully comply with the requirements under section
9 4862 of title 10, United States Code (commonly referred
10 to as the ‘‘Berry Amendment’’) by not later than fiscal
11 year 2028.
12 (b) ELEMENTS.—The report required under sub-
13 section (a) shall include the following elements:
14 (1) A detailed description of current and surge
15 manufacturing capacity for Berry-compliant, govern-
16 ment-issued boots, including suppliers of leather,
17 textiles, soles, and components, as well as risks to
18 supply chain resilience and small business participa-
19 tion. Surge manufacturing capacity includes all
20 major domestic manufacturers of boots including
21 those not currently supplying Berry-compliant boots.
22 (2) A market survey of domestic boot manufac-
23 turers regarding interest in producing Berry-compli-
24 ant boots if there were to be a requirement that all
25 members of the Armed Forces are required to only
26 wear Berry-compliant boots.
†S 2296 ES

446
1 (3) A time-phased schedule of actions, mile-
2 stones, and resources required to achieve full Berry
3 Amendment compliance for combat footwear across
4 all military services by fiscal year 2028.
5 (4) An assessment of how current policies al-
6 lowing the wear of ‘‘optional combat boots’’ that are
7 not Berry-compliant undermine the intent of the
8 Berry Amendment and weaken the United States in-
9 dustrial base, and recommendations for coming into
10 compliance.
11 (5) A plan to implement and enforce narrowly
12 tailored availability and medical exemptions, as au-
13 thorized under section 4862(c) of title 10, United
14 States Code, with controls to prevent overuse.
15 (6) Steps to expand industrial capacity for
16 Berry-compliant government-issued boots through
17 multiyear contracting, demand forecasting, inventory
18 planning, and attracting new Berry-compliant sup-
19 pliers by requiring that optional boots must be
20 Berry-compliant.

450
1 quisition University and the Eisenhower School at

7 as industrial security, counterintelligence, and fi-
8 nance;
9 (5) the workload and span of control over con-
10 tracting actions, based on contract award value and

SEC. 863. EXPEDITED ACCEPTANCE PROGRAM FOR SUPPLY
2
CHAIN ILLUMINATION.
3 (a) ELIGIBILITY FOR EXPEDITED INTERIM NA-
4 TIONAL SECURITY WAIVER.—
5 (1) IN GENERAL.—If a contractor, through the
6 use of supply chain illumination policies, procedures,
7 or analytical tools, discovers an item in the supply
8 chain that is non-compliant with the restrictions out-
9 lined in subsection (d) but promptly discloses that
10 discovery to the program office, the contractor shall
11 be eligible for an expedited interim national security
12 waiver in accordance with subsection (b) to deliver
13 a capability, provided that the program manager is
14 satisfied with the contractor’s corrective plan de-
15 scribed in subsection (e).
16 (2) DISCLOSURES.—Disclosures that are eligi-
17 ble under paragraph (1) include any disclosures
18 made by the contractor to the program office, in-
19 cluding disclosures resulting from supply chain illu-
20 mination efforts conducted by the contractor, a sub-
21 contractor, or by a third-party entity acting on be-
22 half of the contractor or sub-contractor to increase
23 supply chain transparency. Discoveries of non-com-
24 pliance by the United States Government do not
25 constitute eligible disclosures under paragraph (1).
26 (b) INTERIM NATIONAL SECURITY WAIVER.—

SEC. 864. SIMULTANEOUS CONFLICTS CRITICAL MUNI-
6
TIONS REPORT.
7 (a) REPORT.—
8 (1) IN GENERAL.—Not later than 180 days
9 after the date of the enactment of this Act, the Sec-
10 retary of Defense shall submit to the congressional
11 defense committees a report that details the stock-
12 piles of critical munitions required to fight simulta-
13 neous conflicts in different theaters.
14 (2) ELEMENTS.—The report required under
15 paragraph (1) shall include the following elements:
16 (A) An estimate of the amount of each
17 critical munition that would be required over
18 the course of simultaneous conflicts, modeled on
19 the assumption that a contingency operation in
20 any one of the western Pacific, Europe, Middle
21 East, or Korean Peninsula theaters would in-
22 crease the likelihood of a contingency operation
23 in the other theaters, including consideration of
24 the prepositioning of stockpiles and the risk
25 posed by moving stocks out of each theater.
†S 2296 ES

458
1 (B) The number of days before the joint
2 force would exhaust its current stockpiles of
3 critical munitions during simultaneous conflicts.
4 (C) An estimate of the time required for
5 the industrial base to replenish critical munition
6 inventories during a simultaneous conflict, tak-
7 ing into account the Out-Year Unconstrained
8 Total Munitions Requirement directed by sec-
9 tion 222c of title 10, United States Code, and
10 the study required by section 1705 of the
11 James M. Inhofe National Defense Authoriza-

SEC. 866. ESTIMATE OF ALLY AND PARTNER DEMAND FOR
8
UNITED STATES-PRODUCED MUNITIONS AND
9
SPECIFIED EXPENDABLES.
10 (a) IN GENERAL.—The Secretary of Defense shall es-
11 tablish an annual requirement for the production of an
12 estimate of the demand by United States allies and part-
13 ners for United States-produced munitions and specified
14 expendables across the future-years defense plan.
15 (b) ELEMENTS.—Each estimate required under sub-
16 section (a)—
17 (1) shall be disaggregated by specific munitions
18 type and ally or partner; and
19 (2) shall include analytical inputs, such as—
20 (A) information set forth in all approved
21 letters of offer and acceptance from foreign
22 military sales cases;
23 (B) assessments of all letters of request
24 from foreign military sales cases;
†S 2296 ES

462
1 (C) estimates based on an operational
2 analysis of foreign partner munitions needs for
3 critical operational or contingency planning sce-
4 narios;
5 (D) estimates based on an analysis of
6 wargaming results that include foreign partner
7 contributions in the relevant scenario; and
8 (E) estimates based on bilateral or multi-
9 lateral discussions between the United States
10 Government and foreign governments.
11 (c) GUIDANCE.—
12 (1) IN GENERAL.—Not later than March 1,
13 2026, the Secretary of Defense shall issue guidance
14 for the development and collection of data necessary
15 to support the production of the estimate required
16 by subsection (a).
17 (2) ELEMENTS.—The guidance required by
18 paragraph (1) shall include—
19 (A) a consideration of the manner in which
20 the requirement for such an estimate may be le-
21 veraged to support operational and contingency
22 planning activities, wargaming, and net assess-
23 ment activities; and
24 (B) an analysis of the effect of the addi-
25 tion of such an estimate to the Out-Year Un-
†S 2296 ES

463
1 constrained Total Munitions Requirement re-
2 quired by section 222c of title 10, United
3 States Code.
4 (d) ASSESSMENT OF INFORMATION SYSTEMS.—
5 (1) IN GENERAL.—Not later than March 30,
6 2026, the Secretary of Defense shall conduct an as-
7 sessment of existing relevant Department of Defense
8 information systems of record to determine whether
9 any such system, or combination of such systems,
10 may be used or modified to collect and analyze data
11 necessary to support the production of the estimate
12 required by subsection (a) on an ongoing basis.
13 (2) CONSIDERATION.—The assessment required
14 by paragraph (1) shall take into consideration—
15 (A) the cost and technical challenges of
16 adopting or adapting a system described in that
17 paragraph, or combination of such systems, for
18 the purpose described in that paragraph; and
19 (B) the estimated cost and technical chal-
20 lenges of establishing a new information system
21 of record for such purpose.
22 (e) SPECIFIED EXPENDABLES DEFINED.—In this
23 section, the term ‘‘specific expendables’’ includes—
24 (1) chaff;
25 (2) flares;
†S 2296 ES

464
1 (3) sonobouys;
2 (4) decoys;
3 (5) disposable jammers; and
4 (6) any other expendable the Secretary of De-
5 fense considers appropriate.
