SEC. 867. REFORM OF CONTRACTOR PERFORMANCE IN-
7
FORMATION REQUIREMENTS.
8 (a) IN GENERAL.—Not later than 180 days after the
9 date of the enactment of this Act, the Secretary of Defense
10 shall revise subpart 242.15 of the Defense Federal Acqui-
11 sition Regulation Supplement (DFARS) to modify con-
12 tractor performance information requirements to establish
13 an objective, fact-based, and simplified system for report-
14 ing contractor performance. The revised system shall—
15 (1) focus exclusively on negative performance
16 events that are verifiable and measurable to reduce
17 subjectivity and inconsistency in evaluations;
18 (2) reduce the administrative burden on con-
19 tracting officers by limiting reporting to prior con-
20 tractor failures or poor performance; and
21 (3) ensure the government can identify and
22 avoid contractors with a history of poor performance
23 or bad actions.
24 (b) REVISION OF CONTRACTOR PERFORMANCE IN-
25 FORMATION REQUIREMENTS.—Not later than 180 days
†S 2296 ES

465
1 after the date of the enactment of this Act, the Secretary
2 of Defense shall revise subpart 242.15 of the DFARS and
3 related guidance, including the Contractor Performance
4 Assessment Reporting System (CPARS) to provide for the
5 following requirements related to contract performance in-
6 formation:
7 (1) ELIMINATION OF SUBJECTIVE PERFORM-
8 ANCE RATINGS.—(A) Subjective performance ratings
9 for contracts subject to this section shall be elimi-
10 nated.
11 (B) Performance evaluations shall be limited to
12 the reporting and scoring of negative performance
13 events as described in subsections (c) and (d).
14 (2) SCOPE OF REPORTING.—(A) Contracting
15 officers shall report only negative performance
16 events with verifiable data which have a material im-
17 pact on contract performance or government inter-
18 ests, including events involving subcontractors.
19 (B) Reporting shall exclude positive or neutral
20 performance assessments, except as necessary to
21 provide context for a negative performance event.
22 (3) FREQUENCY AND TIMING.—(A) Contracting
23 officers shall report negative performance events
24 within 30 days of identifying and verifying the event.
†S 2296 ES

466
1 (B) Annual or periodic performance evaluations
2 shall not be required unless a negative performance
3 event occurs.
4 (4) USE IN SOURCE SELECTION.—(A) Negative
5 performance events and their associated scores, as
6 calculated under subsection (c), shall be considered
7 in source selection evaluations to assess contractor
8 risk and responsibility.
9 (B) The absence of negative performance events
10 for a contractor, including nontraditional defense
11 contractors or new entrants, shall not be considered
12 a deficiency in past performance evaluations. Such
13 contractors shall be evaluated based on technical ca-
14 pability, price, and other relevant factors.
15 (c) SCORING MECHANISM FOR NEGATIVE PERFORM-
16 ANCE EVENTS.—Not later than 180 days after the date
17 of the enactment of this Act, the Secretary of Defense
18 shall revise subpart 242.15 of the DFARS and related
19 guidance, including the Contractor Performance Assess-
20 ment Reporting System (CPARS) to provide for the fol-
21 lowing requirements related to a scoring mechanism for
22 negative performance events:
23 (1) STANDARDIZED SCORING MECHANISM.—To
24 ensure fair and equitable evaluation of contractors,
25 a standardized scoring mechanism shall normalize
†S 2296 ES

467
1 negative performance events based on the number of
2 transactions and the dollar volume of contracts per-
3 formed by the contractor.
4 (2) APPLICATION OF SCORES.—(A) The com-
5 posite score shall be reported in CPARS alongside
6 the negative performance events and used in source
7 selection to assess past performance risk.
8 (B) Scores shall be calculated automatically by
9 the CPARS system based on data entered by con-
10 tracting officers, including the number of trans-
11 actions and contract dollar value.
12 (3) TRANSPARENCY.—(A) Contractors shall
13 have access to their composite scores and the under-
14 lying data (number of events, transactions, and dol-
15 lar volume) through CPARS.
16 (B) Contractors may submit comments or
17 rebuttals to reported events or scores, which shall be
18 maintained in CPARS for consideration in source se-
19 lection.
20 (d) KEY ISSUES OF NEGATIVE PERFORMANCE.—Not
21 later than 180 days after the date of the enactment of
22 this Act, the Secretary of Defense shall revise subpart
23 242.15 of the DFARS and related guidance, including the
24 Contractor Performance Assessment Reporting System
†S 2296 ES

468
1 (CPARS) to provide for the following requirements related
2 to key issues of negative performance:
3 (1) MANDATORY REPORTING.—Contracting offi-
4 cers shall report the following negative performance
5 events, based on verifiable data or objective evalua-
6 tions:
7 (A) DELIVERY OF DEFECTIVE PROD-
8 UCTS.—Delivery of products failing to meet
9 contract requirements, as verified by govern-
10 ment inspection reports, quality assurance
11 records, or testing results.
12 (B) DELINQUENT DELIVERIES.—Failure to
13 meet contract delivery schedules, as documented
14 in contract milestones, delivery orders, or gov-
15 ernment correspondence.
16 (C) IMPROPER MARKINGS OR RIGHTS AS-
17 SERTIONS ON TECHNICAL DATA DELIVERIES.—
18 Incorrect or unauthorized markings on tech-
19 nical data or software, or improper assertions
20 of restrictive rights, as verified by government
21 review or legal findings.
22 (D) DEFECTIVE PRICING.—Submission of
23 inaccurate, incomplete, or misleading cost or
24 pricing data, as identified through audits by the
†S 2296 ES

469
1 Defense Contract Audit Agency (DCAA) or
2 other authorities.
3 (E) FAILURE TO FLOW DOWN REQUIRED
4 CLAUSES TO SUBCONTRACTORS.—Failure to in-
5 clude mandatory contract clauses in sub-
6 contracts, as verified by contract reviews or au-
7 dits.
8 (F) FALSE CLAIMS OR MISREPRESENTA-
9 TIONS.—Submission of false claims, fraudulent
10 invoices, or misrepresentations, as substantiated
11 by investigations, legal findings, or government
12 records.
13 (G) NON-COMPLIANCE WITH SAFETY OR
14 REGULATORY REQUIREMENTS.—Failure to com-
15 ply with safety, environmental, or other regu-
16 latory requirements, as documented by govern-
17 ment inspections or citations.
18 (H) SIGNIFICANT CYBERSECURITY
19 BREACHES OR FAILURES.—Failure to meet cy-
20 bersecurity requirements or significant breaches
21 caused by contractor negligence, as verified by
22 government assessments or incident reports.
23 (e) ADDITIONAL PERFORMANCE INDICATORS.—The
24 Secretary of Defense may establish additional negative
25 performance indicators, provided they are—
†S 2296 ES

470
1 (1) based on verifiable data or objective evalua-
2 tions; and
3 (2) published in the Defense Federal Acquisi-
4 tion Regulation Supplement (DFARS) with clear
5 criteria for identification and reporting.
6 (f) IMPLEMENTATION.—
7 (1) TEMPLATES.— Not later than 180 days
8 after the date of the enactment of this Act, the Sec-
9 retary of Defense shall issue revised regulations
10 under revise subpart 242.15 of the DFARS to in-
11 clude standardized templates for reporting negative
12 performance events and calculating composite scores.
13 (2) TRAINING AND GUIDANCE.—
14 (A) TRAINING.—The Secretary of Defense
15 shall develop and provide training for con-
16 tracting officers on—
17 (i) identifying, verifying, and report-
18 ing negative performance events; and
19 (ii) entering data for transaction
20 counts and contract dollar values to sup-
21 port the scoring mechanism.
22 (B) GUIDANCE.—Guidance shall emphasize
23 the use of objective evidence and the exclusion
24 of subjective judgments, including—
†S 2296 ES

471
1 (i) standardized templates for report-
2 ing negative performance events;
3 (ii) guidelines for weighting negative
4 performance scores in source selection; and
5 (iii) procedures for quality assurance
6 reviews and contractor dispute resolution.
7 (3) SYSTEM MODIFICATIONS.—Not later than
8 one year after the date of the enactment of this Act,
9 the Secretary of Defense shall modify the CPARS
10 system to—
11 (A) support the categorization of negative
12 performance events;
13 (B) eliminate fields for subjective ratings;
14 (C) automatically calculate composite
15 scores based on reported data;
16 (D) include a mechanism for contractors to
17 review and respond to reported events and
18 scores; and
19 (E) integrate with the Federal Awardee
20 Performance and Integrity Information System
21 (FAPIIS) for seamless data sharing.
22 (4) TRANSITION PERIOD.—
23 (A) EXISTING CPARS EVALUATIONS.—For
24 contracts awarded prior to the effective date of
25 the revised regulations, contracting officers may
†S 2296 ES

472
1 complete existing CPARS evaluations under the
2 prior system until the contract is closed or ter-
3 minated.
4 (B) NEW EVALUATIONS.—New evaluations
5 for contracts awarded after the date of the re-
6 vised implementing regulations shall comply
7 with this section.
8 (g) REPORTING AND OVERSIGHT.—
9 (1) REPORT.—Not later than one year after the
10 date of the enactment of this Act, the Secretary of
11 Defense shall submit a report to the Committees on
12 Armed Services of the Senate and the House of Rep-
13 resentatives on the implementation of the revised
14 Contractor Performance Assessment Reporting Sys-
15 tem required by this section.
16 (2) GOVERNMENT ACCOUNTABILITY OFFICE RE-
17 VIEW.—Not later than 3 years after the date of the
18 enactment of this Act, the Comptroller General of
19 the United States shall conduct a review of the re-
20 vised contractor performance information system to
21 assess—
22 (A) its effectiveness in achieving the pur-
23 poses outlined in subsection (a);
24 (B) the accuracy and fairness of the scor-
25 ing mechanism; and
†S 2296 ES

473
1 (C) the system’s impact on competition
2 and nontraditional defense contractor participa-
3 tion.
4 (h) DEFINITIONS.—In this section:
5 (1) NEGATIVE PERFORMANCE EVENT.—The
6 term ‘‘negative performance event’’ means a
7 verifiable instance of contractor failure or poor per-
8 formance, as described in subsection (d).
9 (2) NONTRADITIONAL DEFENSE CON-
10 TRACTOR.—The term ‘‘nontraditional defense con-
11 tractor’’ has the meaning given the term in section
12 3014 of title 10, United States Code.
13 (3) VERIFIABLE DATA.—The term ‘‘verifiable
14 data’’ means objective evidence documented in con-
15 tract records, inspection reports, audits, correspond-
16 ence, or other government records.

SEC. 873. PROCESSES FOR INCENTIVIZING CONTRACTOR
14
EXPANSION OF SOURCES OF SUPPLY.
15 (a) IN GENERAL.—For critical readiness parts and
16 systems, the Secretary of Defense shall enhance military
17 readiness by incentivizing the design activity to expand
18 sources of supply for critical readiness parts and systems,
19 through expedited qualification processes, advanced manu-
20 facturing techniques, and risk-informed certification.
21 (b) CONTRACTUAL REQUIREMENTS FOR SUPPLIER
22 DIVERSIFICATION.—
23 (1) REQUIREMENT.—The Secretary of Defense
24 shall ensure that all new or modified contracts with
25 a prime contractor shall include contracting incen-
†S 2296 ES

505
1 tives to expand sources of supply with each design
2 activity at any tier of the supply chain for systems
3 with critical readiness parts and systems.
4 (2) MANDATORY AMSC RECLASSIFICATION.—
5 For any identified critical readiness part or system,
6 the design activity shall, not later than 60 days after
7 notification by the Department of Defense, conduct
8 a review and propose reclassification of the Acquisi-
9 tion Method Suffix Code (AMSC) to reduce sole-
10 source dependency for any part or system with a
11 lead time greater than, unless the Secretary of De-
12 fense grants a waiver based on national security or
13 operational necessity.
14 (3) IMPLEMENTATION.—The design activity
15 shall submit supplier diversification plans not later
16 than 90 days after contract award, detailing pro-
17 posed supplier qualifications and projected benefits.
18 (4) ENFORCEMENT.—Noncompliance shall re-
19 sult in corrective action requests, reduced contractor
20 performance ratings, or contract termination.
21 (c) EXPEDITED QUALIFICATION.—
22 (1) IN GENERAL.—The Secretary of Defense
23 shall expedite qualification procedures for critical
24 readiness parts and systems in collaboration with
†S 2296 ES

506
1 the design activity at any tier of the contract supply
2 chain.
3 (2) DELEGATION.—The Secretary of Defense
4 may delegate authority to designated engineering
5 representatives (DERs) of the Federal Aviation Ad-
6 ministration or equivalent third-party certified engi-
7 neers for specific tasks for parts approved through
8 the Federal Aviation Administration’s Parts Manu-
9 facturer Approval (PMA) processes.
10 (d) ENHANCED USE OF SIMULATION FOR CERTIFI-
11 CATION.—
12 (1) IN GENERAL.—The Secretary of Defense
13 shall mandate the use of simulation-based
14 verification for certifying critical readiness parts and
15 systems, reducing reliance on physical testing for
16 non-safety critical items, or non-mission critical
17 items, as those terms are defined in section 865 of
18 the Servicemember Quality of Life Improvement and

†S 2296 ES

510
1 (B) the product or component has already
2 entered the customs territory of the United

†S 2296 ES

SEC. 879. PHASE-OUT OF COMPUTER AND PRINTER ACQUI-
10
SITIONS INVOLVING ENTITIES OWNED OR
11
CONTROLLED BY CHINA.
12 (a) IN GENERAL.—The Secretary of Defense may not
13 directly or indirectly acquire any computer or printer if
14 the manufacturer is a covered Chinese entity.
15 (b) PROHIBITION ON INDIRECT SALES.—The Sec-
16 retary of Defense shall ensure that the prohibition under
17 subsection (a) also applies to indirect sales through ex-
18 empt subsidiaries. No covered entity may use an exempt
19 subsidiary to circumvent the prohibition on the acquisition
20 of computers, unified communication devices, or printers.
21 (c) APPLICABILITY.—This section shall apply only
22 with respect to contracts or other agreements entered into,
23 renewed, or extended in accordance with the percentage
24 thresholds specified in subsection (d), for end user com-
25 puting devices such as laptops, desktops, and other phys-
26 ical computing equipment. This section shall not apply to
†S 2296 ES

515
1 contracts or other agreements for cloud-based services, in-
2 cluding virtual desktops, or cellular telephones.
3 (d) REQUIRED PERCENTAGES.—The percentage
4 thresholds referred to in subsection (c) are, for both com-
5 puters and printers, as follows:
6 (1) Not less than 10 percent of the Depart-
7 ment’s total procurement beginning in fiscal year
8 2026.
9 (2) Not less than 25 percent of the Depart-
10 ment’s total procurement beginning in fiscal year
11 2027.
12 (3) Not less than 50 percent of the Depart-
13 ment’s total procurement beginning in fiscal year
14 2028.
15 (4) 100 percent of the Department’s total pro-
16 curement beginning in fiscal year 2029.
17 (e) WAIVER.—The Secretary of Defense may allow
18 acquisition of items not for operational use, to conduct
19 testing, evaluation, exfiltration, and reverse engineering
20 missions on adversarial products and capabilities.
21 (f) DEFINITIONS.—In this section:
22 (1) COMPUTER.—The term ‘‘computer’’—
23 (A) means an electronic, magnetic, optical,
24 electrochemical, or other high speed data proc-
25 essing device performing logical, arithmetic, or
†S 2296 ES

516
1 storage functions, and includes any data stor-
2 age facility or communications facility directly
3 related to or operating in conjunction with such
4 device; and
5 (B) does not include an automated type-
6 writer or typesetter, a portable handheld calcu-
7 lator, or other similar device.
8 (2) COUNTRY OF CONCERN.—The term ‘‘coun-
9 try of concern’’ means the Government of the Peo-
10 ple’s Republic of China.
11 (3) COVERED CHINESE ENTITY.—The term
12 ‘‘covered Chinese entity’’ means an entity that the
13 Secretary of Defense, in consultation with the Direc-
14 tor of the National Intelligence or the Director of
15 the Federal Bureau of Investigation, determines to
16 be—
17 (A) an entity whose ultimate parent com-
18 pany is domiciled in the People’s Republic of
19 China and therefore required to comply with
20 China’s 2015 National Security Law, China’s
21 2017 National Intelligence Law, and other Chi-

23 company to cooperate with Chinese national de-
24 fense and national intelligence agencies; or
†S 2296 ES

517
1 (B) an entity or parent company of any
2 entity in which a country of concern has an

4 (4) MANUFACTURER.—The term ‘‘manufac-

†S 2296 ES

15 (a) does not apply to the operation or procurement of ad-

21 the prohibition under subsection (a) on a case-by-case
22 basis by certifying in writing to the congressional defense
23 committees that the operation or procurement of additive
24 manufacturing systems or machines is required in the na-
25 tional interest of the United States.
†S 2296 ES

520
1 (d) DEFINITIONS.—In this section:
2 (1) ADDITIVE MANUFACTURING MACHINE.—
3 The term ‘‘additive manufacturing machine’’ means
4 a system of integrated hardware and software used
5 to realize an additive manufacturing process, includ-
6 ing the deposition of material and the associated
7 post-processing steps as applicable.
8 (2) ADDITIVE MANUFACTURING PROCESS.—The
9 term ‘‘additive manufacturing process’’ means a
10 process of joining materials to make parts from 3D
11 model data, usually layer upon layer, as opposed to
12 subtractive manufacturing methodologies.

14 PANY.—The term ‘‘covered additive manufacturing

24 tained under section 1260H of the William
25 M. (Mac) Thornberry National Defense
†S 2296 ES

1 Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2021
2 (Public Law 116–283; 10 U.S.C. 113
3 note).
4 (B) Any entity that produces or provides
5 additive manufacturing machines and—
6 (i) is domiciled in a covered foreign
7 country; or
8 (ii) is subject to unmitigated foreign
9 ownership, control, or influence by a cov-
10 ered foreign country, as determined by the
11 Secretary of Defense in accordance with
12 the National Industrial Security Program
13 or any successor to such program.

16 machine’’ means additive manufacturing machines

20 ‘‘covered foreign country’’ means the People’s Re-

SEC. 882. SKYFOUNDRY PROGRAM.
17 (a) ESTABLISHMENT.—
18 (1) PROGRAM REQUIRED.—The Secretary of
19 Defense shall establish a program to encourage the
20 rapid development, testing, and scalable manufac-
21 turing of small unmanned aircraft systems and com-
22 ponents, with potential expansion to associated
23 energetics and other autonomous systems as deter-
24 mined by the Secretary, leveraging existing com-
†S 2296 ES

539
1 petencies within the commercial sector and the De-
2 partment of Defense organic industrial base.
3 (2) DESIGNATION.—The program established
4 pursuant to paragraph (1) shall be known as the
5 ‘‘SkyFoundry Program’’ (in this section the ‘‘Pro-
6 gram’’).
7 (3) ADMINISTRATION.—The Secretary of De-
8 fense shall—
9 (A) administer the Program through the
10 Secretary of the Army; and
11 (B) establish the Program as part of the
12 Defense Industrial Resilience Consortium.
13 (b) ALTERNATIVE ACQUISITION MECHANISM.—In
14 carrying out the Program, the Secretary of Defense shall
15 prioritize alternative acquisition mechanisms to accelerate
16 development and production, including—
17 (1) other transaction authority under section
18 4022 of title 10, United States Code;
19 (2) middle tier of acquisition pathway for rapid
20 prototyping and rapid fielding as authorized by sec-
21 tion 3602 of such title; and
22 (3) software acquisition pathway as authorized
23 by section 3603 of such title.
24 (c) COMPONENTS.—The Program shall have two
25 components as follows:
†S 2296 ES

540
1 (1) INNOVATION FACILITY.—An innovation fa-
2 cility for the development of small unmanned air-
3 craft systems. The facility may be operated by
4 United States Special Operations Command in col-
5 laboration with United States Army Materiel Com-
6 mand, serving as the research, development, and
7 testing hub, integrating lessons learned from global
8 conflicts to rapidly evolve United States small un-
9 manned aircraft systems designs in partnership with
10 contractor entities.
11 (2) PRODUCTION FACILITY.—The Commander
12 of United States Army Materiel Command shall
13 identify a production facility with the competencies
14 for producing various forms of small unmanned air-
15 craft systems and components of small unmanned
16 aircraft systems. The facility shall be operated by
17 United States Army Materiel Command in collabora-
18 tion with industry partners to enable scalable pro-
19 duction as needed.
20 (d) PUBLIC-PRIVATE PARTNERSHIP MODEL.—To
21 support the Program, the Secretary may leverage authori-
22 ties, including section 2474 of title 10, United States
23 Code, to foster voluntary public-private partnerships. Such
24 partnerships may include—
†S 2296 ES

541
1 (1) agreements with private industry, academic
2 institutions, and nonprofit organizations in support
3 of the Program; and
4 (2) innovative arrangements that allow industry
5 partners to utilize government facilities and equip-
6 ment, such as co-located hybrid teams of military,
7 civilian, and contractor personnel, to promote tech-
8 nology transfer, workforce development, and surge
9 capacity.
10 (e) FACILITIES AND INFRASTRUCTURE.—
11 (1) IN GENERAL.—In carrying out the Pro-
12 gram, the Secretary shall prioritize utilizing or modi-
13 fying existing Army Depot facilities and select at
14 least two separate sites for the Program, one to
15 house the innovation facility required by paragraph
16 (1) of subsection (c) and one to house the produc-
17 tion facility required by paragraph (2) of such sub-
18 section.
19 (2) AUTHORITY TO RENOVATE, EXPAND, AND
20 CONSTRUCT.—The Secretary may renovate, expand,
21 or construct facilities for the Program using avail-
22 able funds, notwithstanding chapter 169 of title 10,
23 United States Code.
24 (3) SELECTION OF SITES.—When selecting sites
25 for the Program, the Secretary shall consider that
†S 2296 ES

542
1 the production facility required by subsection (c)(2)
2 shall be housed at an existing Army Depot.
3 (f) INTELLECTUAL PROPERTY RIGHTS.—The Sec-
4 retary shall ensure that any public-private partnership es-
5 tablished under this section provides the United States de-
6 livery of technical data and rights in technical data for
7 any systems or technologies developed under the Program
8 using Federal Government funding in accordance with sec-
9 tions 3771 through 3775 of title 10, United States Code.
10 (g) DEFENSE PRODUCTION ACT DESIGNATION.—
11 The President (or the Secretary of Defense under dele-
12 gated authority) may use authorities under title III of the
13 Defense Production Act of 1950 (50 U.S.C. 4531 et seq.)
14 to support domestic industrial base capacity for small un-
15 manned aircraft systems and associated energetics and au-
16 tonomous systems.

SEC. 913. STUDY ON FEASIBILITY AND ADVISABILITY OF ES-
11
TABLISHING A JOINT CAPABILITIES AND
12
PROGRAMMING BOARD.
13 (a) STUDY REQUIRED.—The Secretary of Defense
14 shall conduct a study on the feasibility and advisability
15 of establishing a Joint Capabilities and Programming
16 Board (in this section referred to as the ‘‘Board’’) within
17 the Department of Defense to serve as a consolidated
18 forum for addressing joint military capabilities and pro-
19 gram budgeting for investments.
20 (b) ELEMENTS OF STUDY.—The study required by
21 subsection (a) shall assess and provide recommendations
22 on the following elements for the proposed Board:
23 (1) The potential for the Board to act as the
24 primary joint forum for—
†S 2296 ES

569
1 (A) reviewing and recommending actions
2 on joint military capabilities spanning multiple
3 components of the Department of Defense to
4 address priority capability needs; and
5 (B) evaluating and recommending actions
6 on investment portfolio evaluation and budg-
7 eting matters to prioritize joint military capa-
8 bilities and optimize lethality based on available
9 resources.
10 (2) The feasibility of the Board being co-
11 chaired by the Director of Cost Assessment and Pro-
12 gram Evaluation and the Chairman of the Joint Re-
13 quirements Oversight Council, including the roles,
14 authorities, and responsibilities of the co-chair-
15 persons.
16 (3) The advisability of a Board composition
17 that includes—
18 (A) core membership consisting of—
19 (i) the co-chairpersons;
20 (ii) representatives from the Joint Re-
21 quirements Oversight Council;
22 (iii) representatives from the Office of
23 the Director of Cost Assessment and Pro-
24 gram Evaluation;
†S 2296 ES

570
1 (iv) representatives from the Armed
2 Forces and combatant commands to reflect
3 military user perspectives; and
4 (v) representatives of portfolio acquisi-
5 tion executives or equivalent managers to
6 reflect program execution perspectives;
7 (B) a flexible structure permitting the es-
8 tablishment of ad hoc or standing committees
9 to address specific areas or issues, drawing
10 from the core membership;
11 (C) separate staff directly accountable to
12 each co-chairperson to assist in identifying, re-
13 viewing, coordinating, and analyzing matters
14 brought before the Board; and
15 (D) mission engineering and integration
16 analysis cells that evaluate the effectiveness of
17 current and proposed value chains of the De-
18 partment of Defense and inform the assessment
19 of alternative courses of action for capability
20 and resource investments.
21 (4) The potential structure for decision-making
22 by the Board, including—
23 (A) maintaining autonomy for the Armed
24 Forces and portfolio acquisition executives to
25 make decisions and execute programs without
†S 2296 ES

571
1 requiring approval by or the submission of doc-
2 umentation to the Board;
3 (B) issuing recommendations by majority
4 vote of members of the Board, to be forwarded
5 to the Deputy Secretary of Defense unless
6 unanimously rejected by the co-chairpersons;
7 and
8 (C) allowing the members or representa-
9 tives of the Board to submit dissenting opinions
10 alongside recommendations for consideration by
11 the Deputy Secretary of Defense or the Sec-
12 retary of Defense.
13 (5) The feasibility of operational procedures, in-
14 cluding—
15 (A) issue identification processes
16 prioritizing issues—
17 (i) nominated by members of the
18 Board, the Armed Forces, the combatant
19 commands, or portfolio acquisition execu-
20 tives; and
21 (ii) addressing capability gaps, re-
22 source constraints, or programmatic chal-
23 lenges requiring joint or departmental ac-
24 tion; and
†S 2296 ES

572
1 (B) flexible quorum and voting procedures
2 to ensure efficient decision-making and requir-
3 ing participation from representatives of mili-
4 tary users and program acquisition executives
5 directly impacted by any recommendation.
6 (6) The provision of sufficient staff, directly ac-
7 countable to the co-chairpersons, to support the
8 Board’s operations and analysis of issues.
9 (7) The impact of the proposed Board on exist-
10 ing entities of the Department of Defense, including
11 the Joint Requirements Oversight Council and the
12 Office of the Director of Cost Assessment and Pro-
13 gram Evaluation, including potential overlaps,
14 redundancies, or synergies between the missions and
15 responsibilities of those entities and the Board.
16 (8) The anticipated benefits of enhanced joint
17 capability prioritization and resource allocation, in-
18 cluding the ability to consolidate or remove existing
19 processes and decision forums.
20 (9) Potential barriers to establishing the Board,
21 including resource requirements and alignment with
22 existing acquisition and budgeting processes.
23 (c) REPORT REQUIRED.—
24 (1) IN GENERAL.—Not later than July 1, 2026,
25 the Secretary of Defense shall submit to the con-
†S 2296 ES

573
1 gressional defense committees a report on the results
2 of the study required by subsection (a).
3 (2) ELEMENTS.—The report required by para-
4 graph (1) shall include—
5 (A) a comprehensive analysis of the feasi-
6 bility and advisability of establishing the Board,
7 addressing each element specified in subsection
8 (b);
9 (B) if establishing the Board is deemed
10 feasible and advisable—
11 (i) specific recommendations for the
12 organizational structure, governance, vot-
13 ing mechanisms, quorum requirements,
14 and operational procedures of the Board;
15 and
16 (ii) an estimation of the costs, re-
17 source requirements, and timeline for es-
18 tablishing and operating the Board; and
19 (C) any additional findings or rec-
20 ommendations to improve joint capability devel-
21 opment, program budgeting, and resource allo-
22 cation within the Department of Defense.

24 tion shall be construed to prevent the establishment of a

1 ness with policies, operations, and programs

TIONARY COMBAT COMMAND PACIFIC.
3 (a) IN GENERAL.—During the one-year period begin-
4 ning on the date of the enactment of this Act, the Sec-
5 retary of the Navy may not take any action to disestablish
6 the Navy Expeditionary Combat Command Pacific located
7 at Joint Base Pearl Harbor-Hickam.
8 (b) BRIEFING REQUIRED.—Not later than 180 days
9 after the date of the enactment of this Act, the Secretary
10 (or a designee of the Secretary) shall brief the Committees
11 on Armed Services of the Senate and the House of Rep-
12 resentatives on—
13 (1) the status of the decision of the Secretary
14 with respect to the disestablishment of the Navy Ex-
15 peditionary Combat Command Pacific; and
16 (2) the strategic rationale, cost, and benefits of
17 such disestablishment.

20 ery organizations;

24 data management platforms;
25 (D) effectiveness and efficiency of current
26 approaches;
†S 2296 ES

588

7 gineering within the Office of the Secretary of De-
8 fense, including—
9 (A) establishment of a new defense agency

11 (B) integration into an existing defense
12 agency or Department of Defense field activity;
13 (C) consolidation of digital development

SEC. 922. ESTABLISHMENT OF ADVANCED NUCLEAR TRAN-
18
SITION WORKING GROUP.
19 (a) IN GENERAL.—Not later than 180 days after the
20 date of the enactment of this Act, the Secretary of Defense
21 shall establish an Advanced Nuclear Transition Working
22 Group (referred to in this section as the ‘‘working
23 group’’).
24 (b) MEMBERSHIP.—The Working Group shall be
25 composed of the following members:
†S 2296 ES

592
1 (1) The Assistant Secretary of Defense for En-
2 ergy, Installations, and Environment.
3 (2) The Assistant Secretary of the Army for In-
4 stallations, Energy, and Environment.
5 (3) The Assistant Secretary of the Navy for
6 Energy, Installations, and Environment.
7 (4) The Assistant Secretary of the Air Force
8 for Energy, Installations, and Environment.
9 (5) The Joint Staff Director for Logistics, J4.
10 (6) The Principal Director for Energy Resil-
11 ience of the Office of the Under Secretary of De-
12 fense for Research and Engineering.
13 (7) The Director of the Strategic Capabilities
14 Office.
15 (8) The Director of the Defense Innovation
16 Unit.
17 (9) The heads of such other components of the
18 Department of Defense, as determined by the Chair.
19 (c) CHAIR.—The Assistant Secretary of Defense for
20 Nuclear Deterrence, Chemical, and Biological Defense
21 Policy and Programs, or a designee, shall serve as the
22 Chair of the Working Group.
23 (d) DUTIES.—The duties of the Working Group shall
24 include the following:
†S 2296 ES

593
1 (1) To develop and execute a strategy to accel-
2 erate the procurement and fielding of commercial
3 advanced nuclear capabilities, in compliance with
4 laws, regulations, and agreements, and consistent
5 with best practices.
6 (2) To identify and elevate the critical energy
7 requirements of the combatant commands, United
8 States military installations, and the infrastructure
9 and mission capabilities needs of the combatant
10 commands and military installations that may be ad-
11 dressed with advanced nuclear reactors.
12 (3) To connect the combatant commands and
13 military installations with ongoing and planned ef-
14 forts.
15 (4) To create an accelerated pathway to lever-
16 age advanced nuclear technologies to address oper-
17 ational gaps.
18 (5) To provide a forum for members of the
19 Working Group to coordinate advanced nuclear dem-
20 onstration and transition efforts, including by in-
21 creasing opportunities and venues for government
22 and commercial research and development, testing
23 and evaluation, and procurement activities.
24 (6) To advocate for appropriate levels of
25 resourcing within planning, programming, budg-
†S 2296 ES

594
1 eting, and execution processes to advance the devel-
2 opment and use of nuclear energy technologies
3 across the Department of Defense.
4 (7) To coordinate interagency activities and de-
5 velop best practices on workforce development, regu-
6 latory pathways, licensing frameworks, access to fuel
7 sources, safety and security standards, and decom-
8 missioning that currently hinder more rapid fielding
9 of advanced nuclear reactors.
10 (8) To establish venues through which to en-
11 gage commercial companies developing advanced re-
12 actors so as to review the technology readiness,
13 timeline, and availability of reactor capabilities for
14 defense applications.
15 (9) To inform and complete the briefings and
16 reports required in subsection (f).
17 (e) MEETINGS.—The Working Group shall meet at
18 the call of the Chair and not less than once per quarter.
19 (f) REPORT.—
20 (1) IN GENERAL.—Not later than September
21 30, 2026, and annually thereafter until 2029, the
22 Chair shall submit to the appropriate congressional
23 committees a report describing the status of ad-
24 vanced nuclear projects, associated funding and re-
25 quirements, planned program transitions, actions,
†S 2296 ES

595
1 and milestones of the Working Group, and other
2 matters as determined by the Secretary of Defense
3 and the Working Group during the preceding year.
4 (2) CONTENTS.—Each report required by para-
5 graph (1) shall include the following:
6 (A) A summary on the adequacy of exist-
7 ing energy storage and distribution systems to
8 meet mission requirements in a contested or
9 austere operating environment.
10 (B) An identification of the critical energy
11 requirements of the combatant commands,
12 United States military installations, and the in-
13 frastructure and weapons capabilities needs of
14 the combatant commands and military installa-
15 tions that may be addressed with the use of
16 microreactors or small modular reactors, includ-
17 ing through expeditionary, transportable, sta-
18 tionary, space-based, or floating power plants.
19 (C) A list of prioritized potential use cases,
20 including—
21 (i) base electric power;
22 (ii) power for operational systems in
23 austere environments;
24 (iii) desalination or other water pro-
25 duction systems;
†S 2296 ES

596
1 (iv) synthetic fuel production;
2 (v) directed energy weapons;
3 (vi) artificial intelligence at the edge;
4 (vii) defense support of civil authori-
5 ties;
6 (viii) humanitarian response; and
7 (ix) 3D/additive manufacturing.
8 (D) Recommendations for at least 3 pilot
9 projects.
10 (3) APPROPRIATE CONGRESSIONAL COMMIT-
11 TEES.—The term ‘‘appropriate congressional com-
12 mittees’’ means—
13 (A) the Committee on Armed Services of
14 the Senate; and
15 (B) the Committee on Armed Services of
16 the House of Representatives.
17 (g) TERMINATION.—The Working Group shall termi-
18 nate on September 30, 2029.
19 (h) PILOT PROGRAM.—The Secretary of Defense
20 shall establish a pilot program for deploying microreactors
21 at United States military installations to strengthen en-
22 ergy resilience and reduce reliance on vulnerable civilian
23 grids.

SEC. 1001. GENERAL TRANSFER AUTHORITY.
4 (a) AUTHORITY TO TRANSFER AUTHORIZATIONS.—
5 (1) AUTHORITY.—Upon determination by the
6 Secretary of Defense that such action is necessary in
7 the national interest, the Secretary may transfer
8 amounts of authorizations made available to the De-
9 partment of Defense in this division for fiscal year
10 2026 between any such authorizations for that fiscal
11 year (or any subdivisions thereof). Amounts of au-
12 thorizations so transferred shall be merged with and
13 be available for the same purposes as the authoriza-
14 tion to which transferred.
15 (2) LIMITATION.—Except as provided in para-
16 graph (3), the total amount of authorizations that
17 the Secretary may transfer under the authority of
18 this section may not exceed $6,000,000,000.
19 (3) EXCEPTION FOR TRANSFERS BETWEEN
20 MILITARY PERSONNEL AUTHORIZATIONS.—A trans-
21 fer of funds between military personnel authoriza-
22 tions under title IV shall not be counted toward the
23 dollar limitation in paragraph (2).
24 (b) LIMITATIONS.—The authority provided by sub-
25 section (a) to transfer authorizations—
†S 2296 ES

598
1 (1) may only be used to provide authority for
2 items that have a higher priority than the items
3 from which authority is transferred; and
4 (2) may not be used to provide authority for an
5 item that has been denied authorization by Con-
6 gress.
7 (c) EFFECT ON AUTHORIZATION AMOUNTS.—A
8 transfer made from one account to another under the au-
9 thority of this section shall be deemed to increase the
10 amount authorized for the account to which the amount
11 is transferred by an amount equal to the amount trans-
12 ferred.
13 (d) NOTICE TO CONGRESS.—The Secretary shall
14 promptly notify Congress of each transfer made under
15 subsection (a).
16

SEC. 1013. EXEMPTION OF UNMANNED SURFACE VESSELS
2
AND UNMANNED UNDERWATER VEHICLES

QUIREMENTS.

6 ITY REQUIREMENTS.—Unmanned surface vessels and un-
7 manned underwater vehicles acquired or developed by the
8 Department of the Navy are exempt from any requirement
9 for oversight by a senior technical authority established
10 under section 8669b of title 10, United States Code, ex-
11 cept the requirements, specifications, and approvals de-
12 scribed in subsection (c).
13 (b) LIMITATION RELATING TO OFFICE OF THE
14 CHIEF ENGINEER.—Subject to subsection (c), the Chief
15 Engineer of the Naval Sea Systems Command may not
16 establish any requirement, specification, or approval for
17 an unmanned surface vessel or an unmanned underwater
18 vehicle unless such action is approved in advance by the
19 program manager responsible for the respective unmanned
20 system.
21 (c) EXCEPTIONS.—As the Secretary of the Navy con-
22 siders appropriate, unmanned surface vessels and un-
23 manned underwater vehicles may be subject to require-
24 ments, specifications, and approvals established by tech-
25 nical domain managers or technical warrant holders with
26 responsibility for cybersecurity, ordnance and explosives,
†S 2296 ES

604
1 or warfare systems, without advanced approval described
2 in subsection (b).
3 (d) DEFINITIONS.—In this section:
4 (1) UNMANNED SURFACE VESSEL.—The term
5 ‘‘unmanned surface vessel’’ means a vessel designed
6 to operate on the surface of the water without an
7 onboard human crew.
8 (2) UNMANNED UNDERWATER VEHICLE.—The
9 term ‘‘unmanned underwater vehicle’’ means a vehi-
10 cle designed to operate below the surface of the
11 water without an onboard human crew.

SEC. 1018. PILOT PROGRAM ON USE OF AUTOMATED SHIP-
22
BUILDING TECHNOLOGIES AND CAPABILI-
23
TIES.
24 (a) IN GENERAL.—Not later than 90 days after the
25 date of the enactment of this Act, the Secretary of the
26 Navy shall establish a pilot program on the use of auto-
†S 2296 ES

611
1 mated assembly technologies and capabilities in naval
2 shipbuilding to reduce overall construction times and al-
3 leviate workforce constraints (in this section referred to
4 as the ‘‘pilot program’’).
5 (b) ELEMENTS OF PILOT PROGRAM.—In carrying
6 out the pilot program, the Secretary of the Navy shall—
7 (1) identify and select available novel auto-
8 mated hull assembly technologies for incorporation
9 and demonstration;
10 (2) designate at least one surface ship or sub-
11 marine program to demonstrate the automated tech-
12 nologies identified under paragraph (1);
13 (3) carry out such demonstrations;
14 (4) evaluate the demonstrated automated tech-
15 nologies—
16 (A) across a range of functions, including
17 plate preparation, welding, and block assembly;
18 and
19 (B) for compatibility and ease of adoption
20 into the existing shipbuilding value chain; and
21 (5) assess the feasibility and effectiveness of
22 automated approaches in improving subassembly
23 construction times, overall ship construction sched-
24 ules, and workforce efficiency and safety.
25 (c) REPORTS.—
†S 2296 ES

612
1 (1) IN GENERAL.—Not later than September
2 30, 2026, and annually thereafter until the pilot
3 program terminates, the Secretary of the Navy shall
4 submit to the Committee on Armed Services of the
5 Senate and the Committee on Armed Services of the
6 House of Representatives a report on the implemen-
7 tation and results of the pilot program.
8 (2) ELEMENTS OF REPORTS.—Each report re-
9 quired by paragraph (1) shall include the following:
10 (A) An identification of the time required
11 to adapt specific technologies and processes.
12 (B) A description of the impact of the pilot
13 program on workforce and construction sched-
14 ules.
15 (d) TERMINATION.—The pilot program shall termi-
16 nate on the date that is three years after the date of the
17 enactment of this Act.

SEC. 1032. PROHIBITION ON DESTRUCTION OR SCRAPPING
11
OF WORLD WAR II–ERA AIRCRAFT.
12 (a) PROHIBITION.—The Secretary of Defense may
13 not destroy, dismantle, scrap, cannibalize, or otherwise
14 render permanently inoperable any aircraft that—
15 (1) was manufactured prior to December 31,
16 1945; and
17 (2) is in the custody or administrative control
18 of the Department of the Air Force as of the date
19 of the enactment of this Act.
20 (b) AUTHORIZED DISPOSITIONS.—Aircraft described
21 in subsection (a) may only be—
22 (1) retained in the inventory of the Department
23 of the Air Force;
†S 2296 ES

618
1 (2) transferred to the National Museum of the
2 United States Air Force or other official Depart-
3 ment of Defense museums;
4 (3) transferred to qualified Federal agencies,
5 nonprofit institutions, or museums with dem-
6 onstrated indoor preservation and public display ca-
7 pabilities; or
8 (4) de-accessioned under a plan approved by
9 the Secretary of Defense that supports long-term
10 preservation of such aircraft, and consistent with
11 guidelines established in the committee report ac-
12 companying this Act.
13 (c) WAIVER AUTHORITY.—The Secretary of Defense
14 may waive the restriction under subsection (a) on a case-
15 by-case basis only if—
16 (1) the aircraft is determined by qualified per-
17 sonnel to be beyond practical restoration or preser-
18 vation;
19 (2) no eligible institution expresses interest in
20 accepting the aircraft within 12 months following
21 public notice of its availability; and
22 (3) written notification and justification of the
23 waiver is submitted to the congressional defense
24 committees not less than 30 days prior to execution
25 of any disposal action.

6

PROPERTY.

†S 2296 ES

631
1 tion and communications technology and

7 (iii) an unacceptable risk to the na-
8 tional security of the United States or the
9 security and safety of United States per-
10 sons.
11 (2) INCORPORATION OF EXISTING FEDERAL
12 RULES.—In establishing the list required under
13 paragraph (1), the Secretary shall incorporate exist-
14 ing Federal rules for identifying prohibited con-
15 nected vehicles.

24 Any review under subparagraph (A) that makes

†S 2296 ES

1 graph (1) shall include an explanation of why

22 leading collaboration practices referenced in GAO–
23 24-106038, to develop and implement strategies to
24 prevent child trafficking and support child traf-
25 ficking survivors; and

1 (2) establishing achievable performance goals

1 writing of a compromise or failure of any Department of

8 (b) consistent with the national security of the United

SEC. 1059. UNIVERSITY-BASED SECURE INNOVATION INCU-
21
BATOR PROGRAM OF DEPARTMENT OF DE-
22
FENSE.
23 (a) ESTABLISHMENT.—The Secretary of Defense
24 shall establish a program to develop, operate, and main-
†S 2296 ES

655
1 tain incubator programs for secure facilities and networks
2 at select universities across the United States—
3 (1) to accelerate the development and transition
4 of innovative technologies to meet national security
5 needs;
6 (2) to increase the availability of secure facili-
7 ties and networks for classified work at university lo-
8 cations;
9 (3) to foster collaboration between academic re-
10 searchers, private sector entities, and Department of
11 Defense personnel;
12 (4) to expand the pool of security-cleared tech-
13 nical talent available to support defense organiza-
14 tions and personnel in critical defense technology
15 areas; and
16 (5) to create regional innovation hubs that
17 strengthen the national security innovation base.
18 (b) PROGRAM ELEMENTS.—The program established
19 pursuant to subsection (a) shall include the following ele-
20 ments:
21 (1) FACILITY REQUIREMENTS.—Each univer-
22 sity-based secure facility and network shall—
23 (A) meet all physical, technical, and per-
24 sonnel security requirements for handling clas-
†S 2296 ES

656
1 sified information up to the Top Secret or Sen-
2 sitive Compartmented Information level;
3 (B) be designed to accommodate diverse
4 use cases, including secure meetings, classified
5 research, and technology development activities;
6 (C) include collaborative workspaces appro-
7 priate for innovation activities; and
8 (D) leverage modern design principles to
9 maximize utilization and effectiveness.
10 (2) UNIVERSITY SELECTION CRITERIA.—The
11 Secretary shall select universities based on—
12 (A) the absence of a fully functional secure
13 facility and network on the university campus;
14 (B) demonstrated commitment to national
15 security-relevant research and development;
16 (C) existing relationships with the Depart-
17 ment of Defense;
18 (D) technical capabilities relevant to de-
19 fense innovation priorities;
20 (E) geographic distribution to ensure na-

SEC. 1063. COMMISSION ON THE NATIONAL DEFENSE
2
STRATEGY.
3 (a) ESTABLISHMENT.—
4 (1) IN GENERAL.—There is established as of
5 January 5, 2026, an independent commission in the
6 legislative branch to be known as the ‘‘Commission
7 on the National Defense Strategy’’ (in this section
8 referred to as the ‘‘Commission’’).
9 (2) PURPOSE.—The purpose of the Commission
10 is to examine and make recommendations with re-
11 spect to the national defense strategy of the United
12 States.
13 (3) SCOPE AND DUTIES.—In order to provide
14 the fullest understanding of the national defense
15 strategy the Commission shall perform the following
16 duties:
17 (A) NATIONAL DEFENSE STRATEGY RE-
18 VIEW.—The Commission shall review the most
19 recent national defense strategy of the United
20 States including the assumptions, strategic ob-
21 jectives, priority missions, major investments in
22 defense capabilities, force posture and struc-
23 ture, operational concepts, and strategic and
24 military risks associated with the strategy.
†S 2296 ES

664
1 (B) ASSESSMENT.—The Commission shall
2 conduct a comprehensive assessment of the
3 strategic environment, including—
4 (i) United States interests;
5 (ii) the threats to the national secu-
6 rity of the United States, including both
7 traditional and non-traditional threats;
8 (iii) the size and shape of the force;
9 (iv) the readiness of the force;
10 (v) the posture, structure, and capa-
11 bilities of the force;
12 (vi) allocation of resources; and
13 (vii) the strategic and military risks
14 present in the national defense strategy.
15 (4) COMMISSION REPORT AND RECOMMENDA-
16 TIONS.—
17 (A) REPORT.—
18 (i) IN GENERAL.—Not later than one
19 year after the date of establishment of the
20 Commission, the Commission shall trans-
21 mit to the President and Congress a report
22 containing the review and assessment con-
23 ducted under paragraph (3), together with
24 any recommendations of the Commission.
†S 2296 ES

665
1 (ii) CONTENTS.—The report required
2 by clause (i) shall include the following ele-
3 ments:
4 (I) An appraisal of the strategic
5 environment, including an examina-
6 tion of the traditional and non-tradi-
7 tional threats to the United States,
8 and the potential for conflicts arising
9 from such threats and security chal-
10 lenges.
11 (II) An evaluation of the stra-
12 tegic objectives of the Department of
13 Defense for near-peer competition in
14 support of the national security inter-
15 ests of the United States.
16 (III) A review of the military
17 missions for which the Department of
18 Defense should prepare, including
19 missions that support the interagency
20 and a whole-of-government strategy.
21 (IV) An identification of any
22 gaps or redundancies in the roles and
23 missions assigned to the Armed
24 Forces necessary to carry out military
25 missions identified in subclause (III),
†S 2296 ES

666
1 and the roles and capabilities provided
2 by other Federal agencies and by al-
3 lies and international partners.
4 (V) An assessment of how the
5 national defense strategy leverages
6 other elements of national power
7 across the interagency to counter
8 near-peer competitors.
9 (VI) An evaluation of the re-
10 sources necessary to support the
11 strategy, including budget rec-
12 ommendations.
13 (VII) An examination of the ef-
14 forts by the Department of Defense to
15 develop new and innovative oper-

18 near-peer competitors.

21 (aa) the size and shape of
22 the force;
23 (bb) the posture, structure,
24 and capabilities of the force;
†S 2296 ES

667
1 (cc) the readiness of the
2 force;
3 (dd) infrastructure and or-

6 (ee) modifications to per-

SEC. 1065. EXPANSION OF INDIVIDUAL LONGITUDINAL EX-
12
POSURE RECORD.
13 (a) ALL EXPOSURES.—The Secretary of Defense
14 shall expand the Individual Longitudinal Exposure Record
15 (in this section referred to as ‘‘ILER’’) to document all
16 exposures of members of the Armed Forces, including
17 those that occur within the United States, so it can be
18 available for the Secretary of Veterans Affairs when such
19 members transition to civilian life, including the following:
20 (1) All-hazard occupational data.
21 (2) Environmental hazards that were known or
22 found later to which the member was exposed, in-
23 cluding through conducting any monitoring in the
24 area.
25 (b) MEDICAL INFORMATION.—The Secretary of De-
26 fense shall expand the ILER to include the following med-
†S 2296 ES

681
1 ical information of members of the Armed Forces so it
2 can be available for the Secretary of Veterans Affairs
3 when such members transition to civilian life:
4 (1) Medical encounter information relating to
5 exposures (such as diagnosis, treatment, and labora-
6 tory data).
7 (2) Medical concerns that should be addressed
8 regarding possible exposures.
9 (c) AVAILABILITY TO CERTAIN PROFESSIONALS.—
10 The Secretary of Defense shall ensure that the ILER is
11 available, for purposes of improving internal processes, to
12 the following:
13 (1) Health care providers of the Department of
14 Defense and the Department of Veterans Affairs.
15 (2) Epidemiologists and researchers of the De-
16 partment of Defense and the Department of Vet-
17 erans Affairs.
18 (3) Disability evaluation and benefits deter-
19 minations specialists of the Department of Veterans
20 Affairs.
21 (d) INCLUSION IN SERVICE RECORDS.—
22 (1) IN GENERAL.—The Secretary of Defense
23 shall document in the service records of a member
24 of the Armed Forces whether such member served at
†S 2296 ES

682
1 a location where there was a potential of toxic expo-
2 sure.
3 (2) PROTECTION OF CLASSIFIED INFORMA-
4 TION.—In carrying out paragraph (1), the Secretary
5 of Defense shall ensure that service at any location

†S 2296 ES

692
1 (2) QUALIFICATIONS.—
2 (A) IN GENERAL.—The Committee shall be
3 composed of representatives from a variety of
4 space policy, engineering, technical, science,
5 legal, academic, and finance fields who have sig-
6 nificant experience in the commercial space in-
7 dustry, which may include previous Government
8 experience.
9 (B) LIMITATION.—
10 (i) IN GENERAL.—Except as provided
11 in clause (ii), the Secretary may not ap-
12 point as a member of the Committee any

14 ment.

16 appoint as a member of the Committee a

18 section 202(a) of title 18, United States
19 Code) who serves on 1 or more other Fed-

22 member of the Committee—
23 (A) shall be appointed for a term of not
24 more than 4 years; and
†S 2296 ES

693
1 (B) during the 2-year period beginning on
2 the date on which such term ends, may not
3 serve as a member of the Committee.
4 (c) DUTIES.—The duties of the Committee shall be—
5 (1) to advise on the status and recent develop-
6 ments of nongovernmental space activities;
7 (2) to provide to the Secretary and Congress
8 recommendations on the manner in which the
9 United States may facilitate and promote a safe,
10 sustainable, robust, competitive, and innovative com-
11 mercial sector that is investing in, developing, and
12 conducting space activities within the jurisdiction of
13 the Department of Commerce, including through the
14 development and implementation of any regulatory
15 framework applicable to the commercial space indus-
16 try.
17 (3) to identify, and provide recommendations in
18 response to, any challenge faced by the United
19 States commercial sector relating to—
20 (A) the application of international obliga-
21 tions of the United States relevant to commer-
22 cial space sector activities in outer space;
23 (B) export controls that affect the com-
24 mercial space sector;
†S 2296 ES

694
1 (C) harmful interference with commercial
2 space sector activities in outer space; and

8 Moon and other celestial bodies; and
9 (B) adverse changes in the environment of
10 the Earth resulting from the introduction of ex-
11 traterrestrial matter; and
12 (5) to provide information, advice, and rec-
13 ommendations on matters relating to—
14 (A) United States commercial space sector
15 activities in outer space; and
16 (B) other commercial space sector activi-
17 ties, as the Committee considers necessary.

SEC. 1076. FINDING OPPORTUNITIES FOR RESOURCE EX-
7
PLORATION.
8 (a) SENSE OF CONGRESS.—It is the sense of Con-

11 eral processing.

13 (1) ALLIED FOREIGN COUNTRY.—The term ‘‘al-
14 lied foreign country’’ means a member country of

17 under section 517 of the Foreign Assistance Act of
18 1961 (22 U.S.C. 2321k).
19 (2) CRITICAL MINERAL.—The term ‘‘critical
20 mineral’’ has the meaning given the term in section

22 1606(a)).

24 term ‘‘institution of higher education’’ has the
†S 2296 ES

703
1 meaning given the term in section 101 of the Higher

6 (5) RARE EARTH ELEMENT.—The term ‘‘rare
7 earth element’’ means cerium, dysprosium, erbium,
8 europium, gadolinium, holmium, lanthanum, lute-
9 tium, neodymium, praseodymium, promethium, sa-

SEC. 1082. FEASIBILITY STUDY ON REMOVAL OF OIL FROM
7
SUNKEN WORLD WAR II VESSELS IN WATERS
8
NEAR THE FEDERATED STATES OF MICRO-
9
NESIA AND THE REPUBLIC OF PALAU.
10 (a) SENSE OF CONGRESS.—It is the sense of Con-
11 gress that—
12 (1) there is a significant environmental threat
13 posed by World War II-era sunken Japanese war-
14 ships, including three oil tankers, located in the
15 waters near the Federated States of Micronesia and
16 the Republic of Palau;
17 (2) such sunken vessels contain an estimated
18 3,000,000 to 4,000,000 gallons of oil, or approxi-
19 mately the equivalent of 1⁄ of the Exxon Valdez oil
3
20 tanker spill in 1989; and
21 (3) as such sunken vessels continue to deterio-
22 rate, small amounts of oil are already leaking,
23 threatening to cause an ecological disaster that could
24 negatively impact United States military activities,
†S 2296 ES

730
1 the marine ecosystem, and surrounding commu-
2 nities.
3 (b) STUDY.—
4 (1) IN GENERAL.—The Secretary of Defense, in
5 coordination with the Commander of the United
6 States Indo-Pacific Command and the head of any
7 other relevant Federal department or agency, as ap-
8 propriate, shall conduct a comprehensive study on
9 the feasibility and advisability of removing oil from
10 the World War II-era sunken tankers, including an
11 analysis of the cost, logistical requirements, environ-
12 mental risks, and potential methods for removing
13 the oil from the tankers.
14 (2) REPORT.—
15 (A) IN GENERAL.—Not later than March
16 1, 2026, the Secretary shall submit to the ap-
17 propriate committees of Congress a report on
18 the findings of the study conducted under para-
19 graph (1).
20 (B) ELEMENTS.—The report required by
21 subparagraph (A) shall include the following:
22 (i) An assessment of the operational
23 and environmental risks posed by the oil
24 remaining in the sunken tankers and war-
†S 2296 ES

731
1 ships, including current leakage and the
2 potential impacts of a major spill.
3 (ii) An evaluation of the cost,
4 logistical challenges, and technical ap-
5 proaches for safely extracting or containing
6 oil from the shipwrecks.
7 (iii) A review of ongoing and planned
8 efforts by the United States and inter-
9 national partners addressing such matter.
10 (iv) Recommendations on next steps,
11 including resource needs, interagency and
12 international cooperation, and timelines for
13 potential remediation efforts.
14

15
PLY.
16 (a) SHORT TITLE.—This section may be cited as the
17 ‘‘Mapping America’s Pharmaceutical Supply Act’’ or the
18 ‘‘MAPS Act’’.
19 (b) U.S. PHARMACEUTICAL SUPPLY CHAINS MAP-
20 PING.—
21 (1) PHARMACEUTICAL SUPPLY CHAIN MAP-
22 PING.—The Secretary, in coordination with the

24 agencies, shall ensure coordination of efforts of the
25 Department of Health and Human Services, includ-
†S 2296 ES

732
1 ing through public-private partnerships, as appro-
2 priate, to—
3 (A) map, or otherwise visualize, the supply
4 chains, from manufacturing of key starting ma-
5 terials through manufacturing of finished dos-

7 logical products, including the active ingredients
8 of those drugs and biological products, that
9 are—
10 (i) directly related to responding to
11 chemical, biological, radiological, or nuclear

13 tional Response Framework; or
14 (ii) of greatest priority for providing
15 health care and identified as being at high
16 risk of shortage; and
17 (B) use data analytics to identify supply
18 chain vulnerabilities that pose a threat to na-
19 tional security, as determined by the Secretary
20 or the heads of other relevant Federal depart-
21 ments and agencies.
22 (2) REQUIREMENTS.—In carrying out para-
23 graph (1), the Secretary shall—
24 (A) describe the roles and responsibilities
25 of agencies and offices within the Department
†S 2296 ES

733
1 of Health and Human Services related to moni-
2 toring such supply chains and assessing any re-
3 lated vulnerabilities;
4 (B) facilitate the exchange of information
5 between Federal departments, agencies, and of-
6 fices, as appropriate and necessary to enable
7 such agencies and offices to carry out roles and
8 responsibilities described in subparagraph (A)
9 related to drugs and biological products de-
10 scribed in paragraph (1)(A), which may in-
11 clude—
12 (i) the location of establishments reg-
13 istered under subsection (b), (c), or (i) of
14 section 510 of the Federal Food, Drug,
15 and Cosmetic Act (21 U.S.C. 360) involved
16 in the production of drugs and biological
17 products, including the active ingredients
18 of those drugs and biological products, de-
19 scribed in paragraph (1)(A), and to the ex-
20 tent available, the amount of each such
21 drug and biological product, including the
22 active ingredients of those drugs and bio-
23 logical products, produced at each such es-
24 tablishment;
†S 2296 ES

734
1 (ii) to the extent available and as ap-
2 propriate, the location of establishments so
3 registered involved in the production of the
4 key starting materials and excipients need-

SEC. 1097. TRAUMA KIT STANDARDS.
8 Section 521 of title I of the Omnibus Crime Control
9 and Safe Streets Act of 1968 (34 U.S.C. 10202) is amend-
10 ed by adding at the end the following:
11 ‘‘(d) TRAUMA KITS.—
12 ‘‘(1) DEFINITION.—In this subsection, the term
13 ‘trauma kit’ means a first aid response kit, which in-
14 cludes a bleeding control kit that can be used for
15 controlling a life-threatening hemorrhage.
16 ‘‘(2) REQUIREMENT FOR TRAUMA KITS.—
17 ‘‘(A) IN GENERAL.—Notwithstanding any
18 other provision of law, a grantee may only pur-
19 chase a trauma kit using funds made available
20 under this part if the trauma kit meets the per-
21 formance standards established by the Director
22 of the Bureau of Justice Assistance under para-
23 graph (3)(A).
24 ‘‘(B) AUTHORITY TO SEPARATELY AC-
25 QUIRE.—Nothing in subparagraph (A) shall
†S 2296 ES

770
1 prohibit a grantee from separately acquiring the
2 components of a trauma kit and assembling
3 complete trauma kits that meet the perform-
4 ance standards.
5 ‘‘(3) PERFORMANCE STANDARDS AND OP-
6 TIONAL AGENCY BEST PRACTICES.—Not later than
7 180 days after the date of enactment of this sub-
8 section, the Director of the Bureau of Justice Assist-
9 ance, in consultation with organizations representing
10 trauma surgeons, emergency medical response pro-
11 fessionals, emergency physicians, other medical pro-
12 fessionals, relevant law enforcement agencies of
13 States and units of local government, professional
14 law enforcement organizations, local law enforcement
15 labor or representative organizations, and law en-
16 forcement trade associations, shall—
17 ‘‘(A) develop and publish performance
18 standards for trauma kits that are eligible for
19 purchase using funds made available under this
20 part that, at a minimum, require the compo-
21 nents described in paragraph (4) to be included
22 in a trauma kit; and
23 ‘‘(B) develop and publish optional best
24 practices for law enforcement agencies regard-
25 ing—
†S 2296 ES

771
1 ‘‘(i) training law enforcement officers
2 in the use of trauma kits;
3 ‘‘(ii) the deployment and maintenance
4 of trauma kits in law enforcement vehicles;
5 and
6 ‘‘(iii) the deployment, location, and
7 maintenance of trauma kits in law enforce-
8 ment agency or other government facilities.
9 ‘‘(4) COMPONENTS.—The components of a
10 trauma kit described in this paragraph are—
11 ‘‘(A) a tourniquet recommended by the
12 Committee on Tactical Combat Casualty Care;
13 ‘‘(B) a bleeding control bandage;
14 ‘‘(C) a pair of nonlatex protective gloves
15 and a pen-type marker;
16 ‘‘(D) a pair of blunt-ended scissors;
17 ‘‘(E) instructional documents developed—
18 ‘‘(i) under the ‘Stop the Bleed’ na-
19 tional awareness campaign of the Depart-
20 ment of Homeland Security, or any suc-
21 cessor thereto;
22 ‘‘(ii) by the American College of Sur-
23 geons Committee on Trauma;
24 ‘‘(iii) by the American Red Cross; or
†S 2296 ES

772
1 ‘‘(iv) by any partner of the Depart-
2 ment of Defense;
3 ‘‘(F) a bag or other container adequately
4 designed to hold the contents of the kit; and
5 ‘‘(G) any additional trauma kit supplies
6 that—
7 ‘‘(i) are approved by a State, local, or
8 Tribal law enforcement agency or first re-
9 sponders;
10 ‘‘(ii) can adequately treat a traumatic
11 injury; and
12 ‘‘(iii) can be stored in a readily avail-
13 able kit.’’.

Subtitle I—FISH Act of 2025
18
19
SEC. 1091. SHORT TITLE.
20 This subtitle may be cited as the ‘‘Fighting Foreign
21 Illegal Seafood Harvests Act of 2025’’ or the ‘‘FISH Act
22 of 2025’’.
23
SEC. 1092. DEFINITIONS.
24 In this subtitle:
†S 2296 ES

783
1 (1) ADMINISTRATOR.—Unless otherwise pro-
2 vided, the term ‘‘Administrator’’ means the Adminis-
3 trator of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Ad-
4 ministration or the designee of the Administrator.
5 (2) BENEFICIAL OWNER.—The term ‘‘beneficial
6 owner’’ means, with respect to a vessel, a person
7 that, directly or indirectly, through any contract, ar-
8 rangement, understanding, relationship, or other-
9 wise—
10 (A) exercises substantial control over the
11 vessel; or
12 (B) owns not less than 50 percent of the
13 ownership interests in the vessel.
14 (3) FISH.—The term ‘‘fish’’ means finfish,
15 crustaceans, and mollusks.
16 (4) FORCED LABOR.—The term ‘‘forced labor’’
17 has the meaning given that term in section 307 of
18 the Tariff Act of 1930 (19 U.S.C. 1307).
19 (5) IUU FISHING.—The term ‘‘IUU fishing’’
20 means activities described as illegal fishing, unre-
21 ported fishing, and unregulated fishing in paragraph
22 3 of the International Plan of Action to Prevent,
23 Deter, and Eliminate Illegal, Unreported and Un-
24 regulated Fishing, adopted at the 24th Session of
†S 2296 ES

SEC. 1093. STATEMENT OF POLICY.
18 It is the policy of the United States to partner, con-
19 sult, and coordinate with foreign governments (at the na-
20 tional and subnational levels), civil society, international
21 organizations, international financial institutions, sub-
22 national coastal communities, commercial and recreational
23 fishing industry leaders, communities that engage in
24 artisanal or subsistence fishing, fishers, and the private
25 sector, in a concerted effort—
†S 2296 ES

785
1 (1) to continue the broad effort across the Fed-
2 eral Government to counter IUU fishing, including
3 any potential links to forced labor, human traf-
4 ficking, and other threats to maritime security, as
5 outlined in sections 3533 and 3534 of the Maritime
6 SAFE Act (16 U.S.C. 8002 and 8003); and
7 (2) to, additionally—
8 (A) prioritize efforts to prevent IUU fish-
9 ing at its sources; and
10 (B) support continued implementation of
11 the Central Arctic Ocean Fisheries agreement,
12 as well as joint research and follow-on actions
13 that ensure sustainability of fish stocks in Arc-
14 tic international waters.
15

1 of foreign vessels or foreign fleets engaged in IUU

6 shall include any foreign vessel, foreign fleet, or ben-
7 eficial owner of a foreign vessel or foreign fleet for

SEC. 1095. VISA SANCTIONS FOR FOREIGN PERSONS.
6 (a) FOREIGN PERSONS DESCRIBED.—A foreign per-
7 son is described in this subsection if the foreign person
8 is the owner or beneficial owner of a vessel on the IUU
9 vessel list developed under section 608(c) of the High Seas
10 Driftnet Fishing Moratorium Protection Act (16 U.S.C.
11 1826i(c)).
12 (b) INELIGIBILITY FOR VISAS, ADMISSION, OR PA-
13 ROLE.—
14 (1) VISAS, ADMISSION, OR PAROLE.—A foreign
15 person described in subsection (a) is—
16 (A) inadmissible to the United States;
17 (B) ineligible to receive a visa or other doc-
18 umentation to enter the United States; and
19 (C) otherwise ineligible to be admitted or
20 paroled into the United States or to receive any
21 other benefit under the Immigration and Na-
22 tionality Act (8 U.S.C. 1101 et seq.).
23 (2) CURRENT VISAS REVOKED.—
24 (A) IN GENERAL.—The visa or other entry
25 documentation of a foreign person described in
†S 2296 ES

795
1 subsection (a) shall be revoked, regardless of
2 when such visa or other entry documentation is
3 or was issued.
4 (B) IMMEDIATE EFFECT.—A revocation
5 under subparagraph (A) shall, in accordance
6 with section 221(i) of the Immigration and Na-
7 tionality Act (8 U.S.C. 1201(i))—
8 (i) take effect; and
9 (ii) cancel any other valid visa or
10 entry documentation that is in the person’s
11 possession.
12 (c) NATIONAL INTEREST WAIVER.—The President
13 may waive the imposition of sanctions under this section
14 with respect to a foreign person if doing so is in the na-
15 tional interest of the United States.
16 (d) EXCEPTIONS.—
17 (1) EXCEPTIONS FOR AUTHORIZED INTEL-
18 LIGENCE AND LAW ENFORCEMENT ACTIVITIES.—
19 This section shall not apply with respect to activities
20 subject to the reporting requirements under title V
21 of the National Security Act of 1947 (50 U.S.C.
22 3091 et seq.) or any authorized intelligence, law en-
23 forcement, or national security activities of the
24 United States.
†S 2296 ES

796
1 (2) EXCEPTION TO COMPLY WITH INTER-
2 NATIONAL AGREEMENTS.—Sanctions under sub-
3 section (b) shall not apply with respect to the admis-
4 sion of an alien to the United States if such admis-
5 sion is necessary to comply with the obligations of
6 the United States under the Agreement regarding
7 the Headquarters of the United Nations, signed at
8 Lake Success June 26, 1947, and entered into force
9 November 21, 1947, between the United Nations
10 and the United States, or the Convention on Con-
11 sular Relations, done at Vienna April 24, 1963, and
12 entered into force March 19, 1967, or other inter-
13 national obligations.
14 (3) EXCEPTION FOR SAFETY OF VESSELS AND
15 CREW.—Sanctions under subsection (b) shall not
16 apply with respect to a person providing provisions
17 to a vessel identified under section 608(c) of the
18 High Seas Driftnet Fishing Moratorium Protection
19 Act (16 U.S.C. 1826i) if such provisions are in-
20 tended for the safety and care of the crew aboard
21 the vessel, or the maintenance of the vessel to avoid
22 any environmental or other significant damage.
23 (4) EXEMPTIONS.—Sanctions under subsection
24 (b) shall not apply with respect to a person de-
25 scribed in subsection (a), if such person was listed
†S 2296 ES

797
1 as the owner of a vessel described in that subsection
2 through the use of force, threats of force, fraud, or
3 coercion.

18 United States;

20 the United States or any jurisdiction within the
21 United States, including a foreign branch of
22 such an entity; or
23 (C) any person in the United States.

SEC. 1096. AGREEMENTS.
2 (a) PRESIDENTIAL NEGOTIATION.—In negotiating
3 any relevant agreement with a foreign nation or nations
4 after the date of enactment of this Act, the President is
5 encouraged to consider the impacts on or to IUU fishing
6 and fishing that involves the use of forced labor and strive
7 to ensure that the agreement strengthens efforts to com-
8 bat IUU fishing and fishing that involves the use of forced
9 labor as long as such considerations do not come at the
10 expense of higher priority national interests of the United
11 States.
12 (b) FEDERAL GOVERNMENT ENCOURAGEMENT.—
13 The Federal Government should encourage other nations
14 to ratify treaties and agreements that address IUU fishing
15 to which the United States is a party, including the High
16 Seas Fishing Compliance Agreement and the Port State
17 Measures Agreement, and pursue bilateral and multilat-
18 eral initiatives to raise international ambition to combat
19 IUU fishing, including in the G7 and G20, the United Na-
20 tions, the International Labor Organization (ILO), and
21 the International Maritime Organization (IMO), and
22 through voluntary multilateral efforts, as long as clear
23 burden sharing arrangements with partner nations are de-
24 termined. The bilateral and multilateral initiatives should
25 address underlying drivers of IUU fishing and fishing that
26 involves the use of forced labor.
†S 2296 ES

799
1 (c) TRANSPARENCY FOR NON-BINDING INSTRU-
2 MENTS CONCLUDED UNDER THIS SECTION.—Any memo-
3 randum of understanding or other non-binding instrument
4 to further the objectives of this section shall be considered
5 a qualifying non-binding instrument for purposes of sec-
6 tion 112b of title 1, United States Code.
7
SEC. 1097. ENFORCEMENT PROVISIONS.
8 (a) INCREASE BOARDING OF VESSELS SUSPECTED
9 OF IUU FISHING.—The Commandant of the Coast Guard
10 shall strive to increase, from year to year, its observation
11 of vessels on the high seas that are suspected of IUU fish-
12 ing and related harmful practices, and is encouraged to
13 consider boarding these vessels to the greatest extent prac-
14 ticable.
15 (b) FOLLOW UP.—The Administrator shall, in con-
16 sultation with the Commandant of the Coast Guard and
17 the Secretary of State, coordinate regularly with regional
18 fisheries management organizations to determine what
19 corrective measures each country has taken after vessels
20 that are registered or documented by the country have
21 been boarded for suspected IUU fishing.
22 (c) REPORT.—Not later than 3 years after the date
23 of enactment of this Act and in accordance with informa-
24 tion management rules of the relevant regional fisheries
†S 2296 ES

800
1 management organizations, the Commandant of the Coast
2 Guard shall submit a report to Congress on—
3 (1) the total number of bilateral agreements
4 utilized or enacted during Coast Guard counter-IUU
5 patrols and future patrol plans for operations with
6 partner nations where bilateral agreements are re-
7 quired to effectively execute the counter-IUU mis-
8 sion and any changes to IUU provisions in bilateral
9 agreements;
10 (2) incidents of IUU fishing observed while con-
11 ducting High Seas Boarding and Inspections
12 (HSBI), how the conduct is tracked after referral to
13 the respective country where the vessel is registered
14 or documented, and what actions are taken to docu-
15 ment or otherwise act on the enforcement, or lack
16 thereof, taken by the country;
17 (3) the country where the vessel is registered or
18 documented, the country where the vessel was pre-
19 viously registered and documented if known, and
20 status of a vessel interdicted or observed to be en-
21 gaged in IUU fishing on the high seas by the Coast
22 Guard;
23 (4) incident details on vessels observed to be en-
24 gaged in IUU fishing on the high seas, boarding re-
25 fusals, and what action was taken; and

22
THE FISHERIES SECTOR.

25 relevant agencies, are encouraged to increase support to
†S 2296 ES

805
1 programs that provide technical assistance, institutional
2 capacity, and investment to nations’ fisheries sectors for

7 3552(b) of the Maritime SAFE Act (16 U.S.C. 8032(b)).
8 (b) ANALYSIS OF US CAPACITY-BUILDING EXPER-
9 TISE AND RESOURCES.—In order to maximize efforts on

11 Working Group on IUU Fishing established under section
12 3551 of the Maritime SAFE Act (16 U.S.C. 8031) shall

19 time judicial capabilities.

SEC. 1099C. REPORTS.
8 (a) IMPACT OF NEW TECHNOLOGY.—Not later than
9 1 year after the date of enactment of this Act, the Sec-
10 retary of Homeland Security, with support from the Ad-
11 ministrator and the Working Group established under sec-
12 tion 3551 of the Maritime SAFE Act (16 U.S.C. 8031),
13 shall conduct a study to assess the impact of new tech-
14 nology (such as remote observing, the use of drones, devel-
15 opment of risk assessment tools and data-sharing soft-
16 ware, immediate containerization of fish on fishing vessels,
17 satellite Wi-Fi technology on fishing vessels, and other
18 technology-enhanced new fishing practices) on IUU fish-
19 ing and associated crimes (such as trafficking and fishing
20 involving the use of forced labor) and propose ways to inte-
21 grate these technologies into global fisheries enforcement
22 and management.
23 (b) RUSSIAN AND CHINESE FISHING INDUSTRIES’
24 INFLUENCE ON EACH OTHER AND ON THE UNITED
25 STATES SEAFOOD AND FISHING INDUSTRY.—Not later
†S 2296 ES

807
1 than 2 years after the date of enactment of this Act, the

5 tween the Russian and Chinese fishing industries

18

21 in consultation with the Secretary of State and with the
22 agreement of the Government of Mexico, shall submit to

24 program under which the armed forces of Mexico and the
25 United States Armed Forces will train jointly in the
†S 2296 ES

834
1 United States on tactics, techniques, and procedures for
2 countering the threat posed by transnational criminal or-
3 ganizations, including through—
4 (1) operations involving the use of rotary-wing
5 aircraft; and
6 (2) in consultation with the appropriate civilian
7 government agencies specializing in countering
8 transnational criminal organizations—
9 (A) joint network analysis;
10 (B) counter threat financing;
11 (C) counter illicit trafficking (including
12 narcotics, weapons, and human trafficking, and
13 illicit trafficking in natural resources); and
14 (D) assessments of key nodes of activity of
15 transnational criminal organizations.
16 (b) IMPLEMENTATION.—Not later than 15 days after
17 the date on which the plan required by subsection (a) is
18 submitted under such subsection, the Secretary of Defense
19 shall begin implementing the pilot program described in
20 the plan.
