SEC. 1206. CYBERSECURITY COOPERATION WITH THE GOV-
8
ERNMENT OF PANAMA AND THE PANAMA
9
CANAL AUTHORITY.
10 (a) CYBERSECURITY INTEGRATION.—
11 (1) IN GENERAL.—The Secretary of Defense,
12 using existing authorities of the Secretary, may es-
13 tablish a pilot program in Panama—
14 (A) to enhance the cybersecurity capabili-
15 ties of the Panama Canal Authority and the na-
16 tional security forces of Panama; and
17 (B) to increase cybersecurity cooperation
18 measures between the United States and Pan-
19 ama in current and future joint military train-
20 ing exercises.
21 (2) PURPOSES.—The purposes of the cybersecu-
22 rity cooperation under paragraph (1) are—
23 (A) to assist in implementing the Cyber
24 Cooperation Arrangement;
†S 2296 ES

836
1 (B) to provide training and technical as-
2 sistance to, and enhance joint cooperation with,
3 the national security forces of Panama so as to
4 improve mitigation, deterrence, and detection of
5 ransomware attacks on, and vulnerabilities of,
6 critical infrastructure in and around the Pan-
7 ama Canal; and
8 (C) to incorporate cybersecurity coopera-
9 tion measures into current and potential United
10 States-Panama joint military training exercises
11 so as to improve the security of the Panama
12 Canal.
13 (3) ACTIVITIES.—Activities of the Department
14 of Defense to further the purposes described in
15 paragraph (2) may include the following:
16 (A) Provision of education and training to,
17 and information sharing with, the Panama
18 Canal Authority and the national security
19 forces of Panama.
20 (B) Collaboration on cyber incident re-
21 sponse best practices with the Panama Canal
22 Authority and the national security forces of
23 Panama.
24 (C) Provision of technical assistance to the
25 Panama Canal Authority and the national secu-
†S 2296 ES

837
1 rity forces of Panama to detect and mitigate cy-
2 bersecurity attacks.
3 (D) Development of supply chain security
4 best practices and building a trusted vendor
5 network with the Panama Canal Authority and
6 the national security forces of Panama.
7 (E) Engagement with the national security
8 forces of Panama on joint cybersecurity train-
9 ing exercises and other information-sharing and
10 domain awareness activities relating to cyberse-
11 curity, including by—
12 (i) encouraging the participation of
13 the Government of Panama in existing cy-
14 bersecurity training facilitated or managed
15 by the Department and approved by the
16 Secretary;
17 (ii) incorporating cybersecurity into
18 existing joint training exercises, such as
19 PANAMAX; and
20 (iii) conducting an annual joint table-
21 top cybersecurity exercise.
22 (4) REPORT.—Not later than one year after the
23 date of the enactment of this Act, and annually
24 thereafter through 2030, the Secretary shall—
†S 2296 ES

838
1 (A) submit to the congressional defense
2 committees a report on—
3 (i) the implementation of this section
4 and any challenges relating to such imple-
5 mentation;
6 (ii) any known cyber threats relating
7 to Panama, such as incidents of
8 ransomware attacks on critical infrastruc-
9 ture in and around the Panama Canal; and
10 (iii) actions taken to address and miti-
11 gate such threats; and
12 (B) provide the congressional defense com-
13 mittees with a briefing on such report.
14 (5) PROTECTION OF SENSITIVE INFORMA-
15 TION.—Any activity carried out under this section
16 shall be conducted in a manner that appropriately
17 protects sensitive information and the national secu-
18 rity interests of the United States.
19 (b) DEFINITIONS.—In this section:
20 (1) CRITICAL INFRASTRUCTURE.—The term
21 ‘‘critical infrastructure’’ has the meaning given such
22 term in section 1016(e) of the Critical Infrastruc-

25 ‘‘Panama Canal Authority’’ has the meaning given
†S 2296 ES

839
1 such term in section 3(d) of the Panama Canal Act
2 of 1979 (22 U.S.C. 3602(d)).

4 fers to—

6 military exercise and training series relating to
7 the security of the Panama Canal carried out in

9 mand and the military or security forces of—
10 (i) the governments of countries in
11 Latin America and the Caribbean; and

10 er is in the national security interest of the United States.

†S 2296 ES

863
1 ‘‘(1) IN GENERAL.—It is the policy of the
2 United States—
3 ‘‘(A) to assist Ukraine in maintaining a
4 credible defense and deterrence capability;
5 ‘‘(B) to bolster defense and security co-
6 operation with Ukraine as a means of building
7 a future force of Ukraine that is capable of de-
8 fending Ukraine today and deterring future ag-
9 gression; and
10 ‘‘(C) to advance continued reform of the
11 democratic, economic, defense, and security in-
12 stitutions of Ukraine in order to advance the
13 Euro-Atlantic integration and modernization of
14 Ukraine.
15 ‘‘(2) CREDIBLE DEFENSE AND DETERRENCE
16 CAPABILITY DEFINED.—In this subsection, the term
17 ‘credible defense and deterrence capability’ means
18 the ability to defend against and deter any credible
19 conventional military threat from the Russian Fed-
20 eration acting unilaterally or in concert with part-
21 ners, through the use of conventional military
22 means, possessed in sufficient quantity, including
23 weapons platforms and munitions, command, con-
24 trol, communication, intelligence, surveillance, and
25 reconnaissance capabilities.’’.

SEC. 1228. INTELLIGENCE SUPPORT FOR UKRAINE.
2 (a) IN GENERAL.—The Secretary of Defense shall
3 provide intelligence support, including information, intel-
4 ligence, and imagery collection authorized under title 10,
5 United States Code, to the Government of Ukraine for the
6 purpose of supporting military operations of the Govern-
7 ment of Ukraine that are specifically intended or reason-
8 ably expected to defend and retake the territory of
9 Ukraine.

11 tion, the term ‘‘territory of Ukraine’’ includes all territory
12 internationally recognized to be the sovereign territory of
13 Ukraine, including Crimea and the territory the Russian
14 Federation claims to have annexed in Kherson Oblast,
15 Zaporizhzia Oblast, Donetsk Oblast, and Luhansk Oblast.

SEC. 1230C. BALTIC SECURITY INITIATIVE.
11 (a) ESTABLISHMENT.—Pursuant to the authority
12 provided in chapter 16 of title 10, United States Code,
13 the Secretary of Defense may establish and carry out an
14 initiative, to be known as the ‘‘Baltic Security Initiative’’,
15 for the purpose of deepening security cooperation with the
16 military forces of the Baltic countries.
17 (b) RELATIONSHIP TO EXISTING AUTHORITIES.—An
18 initiative established under subsection (a) shall be carried
19 out pursuant to the authorities provided in title 10, United
20 States Code.
21 (c) OBJECTIVES.—The objectives of an initiative es-
22 tablished under subsection (a) should include—
23 (1) to achieve United States national security
24 objectives by—
†S 2296 ES

871
1 (A) deterring aggression by the Russian
2 Federation; and
3 (B) implementing the North Atlantic Trea-
4 ty Organization’s new Strategic Concept, which
5 seeks to strengthen the alliance’s deterrence
6 and defense posture by denying potential adver-
7 saries any possible opportunities for aggression;
8 (2) to enhance regional planning and coopera-
9 tion among the military forces of the Baltic coun-
10 tries, particularly with respect to long-term regional
11 capability projects, including—
12 (A) long-range precision fire systems and
13 capabilities;
14 (B) integrated air and missile defense;
15 (C) maritime domain awareness;
16 (D) land forces development, including
17 stockpiling large caliber ammunition;
18 (E) command, control, communications,
19 computers, intelligence, surveillance, and recon-
20 naissance;
21 (F) special operations forces development;
22 (G) coordination with and security en-
23 hancements for Poland, which is a neighboring
24 North Atlantic Treaty Organization ally; and
†S 2296 ES

872
1 (H) other military capabilities, as deter-
2 mined by the Secretary; and
3 (3) with respect to the military forces of the
4 Baltic countries, to improve cyber defenses and resil-
5 ience to hybrid threats.
6 (d) STRATEGY.—
7 (1) IN GENERAL.—Not later than one year
8 after the date of the enactment of this Act, the Sec-
9 retary shall submit to the Committees on Armed
10 Services of the Senate and the House of Representa-
11 tives a report setting forth a strategy for the De-
12 partment of Defense to achieve the objectives de-
13 scribed in subsection (c).
14 (2) CONSIDERATIONS.—The strategy required
15 by this subsection shall include a consideration of—
16 (A) security assistance programs for the
17 Baltic countries authorized as of the date on
18 which the strategy is submitted;
19 (B) the ongoing security threats to the
20 North Atlantic Treaty Organization’s eastern
21 flank posed by Russian aggression, including as
22 a result of the Russian Federation’s 2022 inva-
23 sion of Ukraine with support from Belarus; and
24 (C) the ongoing security threats to the
25 Baltic countries posed by the presence, coercive
†S 2296 ES

873
1 economic policies, and other malign activities of
2 the People’s Republic of China.

SEC. 1235. BOLSTERING INDUSTRIAL RESILIENCE WITH AL-
2
LIES IN INDO-PACIFIC REGION.
3 (a) ESTABLISHMENT.—The Secretary of Defense, in
4 coordination with the Secretary of State, shall establish
5 and maintain a security cooperation initiative (referred to
6 in this section as the ‘‘Partnership’’) to strengthen co-
7 operation among the defense industrial bases of the
8 United States and allied and partner countries in the
9 Indo-Pacific region.
10 (b) OBJECTIVES.—The objectives of the Partnership
11 shall be the following:
12 (1) To enable the production and supply of the
13 material necessary for equipping the Armed Forces
14 of the United States and the military forces of allied
15 and partner countries to achieve—
16 (A) the objectives set forth in the most re-
17 cent national security strategy report submitted
18 to Congress by the President pursuant to sec-
19 tion 108 of the National Security Act of 1947
20 (50 U.S.C. 3043);
21 (B) the policy guidance of the Secretary of
22 Defense provided pursuant to section 113(g) of
23 title 10, United States Code; and
24 (C) the future-years defense program sub-
25 mitted to Congress by the Secretary of Defense
†S 2296 ES

885
1 pursuant to section 221 of title 10, United
2 States Code.
3 (2) To strengthen the collective defense indus-
4 trial base by expanding industrial base capability,
5 capacity, and workforce, including with respect to
6 enhanced supply chain security, interoperability, and
7 resilience among participating countries.
8 (3) To identify and mitigate industrial base
9 vulnerabilities across partner countries.
10 (4) To advance research and development ac-
11 tivities to provide the Armed Forces of the United
12 States and the military forces of allied and partner
13 countries with systems capable of ensuring techno-
14 logical superiority over potential adversaries.
15 (5) To promote co-development, co-production,
16 and procurement collaboration in key defense sec-
17 tors.
18 (6) To promote defense innovation, improve in-
19 formation sharing, encourage standardization, re-
20 duce barriers to cooperation, and otherwise mitigate
21 potential vulnerabilities and facilitate collaboration.
22 (7) Any other matter the Secretary of Defense
23 considers appropriate.
24 (c) DESIGNATION OF SENIOR OFFICIAL.—
†S 2296 ES

886
1 (1) IN GENERAL.—Not later than 180 days
2 after the date of the enactment of this Act, the Sec-
3 retary of Defense shall designate a senior civilian of-
4 ficial of the Department of Defense at the Assistant
5 Secretary level or above to lead relevant efforts of
6 the Partnership, as determined by the Secretary.
7 (2) NOTIFICATION.—Not later than 30 days
8 after the date on which the Secretary of Defense
9 makes or changes a designation under paragraph
10 (1), the Secretary shall submit to the congressional
11 defense committees a notification of such designa-
12 tion or change.
13 (d) PARTICIPATION.—The Secretary of Defense, in
14 coordination with the Secretary of State, shall establish
15 a process to determine which allies and partners of the
16 United States (including Australia, Japan, the Republic
17 of Korea, India, the Philippines, and New Zealand) shall
18 be invited to participate as member countries of the Part-
19 nership.
20 (e) AUTHORITIES.—To carry out this section, the
21 Secretary of Defense may do the following:
22 (1) Enter into agreements and memoranda of
23 understanding with appropriate counterparts from
24 participating countries.
†S 2296 ES

887
1 (2) Establish working groups and technical ex-
2 changes.
3 (3) Provide technical assistance and capacity-
4 building support to partner countries using authori-
5 ties available to the Secretary under title 10, United
6 States Code.
7 (4) Use funds authorized to be appropriated to
8 the Department of Defense for international co-
9 operation programs, industrial base resilience, or
10 other relevant purposes.
11 (5) Engage with industry, capital providers,
12 academia, and any other stakeholders necessary to
13 advance the objectives described in subsection (b).
14 (f) REPORT AND BRIEFING.—
15 (1) REPORT.—
16 (A) IN GENERAL.—Not later than March
17 1, 2027, and annually thereafter through 2031,
18 the Secretary of Defense shall submit to the
19 congressional defense committees a report on
20 the status and progress of the Partnership.
21 (B) ELEMENTS.—Each report required by
22 subparagraph (A) shall include the following:
23 (i) An assessment of shared industrial
24 base vulnerabilities.
†S 2296 ES

888
1 (ii) An overview of efforts among par-
2 ticipating countries to enhance supply
3 chain integrity and resilience.
4 (iii) A description of any joint defense
5 production or co-development initiative, in-
6 cluding any such initiative involving sen-
7 sitive or classified technologies.
8 (iv) An articulation of priority initia-
9 tives for the upcoming fiscal year.
10 (v) Recommendations for legislative,
11 regulatory, policy, or resourcing changes to
12 achieve the objectives described in sub-

14 (vi) Any other matter the Secretary of
15 Defense considers appropriate.
16 (2) BRIEFING.—Not later than December 1,
17 2026, and annually thereafter through 2030, the
18 Secretary of Defense shall provide the congressional
19 defense committees with a briefing on the progress
20 made toward achieving the objectives described in
21 subsection (b).
22 (g) TERMINATION.—The authority under this section
23 shall terminate on December 31, 2030.

SEC. 1247. SENSE OF CONGRESS ON DEFENSE ALLIANCES
5
AND PARTNERSHIPS IN THE INDO-PACIFIC
6
REGION.
7 It is the sense of Congress that the Secretary of De-
8 fense should continue efforts that strengthen United
9 States defense alliances and partnerships in the Indo-Pa-
10 cific region so as to further the comparative advantage of
11 the United States in strategic competition with the Peo-
12 ple’s Republic of China, including by—
13 (1) enhancing cooperation with Japan, con-
14 sistent with the Treaty of Mutual Cooperation and
15 Security Between the United States of America and

SEC. 1254. JOINT PROGRAM OFFICE FOR NON-PROGRAMS
7
OF RECORD TO SUPPORT FOREIGN ACQUISI-
8
TION.
9 (a) ESTABLISHMENT.—Not later than 180 days after
10 the date of the enactment of this Act, the Secretary of
11 Defense shall establish and charter, within the Office of
12 the Under Secretary of Defense for Acquisition and
13 Sustainment, a Joint Program Office for Non-Programs
14 of Record (referred to in this section as the ‘‘Joint Pro-
15 gram Office’’) to support the acquisition of specified non-
16 program of record systems by approved foreign partners
17 and allies.
18 (b) STRUCTURE.—
19 (1) LEADERSHIP.—The Joint Program Office
20 shall be led by a senior executive or military flag of-
21 ficer of the Office of the Under Secretary of Defense
22 for Acquisition and Sustainment, who shall have a
23 deputy from the Defense Security Cooperation Agen-
24 cy.
†S 2296 ES

918
1 (2) STAFFING.—The staff of the Joint Program
2 Office shall include detailees from the international
3 program offices of the military departments, the De-
4 fense Security Cooperation Agency, and the Defense
5 Technology Security Administration.
6 (c) RESPONSIBILITIES.—
7 (1) IN GENERAL.—The Joint Program Office
8 shall be responsible for the following:
9 (A) Coordinating with allies and partners
10 to identify and procure non-program of record
11 capabilities.
12 (B) Facilitating discussions between indus-
13 try and foreign partners on new non-program-
14 of-record capabilities.
15 (C) Liaising with combatant commands to
16 identify new specified non-program of record
17 systems aligned with the strategic priorities of
18 the combatant commands for theater security
19 cooperation.
20 (D) Promoting capabilities with foreign
21 partners that align with priority capabilities for
22 the combatant commands.
23 (E) Coordinating with, and as necessary,
24 providing additional support to, the inter-
25 national program offices of the military depart-
†S 2296 ES

919
1 ments to expedite delivery of capabilities to for-
2 eign partners and allies.
3 (F) Coordinating internal Department of
4 Defense approval processes to expedite the de-
5 livery of non-program of record capabilities.
6 (d) BRIEFING.—Not later than 30 days after the es-
7 tablishment of the Joint Program Office, the Secretary
8 shall provide the Committees on Armed Services of the
9 Senate and the House of Representatives with a briefing
10 on the charter, responsibilities, resources, and plan of ac-
11 tivities for the Joint Program Office for the subsequent
12 fiscal year.
13 (e) SPECIFIED NON-PROGRAM OF RECORD SYSTEM
14 DEFINED.—In this section, the term ‘‘specified non-pro-
15 gram of record system’’ means a record system that does
16 not exist formally as a program of record within the De-
17 partment of Defense, including—
18 (1) an international or civil variant of a pro-
19 gram of record with nonstandard configurations, or
20 a type 1 non-program of record system;
21 (2) a prior program of record that is no longer
22 supported in United States inventory, or a type 2
23 non-program of record system;
†S 2296 ES

920
1 (3) a program consisting of commercially devel-
2 oped munitions items, or a type 3 non-program of
3 record system;
4 (4) a program consisting of commercially devel-
5 oped dual-use items, or a type 4 non-program of
6 record system;
7 (5) a program consisting of commercially devel-
8 oped dual-use items combined with program of
9 record elements, or a type 5 non-program of record
10 system; and
11 (6) a program consisting of commercially devel-
12 oped dual-use items with military end-use, or a type
13 6 non-program of record system.

18 (A) an acquisition strategy that documents

21 the fastest acquisition path.

23 quisition strategy required by subparagraphs (A)
24 and (B) of paragraph (1), the acquisition program

†S 2296 ES

935
1 (A) measure, and justify with respect to

6 that is not a program of record, transparently
7 consult with the prime contractor to seek con-
8 sensus on cost and schedule; and
9 (C) provide, in coordination with the ap-
10 propriate regional directorate of the Office of
11 the Under Secretary of Defense for Policy and
12 the Director of the Defense Security Coopera-

14 such military department a briefing on the re-
15 sults of the measurements under subparagraph
16 (A) and the consultation under subparagraph
17 (B).
18 (3) DECISION.—Not later than 30 days after
19 the date of a briefing under paragraph (2)(C), the

17 batant commands, the participant institutions in the

22 (b) OBJECTIVE.—The objective of the Program is to
23 promote the readiness and interoperability of the United

25 countries by providing a high-quality, cost effective mili-
26 tary-based educational experience for foreign students in
†S 2296 ES

942
1 furtherance of the military-to-military program objectives

6 ers.

8 of Defense shall—

10 serve Officers’ Training Corps program the foreign
11 students who, based on criteria established by the
12 Secretary, the Secretary recommends be considered
13 for admission under the Program;
14 (2) coordinate with partner countries to evalu-
15 ate interest in and promote awareness of the Pro-
16 gram;
17 (3) establish a mechanism for tracking an
18 alumni network of foreign students who participate
19 in the Program; and

21 ticipant institutions in the Senior Reserve Officers’
22 Training Corps program and partner countries to
23 identify academic institutions and programs that—
†S 2296 ES

943
1 (A) have specialized academic programs in
2 areas of study or interest to participating coun-

4 (B) have high participation from or signifi-

6 countries.

†S 2296 ES

16 (b) STRATEGY ELEMENTS.—The strategy required
17 under subsection (a) shall include the following elements:
18 (1) A detailed plan for how United States secu-
19 rity assistance will—
20 (A) dismantle transnational criminal net-
21 works that traffic illicit drugs, including
22 fentanyl, into the United States and profit from
23 other criminal activities, including pervasive
24 human trafficking and human smuggling, weap-
25 ons trafficking, cybercrimes, money laundering,
†S 2296 ES

947
1 and the importation of precursor chemicals to
2 mass-produce illicit drugs;
3 (B) increase the capacity of Mexico’s mili-
4 tary and public security institutions to improve
5 security at Mexico’s northern and southern bor-
6 ders and degrade transnational criminal organi-
7 zations; and
8 (C) enhance the institutional capacity of
9 civilian law enforcement, prosecutors, and
10 courts to strengthen rule of law, redress public
11 corruption related to the activities and influence
12 of transnational criminal organizations, and
13 combat impunity.
14 (2) A detailed summary of activities to imple-
15 ment the plan described in paragraph (1), including
16 a list of implementing government entities and non-
17 governmental organizations.
18 (3) A detailed summary of priorities, mile-
19 stones, and performance measures to monitor and
20 evaluate results of the strategy.
21 (c) BILATERAL COOPERATION REPORTING.—The re-

25 ment of Mexico, such as diplomatic engagements, security
†S 2296 ES

948
1 assistance programs, technical assistance, and other forms
2 of cooperation that advance the priorities described in sub-
3 section (b).

5 subsection (a) shall be submitted in unclassified form, but
6 may include a classified annex.
7 (e) BRIEFING.—Not later than 1 year after the sub-
8 mission of the report and strategy required under sub-
9 section (a), and annually thereafter, the Secretary of State
10 shall provide to the Committee on Foreign Relations of

12 House of Representatives a briefing on the implementation
13 of the strategy.

15 MILITARY FORCE AGAINST MEXICO.—Nothing in this sec-

SEC. 1271. SHORT TITLE.
18 This subtitle may be cited as the ‘‘Western Balkans
19 Democracy and Prosperity Act’’.
20
SEC. 1272. FINDINGS.
21 Congress finds the following:
22 (1) The Western Balkans countries (the Repub-
23 lic of Albania, Bosnia and Herzegovina, the Republic
24 of Kosovo, Montenegro, the Republic of North Mac-
25 edonia and the Republic of Serbia) form a plural-
†S 2296 ES

955
1 istic, multi-ethnic region in the heart of Europe that
2 is critical to the peace, stability, and prosperity of
3 that continent.
4 (2) Continued peace, stability, and prosperity in
5 the Western Balkans is directly tied to the opportu-
6 nities for democratic and economic advancement
7 available to the citizens and residents of those six
8 countries.
9 (3) It is in the mutual interest of the United
10 States and the countries of the Western Balkans to
11 promote stable and sustainable economic growth and
12 development in the region.
13 (4) The reforms and integration with the Euro-
14 pean Union pursued by countries in the Western
15 Balkans have led to significant democratic and eco-
16 nomic progress in the region.
17 (5) Despite economic progress, rates of poverty
18 and unemployment in the Western Balkans remain
19 higher than in neighboring European Union coun-
20 tries.
21 (6) Out-migration, particularly of youth, is af-
22 fecting demographics in each Western Balkans coun-
23 try, resulting in population decline in all six coun-
24 tries.
†S 2296 ES

956
1 (7) Implementing critical economic and govern-
2 ance reforms could help enable investment and em-
3 ployment opportunities in the Western Balkans, es-
4 pecially for youth, and can provide powerful tools for
5 economic development and for encouraging broader
6 participation in a political process that increases
7 prosperity for all.
8 (8) Existing regional economic efforts, such as
9 the Common Regional Market, the Berlin Process,
10 and the Open Balkan Initiative, could have the po-
11 tential to improve the economic conditions in the
12 Western Balkans, while promoting inclusion and
13 transparency.
14 (9) The Department of Commerce, through its
15 Foreign Commercial Service, plays an important role
16 in promoting and facilitating opportunities for
17 United States investment.
18 (10) Corruption, including among key political
19 leaders, continues to plague the Western Balkans
20 and represents one of the greatest impediments to
21 further economic and political development in the re-
22 gion.
23 (11) Disinformation campaigns targeting the
24 Western Balkans undermine the credibility of its
†S 2296 ES

957
1 democratic institutions, including the integrity of its
2 elections.
3 (12) Vulnerability to cyberattacks or attacks on
4 information and communication technology infra-
5 structure increases risks to the functioning of gov-
6 ernment and the delivery of public services.
7 (13) United States Cyber Command, the De-
8 partment of State, and other Federal agencies play
9 a critical role in defending the national security in-
10 terests of the United States, including by deploying
11 cyber hunt forward teams at the request of partner
12 nations to reinforce their cyber defenses.
13 (14) Securing domestic and international cyber
14 networks and ICT infrastructure is a national secu-
15 rity priority for the United States, which is exempli-
16 fied by offices and programs across the Federal Gov-
17 ernment that support cybersecurity.
18 (15) Corruption and disinformation proliferate
19 in political environments marked by autocratic con-
20 trol or partisan conflict.
21 (16) Dependence on Russian sources of fossil
22 fuels and natural gas for the countries of the West-
23 ern Balkans ties their economies and politics to the
24 Russian Federation and inhibits their aspirations for
25 European integration.
†S 2296 ES

958
1 (17) Reducing the reliance of the Western Bal-
2 kans on Russian natural gas supplies and fossil fuels
3 is in the national interest of the United States.
4 (18) The growing influence of China in the
5 Western Balkans could also have a deleterious im-
6 pact on strategic competition, democracy, and eco-
7 nomic integration with Europe.
8 (19) In March 2022, President Biden launched
9 the European Democratic Resilience Initiative to
10 bolster democratic resilience, advance anti-corruption
11 efforts, and defend human rights in Ukraine and its
12 neighbors in response to Russia’s war of aggression.
13 (20) The parliamentary and local elections held
14 in Serbia on December 17, 2023, and their imme-
15 diate aftermath are cause for deep concern about the
16 state of Serbia’s democracy, including due to the
17 final report of the Organization for Security and Co-
18 operation in Europe’s Office for Democratic Institu-
19 tions and Human Rights, which—
20 (A) found ‘‘unjust conditions’’ for the elec-
21 tion;
22 (B) found ‘‘numerous procedural defi-
23 ciencies, including inconsistent application of
24 safeguards during voting and counting, fre-
25 quent instances of overcrowding, breaches in se-
†S 2296 ES

959
1 crecy of the vote, and numerous instances of
2 group voting’’; and
3 (C) asserted that ‘‘voting must be re-
4 peated’’ in certain polling stations.
5 (21) The Organization for Security and Co-op-
6 eration in Europe also noted that Serbian officials
7 accused primarily peaceful protestors, opposition
8 parties, and civil society of ‘‘attempting to desta-
9 bilize the government’’, a concerning allegation that
10 threatens the safety of important elements of Ser-
11 bian society.
12 (22) Democratic countries whose values are in
13 alignment with the United States make for stronger
14 and more durable partnerships.

SEC. 1273. SENSE OF CONGRESS.
16 It is a sense of Congress that the United States
17 should—
18 (1) encourage increased business links and in-
19 vestment between the United States and allies and

21 (2) expand United States assistance to regional
22 integration efforts in the Western Balkans;
23 (3) strengthen and expand regional economic

SEC. 1275. CODIFICATION OF SANCTIONS RELATING TO
2
THE WESTERN BALKANS.
3 (a) IN GENERAL.—Each person listed or designated
4 for the imposition of sanctions under an executive order
5 described in subsection (c) as of the date of the enactment
6 of this Act shall remain so designated, except as provided
7 in subsections (d) and (f).
8 (b) CONTINUATION OF SANCTIONS AUTHORITIES.—
9 Each authority to impose sanctions provided for under an
10 executive order described in subsection (c) shall remain
11 in effect.
12 (c) EXECUTIVE ORDERS SPECIFIED.—The executive
13 orders specified in this subsection are—
14 (1) Executive Order 13219, as amended by Ex-
15 ecutive Order 13304 (50 U.S.C. 1701 note; relating
16 to blocking property of persons who threaten inter-
17 national stabilization efforts in the Western Bal-
18 kans); and
19 (2) Executive Order 14033 (50 U.S.C. 1701
20 note; relating to blocking property and suspending
21 entry into the United States of certain persons con-
22 tributing to the destabilizing situation in the West-
23 ern Balkans), as amended by Executive Order
24 14140 (90 Fed. Reg. 2589; relating to taking addi-
25 tional steps with respect to the situation in the
†S 2296 ES

966
1 Western Balkans), as in effect on the date of the en-
2 actment of Executive Order 14140.
3 (d) TERMINATION OF SANCTIONS.—The President
4 may terminate the application of a sanction authorized
5 under Executive Order 14033, as amended by Executive
6 Order 14140, with respect to a person if the President
7 certifies to the appropriate committees of Congress that—
8 (1) the person is not engaging in the activity
9 that was the basis for such sanction or has taken
10 significant verifiable steps toward stopping such ac-
11 tivity; and
12 (2) the President has received reliable assur-
13 ances that the person will not knowingly engage in
14 activity subject to such sanction in the future.
15 (e) RULE OF CONSTRUCTION REGARDING DELISTING
16 PROCEDURES RELATING TO SANCTIONS AUTHORIZED
17 UNDER EXECUTIVE ORDERS 13219 AND 13304.—Noth-
18 ing in subsection (d) may be construed to modify the
19 delisting procedures used by the Department of the Treas-
20 ury with respect to sanctions authorized under Executive
21 Order 13219, as amended by Executive Order 13304 (50
22 U.S.C. 1701 note; relating to blocking property of persons
23 who threaten international stabilization efforts in the
24 Western Balkans).
25 (f) WAIVER.—
†S 2296 ES

967
1 (1) IN GENERAL.—The President may waive
2 the application of sanctions under this section for re-
3 newable periods not to exceed 180 days if the Presi-
4 dent—
5 (A) determines that such a waiver is in the
6 national security interests of the United States;
7 and
8 (B) not less than 15 days before the grant-
9 ing of the waiver, submits to the appropriate
10 committees of Congress a notice of and jus-
11 tification for the waiver.
12 (2) FORM.—The waiver described in paragraph
13 (1) may be transmitted in classified form.
14 (g) EXCEPTIONS.—
15 (1) HUMANITARIAN ASSISTANCE.—Sanctions
16 authorized under this section shall not apply to—
17 (A) the conduct or facilitation of a trans-
18 action for the provision of agricultural commod-
19 ities, food, medicine, medical devices, humani-
20 tarian assistance, or for humanitarian purposes;
21 or
22 (B) transactions that are necessary for, or
23 ordinarily incident to, the activities described in
24 subparagraph (A).
†S 2296 ES

968

2 GATIONS AND LAW ENFORCEMENT ACTIVITIES.—

4 apply with respect to an alien if admitting or parol-
5 ing such alien is necessary—
6 (A) to comply with United States obliga-
7 tions under—
8 (i) the Agreement between the United
9 Nations and the United States of America
10 regarding the Headquarters of the United
11 Nations, signed at Lake Success June 26,
12 1947, and entered into force November 21,
13 1947;
14 (ii) the Convention on Consular Rela-
15 tions, done at Vienna April 24, 1963, and
16 entered into force March 19, 1967; or
17 (iii) any other international agree-
18 ment; or
19 (B) to carry out or assist law enforcement
20 activity in the United States.

22 TIES.—Sanctions authorized under this section shall
23 not apply to—
†S 2296 ES

969
1 (A) any activity subject to the reporting

7 GOODS.—
8 (A) IN GENERAL.—The requirement to
9 block and prohibit all transactions in all prop-
10 erty and interests in property under this section
11 shall not include the authority or a requirement

15 the term ‘‘good’’ means any article, natural or
16 manmade substance, material, supply or manu-
17 factured product, including inspection and test
18 equipment, and excluding technical data.

20 promulgate such rules and regulations as may be nec-

24 ers Act (50 U.S.C. 1704)).

SEC. 1276. DEMOCRATIC AND ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT
9
AND PROSPERITY INITIATIVES.
10 (a) ANTI-CORRUPTION INITIATIVE.—The Secretary
11 of State, through ongoing and new programs, should de-
12 velop an initiative that—
13 (1) seeks to expand technical assistance in each
14 Western Balkans country, taking into account local
15 conditions and contingent on the agreement of the
16 host country government to develop new national
17 anti-corruption strategies;
18 (2) seeks to share best practices with, and pro-
19 vide training, including through the use of embedded
20 advisors, to civilian law enforcement agencies and ju-
21 dicial institutions, and other relevant administrative
22 bodies, of the Western Balkans countries, to improve
23 the efficiency, transparency, and accountability of
24 such agencies and institutions;
†S 2296 ES

971
1 (3) strengthens existing national anti-corruption
2 strategies—
3 (A) to combat political corruption, particu-
4 larly in the judiciary, independent election over-
5 sight bodies, and public procurement processes;
6 and
7 (B) to strengthen regulatory and legislative
8 oversight of critical governance areas, such as
9 freedom of information and public procurement,
10 including by strengthening cyber defenses and
11 ICT infrastructure networks;
12 (4) includes the Western Balkans countries in
13 the European Democratic Resilience Initiative of the
14 Department of State, or any equivalent successor
15 initiative, and considers the Western Balkans as a
16 recipient of anti-corruption funding for such initia-
17 tive; and
18 (5) seeks to promote the important role of an
19 independent media in countering corruption through
20 engagements with governments of Western Balkan
21 countries and providing training opportunities for
22 journalists on investigative reporting.
23 (b) PRIORITIZING CYBER RESILIENCE, REGIONAL
24 ECONOMIC CONNECTIVITY, AND ECONOMIC COMPETI-
25 TIVENESS.—

SEC. 1280. RELATIONS BETWEEN KOSOVO AND SERBIA.
9 (a) SENSE OF CONGRESS.—It is the sense of Con-
10 gress that—
11 (1) the Agreement on the Path to Normaliza-
12 tion of Relations, which was agreed to by Kosovo
13 and Serbia on February 27, 2023, with the facilita-
14 tion of the European Union, is a positive step for-
15 ward in advancing normalization between the two
16 countries;
17 (2) Serbia and Kosovo should seek to make im-
18 mediate progress on the Implementation Annex to
19 the agreement referred to in paragraph (1);
20 (3) once sufficient progress has been made on
21 the Implementation Annex, the United States should
22 consider advancing initiatives to strengthen bilateral
23 relations with both countries, which could include—
24 (A) establishing bilateral strategic dia-
25 logues with Kosovo and Serbia; and
†S 2296 ES

990
1 (B) advancing concrete initiatives to deep-
2 en economic ties and investment with both
3 countries; and
4 (4) the United States should continue to sup-
5 port a comprehensive final agreement between
6 Kosovo and Serbia based on mutual recognition.
7 (b) STATEMENT OF POLICY.—It is the policy of the
8 United States Government that—
9 (1) it shall not pursue any policy that advocates
10 for land swaps, partition, or other forms of redraw-
11 ing borders along ethnic lines in the Western Bal-
12 kans as a means to settle disputes between nation
13 states in the region; and
14 (2) it should support pluralistic democracies in
15 countries in the Western Balkans as a means to pre-
16 vent a return to the ethnic strife that once charac-
17 terized the region.
18

20
THE WESTERN BALKANS.
21 (a) REPORTS REQUIRED.—Not later than 180 days

991
1 or agencies, as appropriate, shall submit a report to the
2 appropriate committees of Congress, the Select Committee
3 on Intelligence of the Senate, the Committee on Armed
4 Services of the Senate, and the Permanent Select Com-
5 mittee on Intelligence of the House of Representatives re-
6 garding Russian and Chinese malign influence operations
7 and campaigns carried out with respect to Balkan coun-
8 tries that seek—
9 (1) to undermine democratic institutions;
10 (2) to promote political instability; and
11 (3) to harm the interests of the United States
12 and North Atlantic Treaty Organization member
13 and partner states in the Western Balkans.

15 subsection (a) shall include—
16 (1) an assessment of the objectives of the Rus-
17 sian Federation and the People’s Republic of China
18 regarding malign influence operations and cam-
19 paigns carried out with respect to Western Balkans
20 countries—
21 (A) to undermine democratic institutions,
22 including the planning and execution of demo-
23 cratic elections;
24 (B) to promote political instability; and

992
1 (C) to manipulate the information environ-
2 ment;
3 (2) the activities and roles of the Department

5 countering Russian and Chinese malign influence
6 operations and campaigns;

8 (A) each network, entity and individual, to
9 the extent such information is available, of Rus-
10 sia, China, or any other country with which
11 Russia or China may cooperate, that is sup-
12 porting such Russian or Chinese malign influ-
13 ence operations or campaigns, including the

15 activities in a Western Balkans country that
16 may limit freedom of speech or create barriers
17 of access to democratic processes, including ex-
18 ercising the right to vote in a free and fair elec-
19 tion; and
20 (B) the role of each such entity in pro-
21 viding such support;
22 (4) the identification of the tactics, techniques,

25 kans countries;

5 ‘‘(B) develop and apply, generally, rules
6 and terms to ensure Corporation-backed lending
7 through an intermediary does not carry exces-
8 sively punitive or disproportionate penalties for
9 customers in default;
10 ‘‘(C) ensure that such policies and prac-
11 tices include effective safeguards to prevent
12 usurious or abusive lending by intermediaries,
13 including in the provision of microfinance; and
14 ‘‘(D) ensure the intermediary includes in
15 any lending contract an appropriate level of fi-
16 nancial literacy to the borrower, including—
17 ‘‘(i) disclosures that fully explain to
18 the customer both lender and customer
19 rights and obligations under the contract
20 in language that is accessible to the cus-
21 tomer;
22 ‘‘(ii) the specific loan terms and ten-
23 ure of the contract;
24 ‘‘(iii) any procedures and potential
25 penalties or forfeitures in case of default;
†S 2296 ES

1039
1 ‘‘(iv) information on privacy and per-
2 sonal data protection; and
3 ‘‘(v) any other policies that the Cor-
4 poration determines will further the goal of
5 an informed borrower.

7 priate auditing mechanisms to oversee and monitor
8 secondary lending, provided through intermediaries
9 in partner countries in each annual report to Con-
10 gress required under paragraph (2), a summary of

SEC. 1272. FINDINGS.
10 Congress makes the following findings:
11 (1) The People’s Republic of China, the Rus-
12 sian Federation, the Islamic Republic of Iran, and
13 the Democratic People’s Republic of Korea are each
14 considered—
15 (A) a foreign adversary (as defined in sec-
16 tion 825(d) of the National Defense Authoriza-
17 tion Act for Fiscal Year 2024 (Public Law
18 118–31; 137 Stat. 322; 46 U.S.C. 50309
19 note));
20 (B) a country of risk (as defined in section
21 6432(a) of the Servicemember Quality of Life
22 Improvement and National Defense Authoriza-
23 tion Act for Fiscal Year 2025 (Public Law
24 118–159; 138 Stat. 2488; 42 U.S.C. 7144b
25 note)) for purposes of assessing counterintel-
†S 2296 ES

1056
1 ligence risks posed by certain visitors to Na-
2 tional Laboratories;
3 (C) a foreign country of concern (as de-
4 fined in section 10612(a) of the Research and
5 Development, Competition, and Innovation Act
6 (Public Law 117–167; 136 Stat. 1635; 42
7 U.S.C. 19221 note));
8 (D) a covered foreign country (as defined
9 in section 164 of the Servicemember Quality of
10 Life Improvement and National Defense Au-
11 thorization Act for Fiscal Year 2025 (Public
12 Law 118159; 138 Stat. 1818; 10 U.S.C. 4651
13 note prec.)) for purposes of a prohibition on op-
14 eration, procurement, and contracting relating
15 to foreign-made light detection and ranging
16 technology; and
17 (E) a covered foreign country (as defined
18 in section 1622 of the National Defense Au-
19 thorization Act for Fiscal Year 2022 (Public
20 Law 11781; 135 Stat. 2086; 10 U.S.C. 421
21 note prec.)) for purposes of a strategy and plan

24 (2) According to the 2025 Intelligence Commu-
25 nity Annual Threat Assessment, the United States
†S 2296 ES

1057
1 faces an increasingly contested and dangerous global
2 landscape as the four adversaries named in para-
3 graph (1) deepen cooperation in a manner that—
4 (A) reinforces threats posed by each such
5 adversary individually; and
6 (B) poses new challenges to the strength

8 prehensive Strategic Partnership, signed at

10 (F) traditional relations of friendship and

14 (4) The most concerning forms of such coopera-
15 tion with respect to the interests of the United
16 States occur bilaterally in the realm of defense co-
17 operation. Examples include the following:
18 (A) TRANSFER AND SHARING OF WEAPONS
19 AND MUNITIONS.—Since 2022, the Islamic Re-
20 public of Iran has supplied the Russian Federa-
21 tion with drones and ballistic missiles, and the
22 Democratic People’s Republic of Korea has pro-
23 vided artillery ammunition and ballistic mis-
24 siles. Likewise, the Russian Federation has
25 agreed to provide the Islamic Republic of Iran
†S 2296 ES

1059
1 with Su–35 fighter jets and air defense assist-
2 ance.
3 (B) TRANSFER AND SHARING OF DUAL-
4 USE TECHNOLOGIES AND CAPABILITIES.—Dual-
5 use goods supplied by the People’s Republic of
6 China have enabled the Russian Federation to
7 continue defense production in the face of wide-
8 ranging sanctions and export controls intended
9 to prevent the Russian Federation from access-
10 ing the necessary components to fuel its defense
11 industry. In turn, reporting indicates that the
12 Russian Federation has provided technical ex-
13 pertise on satellite technology to the Democratic
14 People’s Republic of Korea and is working
15 closely with the People’s Republic of China on
16 air defense and submarine technology.
17 (C) JOINT MILITARY ACTIVITIES AND EX-
18 ERCISES.—The military forces of the Demo-
19 cratic People’s Republic of Korea are actively
20 participating in the Russian Federation’s inva-
21 sion of Ukraine, and joint military exercises be-
22 tween the People’s Republic of China and the
23 Russian Federation are expanding in scope,
24 scale, and geographic reach, including in close
25 proximity to territory of the United States.
†S 2296 ES

1060
1 (D) COORDINATION.—Coordination on
2 disinformation and cyber operations, including
3 coordinated messaging aimed at denigrating
4 and isolating the United States internationally.
5 (5) Adversaries of the United States are also
6 cooperating in a manner that may circumvent
7 United States and multilateral economic tools. Ex-
8 amples include the following:
9 (A) The continued purchase by the Peo-
10 ple’s Republic of China of oil from the Islamic
11 Republic of Iran despite sanctions imposed by
12 the Treasury of the United States on oil from
13 the Islamic Republic of Iran.
14 (B) The veto by the Russian Federation
15 of, and abstention by the People’s Republic of
16 China in a vote on, a United Nations Security
17 Council resolution relating to monitoring United
18 Nations Security Council-levied sanctions on the
19 Democratic People’s Republic of Korea.
20 (6) Adversaries of the United States are cooper-
21 ating multilaterally in international institutions such
22 as the United Nations and through expanded multi-
23 lateral groupings, such as the Brazil-Russia-India-
24 China-South Africa group (commonly known as
†S 2296 ES

1061
1 ‘‘BRICS’’), to isolate and erode the influence of the
2 United States.
3 (7) Such increased cooperation and alignment
4 among the People’s Republic of China, the Russian
5 Federation, the Islamic Republic of Iran, and the
6 Democratic People’s Republic of Korea, to an un-
7 precedented extent, poses a significant threat to
8 United States interests and national security.
9 (8) Such increasing alignment—
10 (A) allows each such adversary to mod-
11 ernize its military more quickly than previously
12 anticipated;
13 (B) enables unforeseen breakthroughs in
14 capabilities through the sharing among such ad-
15 versaries of critical military technologies, which
16 could erode the technological edge of the United
17 States Armed Forces;
18 (C) presents increasing challenges to strat-
19 egies of isolation or containment against such
20 individual adversaries, since the People’s Re-
21 public of China, the Russian Federation, the Is-
22 lamic Republic of Iran, and the Democratic
23 People’s Republic of Korea now provide critical
24 lifelines to each other;
†S 2296 ES

1062
1 (D) threatens the effectiveness of United
2 States economic tools, as such adversaries co-
3 operate to evade United States sanctions and
4 export controls and seek to establish alternative
5 payment mechanisms that do not require trans-
6 actions in United States dollars; and
7 (E) increases the chances of United States
8 conflict or tensions with any one of such adver-
9 saries drawing in another, thereby posing a
10 greater risk that the United States will have to
11 contend with simultaneous threats from such
12 adversaries in one or more theaters.
13
SEC. 1273. STATEMENT OF POLICY.
14 It is the policy of the United States—
15 (1) to disrupt or frustrate the most dangerous
16 aspects of cooperation between and among the Peo-
17 ple’s Republic of China, the Russian Federation, the
18 Islamic Republic of Iran, and the Democratic Peo-
19 ple’s Republic of Korea, including by using the
20 threat of sanctions and export controls, bringing
21 such cooperation to light, and sharing information
22 with United States allies and partners who may—
23 (A) share the concerns and objectives of
24 the United States; and
25 (B) have influence over such adversaries;
†S 2296 ES

1063
1 (2) to constrain such grouping from expanding
2 its footprint or capabilities across the world; and
3 (3) to prepare for the increasing likelihood that
4 the United States could face simultaneous challenges
5 or conflict with multiple such adversaries in multiple
6 theaters, including by bolstering deterrence across
7 all priority theaters.
8
SEC. 1274. TASK FORCES AND REPORTS.
9 (a) TASK FORCES ON ADVERSARY ALIGNMENT.—
10 (1) IN GENERAL.—Not later than 60 days after
11 the date of the enactment of this Act, the Secretary
12 of State, the Secretary of Defense, the Secretary of
13 the Treasury, and the Secretary of Commerce shall
14 each—
15 (A) establish a task force on adversary
16 alignment; and

SEC. 1502. STUDY ON FUTURE SPACE LAUNCH CAPACITY.
8 (a) IN GENERAL.—The Secretary of Defense shall
9 conduct a study to assess the operational capacity, infra-
10 structure, and long-term sustainability of heavy and super
11 heavy space launch sites at Cape Canaveral Space Force
12 Station and Vandenberg Space Force Base, with a focus
13 on evaluating the suitability of such sites for ongoing and
14 future missions, and to explore alternate launch locations
15 that may offer advantages with respect to mission-effi-
16 ciency, cost-effectiveness, and strategic value.
17 (b) ELEMENTS.—The study required by subsection
18 (a) shall include the following:
19 (1) An analysis of the current capacity and use
20 of the heavy and super heavy space launch sites at
21 Cape Canaveral Space Force Station and Vanden-
22 berg Space Force Base, including existing infra-
23 structure, launch frequencies, and operational effi-
24 ciency.
†S 2296 ES

1079
1 (2) A detailed evaluation of the infrastructure
2 at Cape Canaveral Space Force Station and Vanden-
3 berg Space Force Base, including transportation ac-
4 cess, environmental considerations, safety protocols,
5 the adequacy of current facilities to support heavy
6 and super heavy space launches, and the estimated
7 costs of maintaining and upgrading such infrastruc-
8 ture.
9 (3) A review of environmental regulations, poli-
10 cies, and potential impacts related to heavy and
11 super heavy space launches at Cape Canaveral Space
12 Force Station and Vandenberg Space Force Base,
13 including any limitations or challenges imposed by
14 Federal, State, or local regulations and an evalua-
15 tion of potential strategies to mitigate adverse envi-
16 ronmental effects.
17 (4) A comparative analysis of alternate loca-
18 tions for heavy and super heavy space launches, in-
19 cluding sites on Federal lands, private land partner-
20 ships, and locations outside the continental United
21 States. Such analysis shall consider geographic, envi-
22 ronmental, logistical, and regulatory factors that
23 may make alternate locations viable or advan-
24 tageous, including cost comparisons and potential
†S 2296 ES

1080
1 challenges in establishing infrastructure at such lo-
2 cations.
3 (5) An examination of the manner in which
4 Cape Canaveral Space Force Station, Vandenberg
5 Space Force Base, and any potential alternate loca-
6 tions align with national defense and space explo-
7 ration goals, including launch site proximity to key
8 orbital paths, security considerations, and redun-
9 dancy for critical missions.
10 (6) An exploration of the manner in which ad-
11 vancements in space launch technology, including re-
12 usable launch vehicles and space traffic manage-
13 ment, could influence the future demand and oper-
14 ational needs for heavy and super heavy space
15 launch sites.
16 (7) An assessment of any innovative tech-
17 nologies that could enhance the capacity or reduce
18 the environmental impact of existing or alternate
19 heavy and super heavy space launch sites.
20 (8) A financial analysis of the long-term costs
21 associated with the use and maintenance of Cape
22 Canaveral Space Force Station and Vandenberg
23 Space Force Base for heavy and super heavy space
24 launches, and the estimated costs for establishing
25 and operating alternative heavy and super heavy
†S 2296 ES

1081
1 space launch sites. Such analysis shall include con-
2 siderations applicable to Government funding, pri-

1 mission-critical space warfighting systems and operations

17 (a) AUTHORIZATION.—The Secretary of the Air

19 Force Global Strike Command, is authorized to carry out
20 a pilot program under which the Secretary may establish
21 a partnership to assess the feasibility and effectiveness of
22 implementing a low cost and repeatable resupply of inter-
23 continental ballistic missile launch facilities or control cen-
24 ters using unmanned aircraft systems.
†S 2296 ES

1102
1 (b) ELEMENTS.—If the Secretary carries out the
2 pilot program authorized under subsection (a), such pilot
3 program shall include—
4 (1) demonstration flights conducted in unre-
5 stricted airspace, including the transportation of
6 cargo, from a main Air Force Base to interconti-
7 nental ballistic missile launch facilities or control
8 centers;
9 (2) consultation with the Administrator of the
10 Federal Aviation Administration and the heads of
11 other Federal agencies, as the Secretary determines
12 appropriate, to facilitate the flights described in
13 paragraph (1);
14 (3) the use of existing technology to the great-
15 est extent possible;
16 (4) an evaluation of the potential of unmanned
17 aircraft systems to resupply intercontinental ballistic
18 missile launch facilities or control centers more effi-
19 ciently than ground-based resupply methods; and
20 (5) the incorporation, implementation, and utili-
21 zation of unmanned aircraft system service supplier
22 airspace system integration services for enhanced
23 safety, awareness, and command and control.
24 (c) TERMINATION.—The authorization to carry out
25 the pilot program under subsection (a) shall terminate on
†S 2296 ES

1103

20
COMMAND.
21 (a) IN GENERAL.—The Secretary of the Air Force,
22 acting through the Commander of the Air Force Global
23 Strike Command, shall ensure that each launch control
24 center within the 3 missile wings comprising the 20th Air
25 Force undergoes a deep cleaning of its crew capsules every
26 5 years until each such launch control center is decommis-
†S 2296 ES

1105
1 sioned by the Sentinel intercontinental ballistic missile
2 program.
3 (b) WAIVER.—The Commander of the Air Force
4 Global Strike Command may waive the deep cleaning of
5 a particular launch control center based upon conditions
6 that are unforeseen, impracticable, or due to national se-
7 curity. If such a waiver is exercised, the Commander shall
8 report to the congressional defense committees the par-
9 ticular launch control center that is waived and when such
10 launch control center is expected to be deep cleaned.
11 (c) ANNUAL REPORT.—Each fiscal year, the Sec-
12 retary of the Air Force shall submit to the congressional
13 defense committees a report that identifies each launch
14 control center that was deep cleaned during such fiscal
15 year and any additional matters of concern with respect
16 to the launch control centers.

SEC. 1532. INCLUSION OF HAWAII AND ALASKA IN PLANS
11
FOR IRON DOME FOR AMERICA.
12 (a) IN GENERAL.—In complying with Executive
13 Order 14186 (90 Fed. Reg. 8767; relating to The Iron
14 Dome for America), the Secretary of Defense shall ensure
15 that plans, reviews, strategies, and capabilities to improve
16 missile defense of the United States also include improve-

SEC. 1544. IMPROVING UNITED STATES MISSILE DEFENSE
23
CAPABILITIES.
24 (a) ACCELERATING DEVELOPMENT OF NON-KINETIC
25 CAPABILITIES.—The Secretary shall assess the funding
†S 2296 ES

1133
1 needs required to accelerate development of non-kinetic
2 capabilities to negate missile or unmanned system threats
3 prior to launch or after launch. Such capabilities may in-
4 clude cyber (offense and defense), supply chain interdic-
5 tion, artificial intelligence-driven battle management, elec-
6 tromagnetic spectrum, directed energy weapons, and high-
7 power microwave defense options capable of defeating
8 large-scale missile or unmanned system attacks.
9 (b) ACCELERATING DEVELOPMENT OF INFORMATION
10 FUSION PLATFORM USING ARTIFICIAL INTELLIGENCE TO
11 DETECT THREATS.—The Secretary shall assess the fund-
12 ing needs required to accelerate development and rapid
13 prototyping of high technology readiness level (TRL) ca-
14 pabilities in order to acquire and field an information fu-
15 sion, software-centric platform that utilizes machine learn-
16 ing and artificial intelligence technologies capable of deliv-
17 ering air, land, space, and maritime domain awareness
18 and early warning capabilities for homeland defense across
19 disparate novel and legacy systems. Such platform shall
20 employ a common data layer that can support the rapid
21 integration of new sensors and effectors across all tiers
22 of the integrated air and missile defense system.
23 (c) REQUIREMENT FOR NEXT GENERATION INTER-
24 CEPTOR FIELDING AND SILO CONSTRUCTION.—The Pro-
25 gram Manager shall, with support from the Missile De-
†S 2296 ES

1134
1 fense Agency, assess the funding needs necessary to ex-
2 pand Next Generation Interceptor production and silo con-
3 struction to field up to 80 interceptors for defense of the
4 United States. Subject to the availability of appropria-
5 tions, interceptor testing and initial fielding shall be com-
6 pleted not later than January 1, 2028.
7 (d) REQUIREMENT FOR COMBATANT COMMANDS TO
8 ACCOUNT FOR MISSILE DEFENSE INTERCEPTORS AND
9 SENSOR REQUIREMENTS IN THEIR ANNUAL RE-
10 QUESTS.—For each fiscal year beginning after the date
11 of the enactment of this Act, each commander of a com-
12 batant command shall include the terrestrial-based sensor
13 requirements, space-based sensor requirements, and
14 counter-unmanned system requirements of the combatant
15 command of the commander in the supporting information
16 for the Department of Defense submitted along with the
17 budget of the President to Congress for such fiscal year
18 pursuant to section 1105(a) of title 31, United States
19 Code.
20 (e) ACCELERATING DEVELOPMENT OF GLIDE PHASE
21 INTERCEPTOR.—The Program Manager shall assess the
22 funding needs required to accelerate development of the
23 Glide Phase Interceptor to defend against hypersonic
24 threats to the United States homeland.
†S 2296 ES

1135
1 (f) ACCELERATING PRODUCTION AND FIELDING OF
2 GROUND MOBILE INTERCEPTORS.—The Program Man-
3 ager shall assess the funding needs required to accelerate
4 the production and fielding of ground mobile interceptors
5 and radars for forward deployment and homeland defense
6 as the Secretary and President consider appropriate.
7 (g) ACCELERATING DEVELOPMENT OF RESILIENT
8 POSITIONING, NAVIGATION, AND TIMING FOR MISSILE
9 DEFENSE SYSTEMS.—The Program Manager shall assess
10 the funding needs required to accelerate development and
11 fielding of resilient positioning, navigation, and timing
12 (PNT) solutions that can operate effectively in ground po-
13 sitioning system (GPS)-denied environments. Such solu-
14 tions may include the following:
15 (1) Quantum-enhanced inertial navigation and
16 atomic clock technologies to maintain continuous po-
17 sitioning, navigation, and timing functionality in
18 ground positioning system-degraded or denied sce-
19 narios.
20 (2) Enhanced terrestrial-based navigation sys-
21 tems for greater assured positioning in ground posi-
22 tioning system-contested environments.
23 (3) Robust data fusion techniques that inte-
24 grate multiple positioning, navigation, and timing
25 sources, such as radar-based tracking, vision-aided
†S 2296 ES

1136
1 navigation, and low-Earth orbit (LEO) signals, to
2 sustain operational effectiveness during electronic
3 warfare (EW) attacks or cyber intrusions.
4 (4) Commercially available, field-proven alter-
5 native positioning, navigation, and timing solutions
6 that leverage advanced sensor fusion, artificial intel-
7 ligence-driven error correction, and resilient posi-
8 tioning, navigation, and timing processing to provide
9 assured navigation for mobile and fixed defense plat-
10 forms, including those currently deployed in
11 hypersonic tracking and integrated air and missile
12 defense applications.
13 (h) ACCELERATING DEVELOPMENT AND FIELDING
14 OF LOW-COST SCALABLE INTERCEPTOR.—The Program
15 Manager shall assess the funding needs required to accel-
16 erate development, test, and fielding of a low-cost scalable
17 interceptor that can augment existing production lines and
18 provide resiliency to the integrated air and missile defense
19 system.
20 (i) ACCELERATING DEVELOPMENT AND DEPLOY-
21 MENT OF SPACE-BASED SENSORS AND INTERCEPTORS.—
22 The Program Manager shall assess the funding needs re-
23 quired to accelerate development and deployment of pro-

15 essary to ensure an individual who has been retired or oth-
16 erwise separated from service in the Armed Forces or em-
17 ployment with the Department of Defense for a period of
18 not more than 5 years and who was eligible to access clas-
19 sified information on the day before the individual retired
20 or otherwise separated, will be granted eligibility by the
21 Secretary to access classified information as long as—
22 (1) there is no indication the individual no
23 longer satisfies the standards established for access
24 to classified information;
†S 2296 ES

1145
1 (2) the individual certifies in writing to an ap-
2 propriate security professional that there has been
3 no change in the relevant information provided for

5 and

7 favorable information.

18 to the assessment conducted pursuant to paragraph
19 (1).

1 intelligence assessment of the electromagnetic order of

6 ‘‘(1) the exercise does not require—
7 ‘‘(A) a demonstration of electronic warfare
8 capabilities; or
9 ‘‘(B) a militarily significant threat from
10 electronic warfare attack; or
11 ‘‘(2) the integration of offensive and defensive
12 electronic warfare capabilities into the exercise is
13 cost prohibitive or not technically feasible based on
14 the overall goals of the exercise.
15 ‘‘(d) BRIEFING.—Concurrent with the submission of

4 fensive electronic warfare capabilities were inte-

6 ‘‘(B) an evaluation and assessment of the
7 exercise to determine the impact of the oppos-
8 ing force on the participants in the exercise, in-
9 cluding—
10 ‘‘(i) joint lessons learned;
11 ‘‘(ii) high interest training issues; and
12 ‘‘(iii) high interest training require-

14 ‘‘(C) an assessment as to whether offensive
15 and defensive electronic warfare capabilities

10 ture joint use of dynamic spectrum sharing tech-
11 nologies.
12 ‘‘(5) The feasibility and advisability of estab-
13 lishing designated virtual testing ranges so that op-
14 erators can develop tactics, techniques, and proce-
15 dures for dynamic spectrum sharing technologies.’’.

18
BY DEPARTMENT OF DEFENSE.

20 amended by adding at the end the following new sub-

22 ‘‘(c) LIMITATION ON MODIFICATION OF SPEC-
23 TRUM.—(1) Until the earlier of September 30, 2034, or
24 the date on which the Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of
25 Staff certifies to the congressional defense committees
†S 2296 ES

1162
1 that dynamic spectrum sharing (as defined in the Emerg-

SEC. 1603. STRATEGY FOR DETERRENCE AGAINST
5
CYBERATTACKS AGAINST DEFENSE CRITICAL
6
INFRASTRUCTURE OF THE UNITED STATES.
7 (a) IN GENERAL.—The Secretary of Defense shall,
8 in coordination with the Assistant Secretary of Defense
9 for Cyber Policy, the Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of
10 Staff, the Commander of United States Cyber Command,
11 and the Deputy Assistant Secretary of Defense for De-
12 fense Continuity and Mission Assurance, develop a strat-
13 egy and a list of various courses of action across the spec-
14 trum of military capabilities to create a credible deterrence
15 against cyberspace attacks and posturing for future such
16 attacks against United States defense critical infrastruc-
17 ture.
18 (b) STRATEGY.—
19 (1) IN GENERAL.—The Secretary shall ensure
20 that the strategy required by subsection (a)—
21 (A) includes an evaluation of how to deter
22 actions of adversaries in cyberspace across the
23 full spectrum of offensive planning and action;
24 and
†S 2296 ES

1170
1 (B) outlines a range of options available
2 for the Department to demonstrate a credible
3 deterrence through cost imposing courses of ac-
4 tion.
5 (2) ELEMENTS.—The strategy required by sub-
6 section (a) shall incorporate the following elements:
7 (A) A comprehensive assessment of adver-
8 sary cyber capabilities and intent regarding de-
9 fense critical infrastructure attacks.
10 (B) Identification of what specific adver-
11 sary cyber capabilities and actor’s actions under
12 this strategy seeks to deter.
13 (C) Methodology and classification of types
14 of targets to hold at risk and what actions
15 would be necessary to impose costs at different
16 levels of escalation.
17 (D) An assessment of the capabilities and
18 any related requirement gaps to create the
19 needed effects against these categories of tar-
20 gets and their relative impact to deterrence and
21 escalation.
22 (E) An evaluation of the role of offensive
23 cyber operations in combination with, as well as
24 independent of, other means of military capa-
25 bilities in creating an effective deterrent, and
†S 2296 ES

1171
1 an assessment of the current capability and
2 gaps in capability needed to successfully con-
3 duct these offensive cyber operations.
4 (F) An assessment of policy and authori-
5 ties in effect with respect to holding adversary
6 targets at risk and recommendations for modi-
7 fications to enable effective deterrence and
8 managed escalation.
9 (G) Evaluation of reveal and conceal cri-
10 teria and methodology to demonstrate the
11 United States capability of imposing costs while
12 preserving operational security.
13 (H) Framework for integration of inter-
14 agency partners, as well as allies and partners,
15 industry, and academia, to enhance deterrence.
16 (3) DEADLINE.—The Secretary shall complete
17 the development of the strategy required by sub-
18 section (a) on or before December 1, 2026.
19 (c) COURSES OF ACTION.—
20 (1) IN GENERAL.—The list of various courses
21 of action required under subsection (a) shall include
22 a list of military alternatives, guided by the strategy
23 developed under such subsection, using the full
24 range of military capabilities, including offensive
25 cyber operations that actively impose or threaten to
†S 2296 ES

1172
1 impose costs on an adversary to create a credible de-
2 terrence. The courses of action shall be organized for
3 competition, crisis, and conflict.
4 (2) DEADLINE.—Not later than June 1, 2026,
5 the Secretary shall complete the development of the
6 list of various courses of action required by sub-
7 section (a).
8 (d) BRIEFINGS AND SUBMITTAL TO CONGRESS.—
9 (1) INTERIM BRIEFING.—Not later than March
10 1, 2026, the Secretary shall provide to the congres-
11 sional defense committees an interim briefing on the
12 strategy required under subsection (a).
13 (2) FINAL BRIEFING AND SUBMITTAL.—Not
14 later than June 1, 2026, the Secretary shall—
15 (A) provide to the congressional defense
16 committees a briefing on the strategy developed
17 under subsection (a) and the list of various
18 courses of action developed under such sub-
19 section; and
20 (B) submit to the congressional defense
21 committees a report on such strategy and such
22 list of various courses of action.
23 (e) DEFINITIONS.—In this section:
24 (1) The term ‘‘defense critical infrastructure’’
25 has the meaning given that term ‘‘critical infrastruc-
†S 2296 ES

1173
1 ture of the Department of Defense’’ in section
2 1650(e) of the National Defense Authorization Act
3 for Fiscal Year 2017 (Public Law 114–328; 10
4 U.S.C. 2224 note).
5 (2) The term ‘‘imposing costs’’ means actions
6 taken against adversaries that result in economic,
7 diplomatic, informational, or military consequences
8 significant enough to change the adversary’s behav-
9 ior or calculations regarding cyberspace operations
10 against the United States.

SEC. 1610C. PROGRAM FOR TALENT MANAGEMENT OF
4
CYBER PERSONNEL THROUGH ACTIVE AND
5
RESERVE TRANSITIONING.
6 (a) PROGRAM ESTABLISHED.—The Secretary of De-
7 fense, as part of the Defense Cyber Workforce Frame-
8 work, shall design and implement a program to support
9 active management of cyber talent transitioning to the re-
10 serve cyber force by May 1, 2026.
11 (b) ELEMENTS.—The program as required under
12 subsection (a) shall include the following elements:
13 (1) The ability to track, reskill, and upskill
14 transitioning active-duty cyber personnel and critical
15 enablers from the Cyber Mission Force (CMF) for
16 potential retention in the reserve component to meet
17 emerging cyber mission demands.
18 (2) The ability to conduct transparent and time
19 efficient means to recruit transitioning, fully quali-
20 fied, and in good standing active-duty cyber mission
21 force personnel and cyber enabling forces deemed
22 necessary by the United States Cyber Command
23 (USCYBERCOM) and its subordinate commands.
24 (3) Establishment of a centralized resource in
25 the Department to—
†S 2296 ES

1194
1 (A) provide incentive services as a reten-
2 tion tool to aid transitioning CMF personnel in
3 navigating the active to reserve component per-
4 sonnel system across the military services;
5 (B) identify and advertise vacancies in re-
6 serve cyber units; and
7 (C) enable transition to civilian occupa-
8 tions (specifically with critical need strategic in-
9 dustries and critical infrastructure providers)
10 that could include mentorship, employment
11 counseling, and education focused on critical
12 high demand/low density cyber skills.
13 (4) The ability to expand such services to re-
14 lated areas, such as cyber auxiliary forces or direct
15 commissioning programs directed towards cyber
16 forces.
17 (c) BRIEFING.—Not later than June 1, 2026, the
18 Secretary of Defense shall provide a briefing to the Com-
19 mittees on Armed Services of the Senate and the House
20 of Representatives on the establishment of the program
21 required under subsection (a), including—
22 (1) the establishment of this program;
23 (2) an assessment of resourcing needs for the
24 program across the future years defense program;
25 and
†S 2296 ES

1195
1 (3) identification of metrics or other assessment
2 capabilities to determine the impact on retention of
3 CMF forces and enabling cyber forces as part of a
4 total force strategy.

6 shall establish a pilot program to assess the feasibility and
7 advisability of paying skill incentive pay or a skill pro-
8 ficiency bonus under section 353 of title 37, United States
9 Code, to members of the Cyber Mission Force working for
10 the United States Cyber Command that will expire on
11 September 30, 2030.

9

10
FOR CYBER THREATS.
11 (a) ASSESSMENT REQUIRED.—The Secretary of De-
12 fense shall conduct a comprehensive assessment of the fea-

15 (1) to remediate all weapon system platforms
16 that do not currently have capabilities that satisfy
17 requirements for weapon system platform cybersecu-
18 rity through automated, real-time monitoring for
19 threat detection and mitigation; and

21 (A) identifying and prioritizing weapon
22 systems lacking real-time monitoring for self-
23 protection capabilities;

25 and minimum cybersecurity standards for real-
†S 2296 ES

1200
1 time protection across different categories of
2 weapon systems;

8 process to ensure deployed solutions effectively
9 mitigate identified cybersecurity risks; and
10 (E) establishing a governance structure for
11 ongoing maintenance, updates, and operational
12 support of implemented capabilities.

14 to subsection (a) shall include the following:

20 data from such applications.

25 funding plan that includes—
†S 2296 ES

1201

9 such applications; and

SEC. 1614. FRAMEWORK FOR INTEGRATION OF INFORMA-
5
TION TECHNOLOGY TECHNICAL DEBT AS-
6
SESSMENT INTO ANNUAL BUDGET PROCESS.
7 (a) FRAMEWORK DEVELOPMENT.—Not later than
8 September 1, 2026, the Secretary of Defense shall, in co-
9 ordination with the Chief Information Officer of the De-
10 partment of Defense, the Secretaries of the military de-
11 partments, and the Chief Information Officers of the mili-
12 tary departments, develop a framework for the integration
13 of technical debt assessment, tracking, and management
14 into existing Department of Defense processes for infor-
15 mation technology investment decisions and budget jus-
16 tification materials.
17 (b) TECHNICAL DEBT DEFINITION.—The Secretary
18 of Defense shall direct a comprehensive reevaluation of the
19 Department’s current definition of ‘‘technical debt’’ and
20 develop a categorization framework that adequately re-
21 flects different types of technical debt, including applica-
22 tion, physical infrastructure, architecture, and documenta-
23 tion components.
24 (c) FRAMEWORK COMPONENTS.—
†S 2296 ES

1211
1 (1) INTEGRATION REQUIREMENT.—The Sec-
2 retary of Defense shall ensure the framework devel-
3 oped under subsection (a) provides for integration of
4 technical debt considerations into existing Depart-
5 ment management processes and structures relating
6 to resourcing and programmatic decisions for exist-
7 ing or proposed information technology systems,
8 services, or related programs of record.
9 (2) METRICS.—The framework developed under
10 subsection (a) shall include—
11 (A) baseline measurement for technical
12 debt for a specific technology or program;
13 (B) objectives for technical debt reduction;
14 (C) consolidated metrics for Department-
15 wide use; and
16 (D) outcome-based metrics for assessing
17 operational and financial impacts.
18 (3) PROCESS INTEGRATION.—The framework
19 developed under subsection (a) shall utilize existing
20 governance structures for overseeing information
21 technology investments.
22 (4) MINIMUM REQUIREMENTS.—The framework
23 developed under subsection (a) shall—
24 (A) establish methods for identifying and
25 evaluating technical debt;
†S 2296 ES

1212
1 (B) integrate technical debt management
2 into the planning, programming, budgeting, and
3 execution process, as well as information tech-
4 nology governance bodies;
5 (C) establish prioritization approaches
6 based on mission impact;
7 (D) develop mechanisms for gap identifica-
8 tion; and
9 (E) define organizational responsibilities
10 for remediating assessed technical debt of a
11 program or system.
12 (5) IMPLEMENTATION.—The Secretary of De-
13 fense shall implement the framework developed
14 under subsection (a) not later than October 1, 2026,
15 to support the planning, programming, and process
16 for the budget justification materials to be submitted
17 to Congress in support of the Department, as sub-
18 mitted with the budget of the President for fiscal
19 year 2027 under section 1105(a) of title 31, United
20 States Code.
21 (d) BUDGET MATERIALS.—
22 (1) JUSTIFICATION REQUIREMENTS.—Begin-
23 ning with the fiscal year 2027 budget request, the
24 Secretary of Defense shall ensure that, for each fis-
25 cal year, the budget justification materials to be sub-
†S 2296 ES

1213
1 mitted to Congress in support of the budget of the
2 Department (as submitted with the budget of the
3 President under section 1105(a) of title 31, United
4 States Code) include—
5 (A) technical debt status assessments;
6 (B) planned remediation investments;
7 (C) risk assessments of investment gaps;
8 and

10 ities.
