SEC. 1615. MISSION INFRASTRUCTURE RESILIENCE TASK
6
FORCE.
7 (a) ESTABLISHMENT.—
8 (1) IN GENERAL.—Not later than 180 days
9 after the date of the enactment of this Act, the Sec-
10 retary of Defense shall establish a task force to sup-
11 port the assessment of vulnerabilities to defense crit-
12 ical infrastructure necessary for the execution of ex-
13 isting defense operational and contingency plans.
14 (2) DESIGNATION.—The task force established
15 pursuant to paragraph (1) shall be known as the
16 ‘‘Mission Infrastructure Resilience Task Force’’ (in
17 this section the ‘‘Task Force’’).
18 (b) PURPOSES.—The purposes of the Task Force
19 shall be—
20 (1) to conduct assessments and analysis of use
21 case-based mission threads to comprehensively iden-
22 tify, develop, and operationalize the full spectrum of
23 capabilities required to protect and maintain defense
24 critical infrastructure; and
†S 2296 ES

1215
1 (2) to build and integrate the necessary re-
2 sources, technologies, communication systems, tac-
3 tics, techniques, and procedures, personnel with ap-
4 propriate authorities, and exercise programs to en-
5 sure efficient and effective response when critical in-
6 frastructure supporting military operations and con-
7 tingencies is threatened, degraded, or disrupted.
8 (c) COMPOSITION.—
9 (1) CHAIR.—The Task Force shall be chaired
10 by a representative from the Department of Defense
11 Cyber Defense Command.
12 (2) MEMBERSHIP.—The Task Force shall in-
13 clude representatives from the following:
14 (A) United States Cyber Command.
15 (B) The Office of the Deputy Assistant
16 Secretary of Defense for Defense Continuity
17 and Mission Assurance.
18 (C) The Joint Warfighting Analysis Cen-
19 ter.
20 (D) The Defense Advanced Research
21 Projects Agency.
22 (E) The Critical Infrastructure Defense
23 Analysis Center.
24 (F) The Air Force Cyber Resiliency Office
25 of Control Systems program.
†S 2296 ES

1216
1 (G) The energy, installations and environ-
2 ment, or civil engineering organizations of the
3 military departments.
4 (H) The Army Corps of Engineers Engi-
5 neering Research and Development Center.
6 (I) Each of the geographic and functional
7 combatant commands, on an as-needed basis.
8 (d) TASKS.—The Task Force shall—
9 (1) conduct assessments and analysis of use
10 case-based mission threads associated with defense
11 operational and contingency plans, including through
12 pilot programs, tabletop exercises, or studies that
13 identify infrastructure dependencies and organiza-
14 tional transition points where operational respon-
15 sibilities transfer between entities;
16 (2) identify vulnerabilities and capability gaps
17 in mission-critical infrastructure and determine—
18 (A) the resources, authorities, technologies,
19 partnerships with external and nongovernment
20 entities, and funding necessary to address such
21 vulnerabilities and gaps; and
22 (B) the designation of lead organizations
23 responsible for remediation activities and asso-
24 ciated costs;
†S 2296 ES

1217
1 (3) develop broad-based solutions to address
2 gaps identified under paragraph (2), including—
3 (A) establishment of communication path-
4 ways;
5 (B) development of tools and technologies;
6 (C) implementation of visualization and
7 analytic programs; and
8 (D) integration of unique capabilities, such
9 as those provided by the National Guard;
10 (4) assign organizational leads for remediation
11 of specific gaps and vulnerabilities and develop com-
12 prehensive plans to address such gaps, including
13 identification of funding and budgeting requirements
14 necessary for successful remediation efforts;
15 (5) monitor and assess the progress of remedi-
16 ation efforts and identify process improvements and
17 solutions to address common deficiencies across mul-
18 tiple remediation activities;
19 (6) develop and conduct exercises based on like-
20 ly operational scenarios—
21 (A) to validate the effectiveness of remedi-
22 ation efforts; and
23 (B) to identify additional deficiencies or
24 vulnerabilities requiring remediation;
†S 2296 ES

1218
1 (7) establish a framework for readiness assess-
2 ments to provide installation commanders and com-
3 batant commanders with visibility into the status of
4 mission infrastructure resilience capabilities within
5 their respective areas of responsibility;
6 (8) conduct targeted analysis of specific topics
7 as directed by the Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of
8 Staff or the Secretary of Defense; and
9 (9) perform such other duties as the Secretary
10 of Defense may determine to be necessary and ap-
11 propriate.
12 (e) TRANSITION TO PERMANENT ORGANIZATION.—
13 (1) TRANSITION PLAN REQUIRED.—The Task

17 (2) SUBMISSION TO SECRETARY OF DE-
18 FENSE.—The transition plan required under para-
19 graph (1) shall be developed and presented to the
20 Secretary of Defense not later than 180 days prior
21 to the termination date specified in subsection (f).
22 (3) BRIEFINGS TO CONGRESS.—Not later than

25 tember 30, 2033, the Secretary shall provide to the
†S 2296 ES

1219
1 congressional defense committees a briefing on the
2 transition plan required under paragraph (1).
3 (f) TERMINATION.—The Task Force shall terminate
4 on September 30, 2030.

SEC. 1620D. AUDIT AND UPDATED GUIDANCE TO REDUCE,
5
MITIGATE, OR ELIMINATE RISK FROM CLOUD
6
COMPUTING CONTRACTS WITH FOREIGN EX-
7
POSURE.
8 (a) REVIEW OF FOREIGN EXPOSURE FROM DEPART-
9 MENT OF DEFENSE CLOUD COMPUTING CONTRACTS.—
10 (1) AUDIT REQUIRED.—The Inspector General
11 of the Department of Defense shall conduct an audit
12 of cloud computing contracts for the Department of
13 Defense to assess the risk of exposure of sensitive
14 information, including data, systems architecture de-
15 tails, procedures, or other controlled unclassified in-
16 formation, as a result of policies that may have al-
17 lowed computer scientists or engineers from foreign
18 countries of concern to access proposed software up-
19 dates to underlying cloud computing infrastructure
20 or operating systems.
21 (2) ELEMENTS.—The audit conducted pursuant
22 to paragraph (1) shall cover the following:
23 (A) Determination of how many cloud
24 computing contracts the Department has that
25 may be or have been supported by employees lo-
†S 2296 ES

1241
1 cated in foreign countries of concern or are citi-
2 zens of foreign countries of concern.
3 (B) Identification of policies or clauses in
4 such cloud computing contracts that allow for
5 the use of so called ‘‘digital escorts’’, computer
6 scientists, or engineers from foreign countries
7 of concern.
8 (C) Assessment of agreements in place
9 that use so called ‘‘digital escorts’’ to provide
10 oversight to employees from foreign countries of
11 concern, including identification of instances in
12 which such authorities were used during the pe-
13 riod beginning on January 1, 2022, and ending
14 on the date of the enactment of this Act.
15 (D) Assessment of the national security
16 risks that stem from cloud computing contracts
17 that use labor from foreign countries of con-
18 cern.
19 (E) Recommendations on ways to reduce,
20 mitigate, or eliminate risk from initiatives such
21 as so called ‘‘digital escorting’’, or the use of
22 computer scientists or engineers from foreign
23 countries of concern.
24 (3) REPORT TO CONGRESS.—Not later than
25 July 1, 2026, the Inspector General shall submit to
†S 2296 ES

1242
1 the Committee on Armed Services of the Senate and
2 the Committee on Armed Services of the House of
3 Representatives a report setting forth the findings of
4 the Inspector General with respect to the audit con-
5 ducted pursuant to paragraph (1).
6 (b) GUIDANCE TO REDUCE, MITIGATE, OR ELIMI-
7 NATE RISK.—
8 (1) GUIDANCE.—Based on the audit conducted
9 under subsection (a), the Secretary shall issue new
10 guidance to reduce, mitigate, or eliminate risk to
11 Department data or cloud computing infrastructure
12 from foreign countries of concern.
13 (2) REQUIREMENTS.—The guidance issued pur-
14 suant to paragraph (1) shall—
15 (A) restrict the use of personnel from for-
16 eign countries of concern to support Depart-
17 ment information technology systems; and
18 (B) require disclosure to the congressional
19 defense committees if the Secretary finds a De-
20 partment information technology system is
21 maintained by personnel from a foreign country
22 of concern.

22 to highly capable artificial intelligence and machine learn-

24 (b) FORUM FOR ENGAGEMENT.—The public-private
25 partnership body established under subsection (a) shall
†S 2296 ES

1244
1 serve as a forum for engagement between the Department

9 (1) convene regular engagements to discuss cy-
10 bersecurity and physical security threats and
11 vulnerabilities specific to highly capable artificial in-
12 telligence and machine learning systems, with a

18 partment and commercial industry to protect artifi-
19 cial intelligence and machine learning systems;
20 (3) promote collaborative threat intelligence
21 sharing between the Department and commercial en-
22 tities, with particular attention to vulnerabilities in
23 artificial intelligence and machine learning systems
24 used in critical infrastructure, defense operations,
25 and sensitive national security functions; and
†S 2296 ES

2 and physical security policy enhancements aimed at
3 safeguarding artificial intelligence and machine
4 learning technologies from state-sponsored cyber at-
5 tacks and report findings and policy recommenda-

20 Projects Agency;

24 (I) such other entities in the Department
25 of Defense and military departments with re-
†S 2296 ES

1246
1 sponsibilities for cybersecurity or artificial intel-
2 ligence systems as the Assistant Secretary con-
3 siders relevant;
4 (2) commercial industry companies with exper-
5 tise in highly capable artificial intelligence and ma-

SEC. 1622. DIGITAL SANDBOX ENVIRONMENTS FOR ARTIFI-
17
CIAL INTELLIGENCE.
18 (a) REQUIREMENT TO ESTABLISH.—Not later than
19 April 1, 2026, the Secretary of Defense shall, acting
20 through the Chief Digital and Artificial Intelligence Offi-
21 cer and the Chief Information Officer of the Department
22 of Defense, establish a task force on artificial intelligence
23 sandbox environments (in this section referred to as the
24 ‘‘Task Force’’).
†S 2296 ES

1248
1 (b) PURPOSE.—The Task Force shall identify, co-
2 ordinate, and advance Department-wide efforts to develop
3 and deploy virtual environments necessary to support arti-
4 ficial intelligence experimentation, training, familiariza-
5 tion, and development across the Department of Defense
6 enterprise. These virtual environments, known as an ‘‘arti-
7 ficial intelligence sandbox’’, shall—
8 (1) provide capability for personnel with varied
9 technical proficiency, from novice users to experi-
10 enced practitioners;
11 (2) enable the building, training, evaluation,
12 and deployment of artificial intelligence models;
13 (3) facilitate familiarity with and utilization of
14 existing artificial intelligence capabilities; and
15 (4) accelerate the responsible adoption of artifi-
16 cial intelligence across the Department.
17 (c) CO-CHAIRS.—The Task Force shall be co-chaired
18 by the Chief Digital and Artificial Intelligence Officer and
19 the Chief Information Officer.
20 (d) COMPOSITION.—The Task Force shall be com-
21 posed of—
22 (1) the chief artificial intelligence officers of the
23 military departments, or in the absence of such posi-
24 tion, the individual responsible for leading artificial
25 intelligence efforts within each military department;
†S 2296 ES

1249
1 (2) the chief information officers of the military
2 departments;
3 (3) the chief artificial intelligence officers of the
4 combatant commands and joint staff, or in the ab-
5 sence of such position, the individual responsible for
6 leading artificial intelligence efforts within each com-
7 batant commands;
8 (4) the chief information officers of the combat-
9 ant commands, and joint staff, or in the absence of
10 such position, the individual responsible for leading
11 information technology efforts within each combat-
12 ant commands;
13 (5) the Directors for Command, Control, Com-
14 munications, and Computers/Cyber (J6) of the com-
15 batant commands, or their designees;
16 (6) the Director for Command, Control, Com-
17 munications, and Computers/Cyber (J6) of the Joint
18 Staff, or their designee; and
19 (7) such other officials of the Department as
20 the co-chairs of the Task Force consider appro-
21 priate.
22 (e) FUNCTIONS.—The Task Force shall—
23 (1) identify and consolidate common require-
24 ments with respect to artificial intelligence sandbox
25 environments across the Department, including re-
†S 2296 ES

1250
1 quirements relating to interfaces for users with vary-
2 ing technical expertise, computational resources and
3 infrastructure, pre-trained models and datasets, and
4 educational and training materials;
5 (2) identify, inventory, and ensure the avail-
6 ability of existing solutions and technical documenta-
7 tion, including machine-readable documents, ref-
8 erence architectures, and user guides;
9 (3) publish an analysis matching common re-
10 quirements identified under paragraph (1) with ex-
11 isting solutions identified under paragraph (2);
12 (4) utilize existing Department mechanisms to
13 achieve efficiencies through enterprise licenses and
14 contracts;
15 (5) identify and, where possible, streamline au-
16 thority to operate approvals for each element of
17 common artificial intelligence sandbox environment
18 architectures; and
19 (6) publish guidance on the appropriate use of
20 artificial intelligence sandbox environments for users
21 at all skill levels.
22 (f) BRIEFING.—Not later than August 1, 2026, the
23 co-chairs of the Task Force shall provide to the congres-
24 sional defense committees a briefing on the goals and ob-
25 jectives of the Task Force.
†S 2296 ES

1251
1 (g) TERMINATION.—The Task Force shall terminate
2 on January 1, 2030.
3 (h) DEFINITIONS.—In this section:
4 (1) The term ‘‘artificial intelligence’’ has the
5 meaning given such term in section 238(g) of the
6 John S. McCain National Defense Authorization Act
7 for Fiscal Year 2019 (Public Law 115–232; 10
8 U.S.C. note prec. 4061).
9 (2) The term ‘‘artificial intelligence sandbox en-
10 vironment’’ means a secure, isolated computing envi-
11 ronment that enables users with varying levels of
12 technical expertise to access artificial intelligence
13 tools, models, and capabilities for the purposes of ex-
14 perimentation, training, testing, and development
15 without affecting operational systems or requiring
16 specialized technical knowledge to operate.
17 (3) The term ‘‘authority to operate’’ means the
18 official management decision given by a senior orga-
19 nizational official to authorize operation of an infor-
20 mation system and to explicitly accept the risk to or-
21 ganizational operations and assets, individuals, other
22 organizations, and the United States based on the
23 implementation of an agreed-upon set of security
24 controls, as defined in Committee on National Secu-
†S 2296 ES

1 rity Systems Instruction 4009, or successor docu-
2 ment.

SEC. 1623. ARTIFICIAL INTELLIGENCE MODEL ASSESSMENT
4
AND OVERSIGHT.
5 (a) CROSS-FUNCTIONAL TEAM FOR ARTIFICIAL IN-
6 TELLIGENCE MODEL ASSESSMENT AND OVERSIGHT.—
7 (1) ESTABLISHMENT.—The Secretary of De-
8 fense shall, in accordance with section 911 of the
9 National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year
10 2017 (Public Law 114–328; 10 U.S.C. 111 note),
11 establish a cross-functional team for artificial intel-
12 ligence model assessment and oversight (in this sec-
13 tion referred to as the ‘‘Cross-Functional Team’’).
14 (2) PURPOSE.—The purpose of the Cross-Func-
15 tional Team is to develop a standardized assessment
16 framework and governance structure to evaluate,
17 oversee, and facilitate collaboration on artificial in-
18 telligence models employed by the Department of
19 Defense.
20 (3) COMPOSITION.—
21 (A) LEADERSHIP.—The Chief Digital and
22 Artificial Intelligence Officer shall lead the
23 Cross-Functional Team.
†S 2296 ES

1253
1 (B) MEMBERSHIP.—The Secretary shall
2 ensure that the Cross-Functional Team includes
3 representatives from—
4 (i) the Office of the Chief Information
5 Officer;
6 (ii) the chief artificial intelligence offi-
7 cers of the military departments, or in the
8 absence of such position, the individual re-
9 sponsible for leading artificial intelligence
10 efforts within each military department;
11 (iii) the chief information officers of
12 the military departments;
13 (iv) the chief artificial intelligence of-
14 ficers of the combatant commands and the
15 Joint Staff, or in the absence of such posi-
16 tion, the individuals responsible for leading
17 artificial intelligence efforts within each
18 such command and the Joint Staff;
19 (v) the chief information officers of
20 the combatant commands and the Joint
21 Staff, or in the absence of such position,
22 the individuals responsible for leading in-
23 formation technology efforts within each
24 such command and the Joint Staff; and
†S 2296 ES

1254
1 (vi) such other components as the
2 Secretary determines appropriate.
3 (4) DUTIES.—The duties of the Cross-Func-
4 tional Team are as follows:
5 (A) To develop a standardized assessment
6 framework for artificial intelligence models cur-
7 rently used by the Department of Defense.
8 (B) To establish Department-wide guide-
9 lines for artificial intelligence model evaluation
10 for future models being considered for Depart-
11 ment use.
12 (C) To develop governance structures for
13 model development, testing, and deployment.
14 (D) To identify appropriate assessment
15 levels based on use case-based risk.
16 (E) To establish mechanisms for cross-
17 component collaboration.
18 (F) To develop processes for use case sub-
19 mission, review, and approval.
20 (5) FRAMEWORK CONTENT.—The assessment
21 framework developed under subsection (b) shall ad-
22 dress—
23 (A) model performance standards;
24 (B) development documentation require-
25 ments;
†S 2296 ES

1255
1 (C) testing procedures;
2 (D) ethical principles compliance;
3 (E) assessment methodologies and validity
4 periods;
5 (F) security requirements and compliance
6 regulations, including the Federal Risk and Au-
7 thorization Management Program; and
8 (G) such other elements as the Cross-
9 Functional Team determines appropriate.
10 (b) FUNCTIONAL LEADS FOR ARTIFICIAL INTEL-
11 LIGENCE APPLICATION.—
12 (1) DESIGNATION.—The Secretary shall des-
13 ignate such Department organizations as the Sec-
14 retary considers appropriate to serve as functional
15 leads for artificial intelligence applications.
16 (2) SELECTION CRITERIA.—In designating
17 functional leads under paragraph (1), the Secretary
18 shall consider—
19 (A) subject matter expertise;
20 (B) equities in the functional area; and
21 (C) capability to establish assessment
22 standards.
23 (3) CDAO RESPONSIBILITIES.—The Chief Dig-
24 ital and Artificial Intelligence Officer shall—
†S 2296 ES

1256
1 (A) serve as the functional lead for busi-
2 ness systems with artificial intelligence models;
3 and
4 (B) provide Department-wide guidance on
5 commercial artificial intelligence models.
6 (c) ASSESSMENTS OF MAJOR ARTIFICIAL INTEL-
7 LIGENCE SYSTEMS.—Not later than January 1, 2028, the
8 Secretary shall, using the standard assessment framework
9 developed by the Cross-Functional Team under subsection
10 (a)(2), assess all major artificial intelligence systems of
11 the Department.
12 (d) ADMINISTRATION.—
13 (1) IN GENERAL.—In administering this sec-
14 tion, the Secretary shall ensure the completion of
15 each of the following milestones:
16 (A) The Cross-Functional Team is estab-
17 lished in accordance with subsection (a) on or
18 before June 1, 2026.
19 (B) The functional leads for artificial intel-
20 ligence application are designated in accordance
21 with subsection (b) on or before January 1,
22 2027.
23 (C) The Cross-Function Team completes
24 development of the standardized assessment
†S 2296 ES

1257
1 framework and governance structure required
2 by subsection (a)(2) on or before June 1, 2027.
3 (D) Initial assessments of major artificial
4 intelligence systems are conducted under sub-
5 section (c) and completed on or before January
6 1, 2028.
7 (2) CONGRESSIONAL BRIEFING.—Not later than
8 30 days after the completion of each milestone set
9 forth under paragraph (1), the Secretary shall pro-
10 vide the congressional defense committees a briefing
11 on the status of the Secretary in administering this
12 section.
13 (e) SUNSET AND TRANSITION.—
14 (1) SUNSET.—The Cross-Functional Team
15 shall terminate on December 31, 2030.
16 (2) TRANSITION.—Not later than June 30,
17 2030, the Secretary shall designate an organization
18 to succeed the Cross-Functional Team and develop
19 a plan to transfer the duties of the Cross-Functional
20 Team specified by subsection (a)(4) to such suc-
21 cessor organization.
22 (3) REPORT ON ACTIVITIES OF SUCCESSOR OR-
23 GANIZATION.—Not later than one year after the
24 date on which the Cross-Functional Team is termi-
25 nated and not less frequently than once each year
†S 2296 ES

1258
1 thereafter until the date that is three years after the

3 nated, the Secretary shall submit to the congres-
4 sional defense committees an annual report on the

6 the duties of the Cross-Functional Team were trans-
7 ferred.
8 (f) DEFINITIONS.—In this section:
9 (1) The term ‘‘artificial intelligence’’ has the
10 meaning given in section 238(g) of the John S.
11 McCain National Defense Authorization Act for Fis-
12 cal Year 2019 (Public Law 115–232; 10 U.S.C. note
13 prec. 4061).
14 (2) The term ‘‘functional area’’ refers to a spe-
15 cialized domain of artificial intelligence application
16 within the Department where models are developed,
17 evaluated, and employed for similar use cases under
18 comparable operational conditions. Examples of
19 functional areas may include decision support sys-
20 tems, business systems, avionics, cybersecurity, intel-
21 ligence applications, logistics and maintenance, and
22 health care.

SEC. 1624. DEPARTMENT OF DEFENSE ONTOLOGY GOVERN-
24
ANCE WORKING GROUP.
25 (a) ESTABLISHMENT.—
†S 2296 ES

1259
1 (1) IN GENERAL.—The Secretary of Defense
2 shall establish a working group to develop and im-
3 plement a common data ontology and governance
4 structure across the Department of Defense.
5 (2) DESIGNATION.—The working group estab-
6 lished pursuant to paragraph (1) shall be known as
7 the ‘‘Department of Defense Ontology Governance
8 Working Group’’ (in this section the ‘‘Working
9 Group’’).
10 (b) PURPOSE.—The purpose of the Working Group
11 is to develop and implement a common data ontology and
12 governance structure across the Department of Defense
13 to improve data interoperability, enhance information
14 sharing, and enable more effective decision making
15 throughout the Department.
16 (c) MEMBERSHIP.—The Working Group shall consist
17 of—
18 (1) the Chief Digital and Artificial Intelligence
19 Officer;
20 (2) the Chief Information Officer of the Depart-
21 ment of Defense;
22 (3) the Chief Data Officers of the Department
23 of Defense;
24 (4) the Chief Information Officers of the mili-
25 tary departments and the combatant commands;
†S 2296 ES

1260
1 (5) such representatives from defense intel-
2 ligence entities as the Secretary considers appro-
3 priate; and
4 (6) such other officers or employees of the De-
5 partment as the Secretary considers appropriate.
6 (d) DUTIES.—The Working Group shall—
7 (1) shall coordinate with and build upon any ex-
8 isting data ontology development efforts within the
9 Department of Defense and intelligence community
10 (as defined in section 3 of the National Security Act
11 of 1947 (50 U.S.C. 3003)) to ensure complementary
12 and nonduplicative efforts;
13 (2) incorporate Department-wide data as well
14 as data from defense intelligence entities;
15 (3) develop and maintain domain-specific data
16 ontologies that address specialized knowledge areas
17 within the Department of Defense, including
18 warfighting, logistics, personnel, intelligence, and cy-
19 bersecurity domains;
20 (4) establish a process to identify and designate
21 functional domain leads responsible for leading the
22 development, review, approval, and respective guid-
23 ance of data ontologies for their particular domains;
†S 2296 ES

1261
1 (5) evaluate what security risks are introduced
2 with common and domain-specific data ontologies
3 and how these risks should be mitigated; and
4 (6) establish a governance framework that in-
5 cludes—
6 (A) a centralized repository to store the
7 common and domain-specific data ontologies in
8 a manner accessible to all authorized stake-
9 holders;
10 (B) robust version control mechanisms to
11 track changes, manage different versions, and
12 ensure a stable and authoritative source;
13 (C) clear ownership designations and role
14 definitions for data ontology management, in-
15 cluding modification and access authorities for
16 both enterprise-wide and domain-specific
17 ontologies;
18 (D) standardized governance procedures
19 for updating, reviewing, and maintaining the
20 data ontologies to ensure relevance and accu-
21 racy;
22 (E) adherence to established data ontology
23 engineering principles that promote interoper-
24 ability and reusability across domains; and
†S 2296 ES

1262
1 (F) integration with existing Department
2 data management practices and systems.
3 (e) FUNCTIONAL DOMAIN LEADS.—
4 (1) SELECTION CRITERIA.—In designating
5 functional domain leads under subsection (d)(4), the
6 Working Group shall select individuals who possess
7 extensive subject matter expertise in their respective
8 domains and maintain substantial equities or re-
9 sponsibilities within the domain.
10 (2) REPRESENTATION.—Functional domain
11 leads selected under subsection (d)(4) shall be se-
12 lected to ensure appropriate representation across
13 the Department, including the military departments,
14 combatant commands, defense agencies, and field
15 activities.
16 (3) RESPONSIBILITIES.—Functional domain
17 leads selected under subsection (d)(4) shall be re-
18 sponsible for—
19 (A) leading the development and mainte-
20 nance of data ontologies within their domains;
21 (B) reviewing and approving domain-spe-
22 cific data ontology elements;
23 (C) ensuring alignment between domain-
24 specific data ontologies and the enterprise-wide
25 data ontology framework;
†S 2296 ES

1263
1 (D) developing domain-specific guidance
2 for data ontology implementation; and
3 (E) serving as the authoritative source for
4 domain knowledge within the data ontology gov-
5 ernance structure.
6 (f) TIMELINE AND DELIVERABLES.—
7 (1) ESTABLISHMENT.—The Secretary shall en-
8 sure that the Working Group is established pursuant
9 to subsection (a) not later than June 1, 2026, and
10 the Working Group shall remain in effect for a pe-
11 riod of not less than 5 years beginning on the date
12 of the establishment of the Working Group, unless
13 the Secretary determines that it is necessary to tran-
14 sition the Working Group into a permanent organi-
15 zation.
16 (2) FUNCTIONAL DOMAIN LEAD DESIGNA-
17 TION.—Not later than August 1, 2026, the Working
18 Group shall identify and designate functional do-
19 main leads in accordance with subsections (d)(4)
20 and (e).
21 (3) DEPARTMENT-LEVEL POLICY.—Not later
22 than June 1, 2027, the Working Group shall develop
23 and distribute Department-level policy on the data
24 ontology governance structure, including guidelines
†S 2296 ES

1264
1 for the development, maintenance, and integration of
2 domain-specific ontologies.
3 (4) IMPLEMENTATION.—The Working Group
4 shall oversee the implementation of the governance
5 structure by June 1, 2028.
6 (g) BRIEFING AND REPORT.—
7 (1) BRIEFING.—Not later than July 1, 2027,
8 the Working Group shall provide to the congres-
9 sional defense committees a briefing on progress of
10 the Working Group.
11 (2) REPORT.—Not later than June 30, 2028,
12 the Secretary shall submit to the congressional de-
13 fense committees a report on the implementation of
14 the ontology governance structure, including the sta-
15 tus of implementation for both enterprise-wide and
16 domain-specific ontologies, and recommendations for
17 sustainment and further development.
18 (h) DEFINITIONS.—In this section:
19 (1) The term ‘‘data domain ontology’’ means a
20 data ontology that is specific to a particular func-
21 tional, operational, or subject-matter area within the
22 Department, including warfighting, logistics, per-
23 sonnel, intelligence, or cybersecurity domains.
24 (2) The term ‘‘data ontology’’ means a formal,
25 structured representation and categorization of data
†S 2296 ES

1265
1 elements, their properties, and the relationships be-
2 tween them within an information system or knowl-
3 edge domain that enables consistent interpretation,
4 integration, and analysis of data across different
5 systems and users.

SEC. 1625. MODIFICATION OF HIGH-PERFORMANCE COM-

SEC. 1626. ARTIFICIAL GENERAL INTELLIGENCE STEERING
4
COMMITTEE.
5 (a) ESTABLISHMENT.—
6 (1) IN GENERAL.—Not later than April 1,
7 2026, the Secretary of Defense shall establish a
8 steering committee on artificial general intelligence.
9 (2) DESIGNATION.—The steering committee es-
10 tablished pursuant to paragraph (1) shall be known
11 as the ‘‘Artificial General Intelligence Steering Com-
12 mittee’’ (in this section the ‘‘Steering Committee’’).
13 (b) MEMBERSHIP.—The Steering Committee shall be
14 composed of the following:
15 (1) The Deputy Secretary of Defense.
16 (2) The Vice Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of
17 Staff.
18 (3) The Vice Chief of Staff of the Army, the
19 Vice Chief of Staff of Naval Operations, the Assist-
20 ant Commandant of the Marine Corps, the Vice
21 Chief of Staff of the Air Force, the Vice Chief of
22 Space Operations, and the Vice Chief of the Na-
23 tional Guard Bureau.
24 (4) The Under Secretary of Defense for Acqui-
25 sition and Sustainment.
†S 2296 ES

1268
1 (5) The Under Secretary of Defense for Re-
2 search and Engineering.
3 (6) The Under Secretary of Defense for Intel-
4 ligence and Security.
5 (7) The Under Secretary of Defense (Comp-
6 troller)/Chief Financial Officer.
7 (8) Such representatives from the military de-
8 partments as the Secretary considers appropriate.
9 (9) The Chief Digital and Artificial Intelligence
10 Officer of the Department of Defense.
11 (10) Representatives of such innovation centers
12 within the defense innovation ecosystem as the Sec-
13 retary of Defense determines appropriate.
14 (11) Representatives of such other organiza-
15 tions and elements of the Department of Defense as
16 the Secretary determines appropriate.
17 (c) CO-CHAIRPERSONS.—The Deputy Secretary of
18 Defense and the Vice Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of
19 Staff shall serve as the Co-Chairpersons of the Steering
20 Committee.
21 (d) RESPONSIBILITIES.—The Steering Committee
22 shall be responsible for—
23 (1) analyzing the current trajectory of artificial
24 intelligence models and enabling technologies that
†S 2296 ES

1269
1 would support achievement of artificial general intel-
2 ligence, including—
3 (A) current and emerging models, includ-
4 ing frontier and world models;
5 (B) agentic algorithms;
6 (C) neuromorphic computing;
7 (D) cognitive science applications for algo-
8 rithm or model development;
9 (E) infrastructure needs;
10 (F) new or emerging microelectronics de-
11 signs or architectures; and
12 (G) such other technology disciplines as
13 the Steering Committee determines appropriate;
14 (2) assess the technological, operational, and
15 doctrinal trajectory of adversaries of the United
16 States towards the goal of achieving an artificial
17 general intelligence;
18 (3) analyzing the military applications and im-
19 plications of artificial general intelligence for the De-
20 partment;
21 (4) developing a strategy for the Department
22 adoption of artificial general intelligence, includ-
23 ing—
24 (A) articulation of ethical and policy
25 guardrails;
†S 2296 ES

1270
1 (B) required resources, including through
2 the use of new or novel funding mechanisms
3 like purchase commitments, financing arrange-
4 ments, or loans or loan guarantees;
5 (C) measurable goals; and
6 (D) mechanisms available for transition or
7 adoption through public-private partnerships;
8 and
9 (5) analyzing the threat landscape emanating
10 from adversarial use of artificial general intelligence
11 and developing options and counter-artificial general
12 intelligence strategies to defend against such use.
13 (e) REPORT.—
14 (1) IN GENERAL.—Not later than January 31,
15 2027, the Deputy Secretary shall submit to the con-
16 gressional defense committees a report on the find-
17 ings of the Steering Committee with respect to the
18 matters covered by subsection (d).
19 (2) FORM OF REPORT.—The report submitted
20 pursuant to paragraph (1) shall be submitted in un-
21 classified form, but may include a classified annex.
22 (3) PUBLIC AVAILABILITY.—The Deputy Sec-
23 retary shall make available to the public the unclas-
24 sified portion of the report submitted pursuant to
25 paragraph (1).
†S 2296 ES

1271
1 (f) SUNSET.—The requirements and authorities of
2 this section shall terminate on December 31, 2027.
3 (g) DEFINITIONS.—In this section:
4 (1) The term ‘‘artificial general intelligence’’
5 means artificial intelligence-capable systems with the
6 potential to match or exceed human intelligence
7 across most cognitive tasks, distinct from narrow ar-
8 tificial intelligence systems designed for specific
9 tasks in defined domains.
10 (2) The term ‘‘innovation ecosystem’’ means a
11 regionally based network of private sector, academic,
12 and government institutions in a network of formal
13 and informal institutional relationships that con-
14 tribute to technological and economic development in
15 a defined technology sector or sectors.

SEC. 1627. PHYSICAL AND CYBERSECURITY PROCUREMENT
17
REQUIREMENTS FOR ARTIFICIAL INTEL-
18
LIGENCE SYSTEMS.
19 (a) SECURITY FRAMEWORK.—
20 (1) IN GENERAL.—The Secretary of Defense
21 shall develop a framework for implementation of cy-
22 bersecurity and physical security standards and best
23 practices relating to covered artificial intelligence
24 and machine learning technologies to mitigate risks
†S 2296 ES

1272
1 to the Department of Defense from the use of such
2 technologies.
3 (2) COVERAGE OF RELEVANT ASPECTS OF SE-
4 CURITY.—The framework developed under para-
5 graph (1) shall cover all relevant aspects of the secu-
6 rity of artificial intelligence and machine learning
7 systems, including the following:
8 (A) Workforce risks, such as insider threat
9 risks.
10 (B) Training and workforce development
11 requirements, including with respect to the fol-
12 lowing:
13 (i) Artificial intelligence security
14 awareness.
15 (ii) Artificial intelligence-specific
16 threats and vulnerabilities.
17 (iii) Continuum of professional devel-
18 opment and education of artificial intel-
19 ligence security expertise.
20 (C) Supply chain risks, such as counterfeit
21 parts or data poisoning risks.
22 (D) Risks relating to adversarial tam-
23 pering with artificial intelligence systems.
†S 2296 ES

1273
1 (E) Risks relating to unintended exposure
2 or theft of artificial intelligence systems or
3 data.
4 (F) Security posture management prac-
5 tices, including governance of security meas-
6 ures, continuous monitoring, and incident re-
7 porting procedures.
8 (G) An evaluation of commercially avail-
9 able platforms for continuous monitoring and
10 assessment.
11 (3) RISK-BASED FRAMEWORK.—The framework
12 developed under paragraph (1) shall be risk-based,
13 with higher security levels corresponding proportion-
14 ally to the national security or foreign policy risks
15 posed by the covered artificial intelligence technology
16 being stolen or tampered with.
17 (4) USE OF EXISTING FRAMEWORKS.—To the
18 maximum extent feasible, the framework developed
19 under paragraph (1) shall—
20 (A) draw on existing cybersecurity ref-
21 erences, such as the NIST Special Publication
22 800 series; and
23 (B) be implemented as an extension or
24 augmentation of existing cybersecurity frame-
25 works developed by the Department of Defense,
†S 2296 ES

1274
1 such as the Cybersecurity Maturity Model Cer-
2 tification framework.
3 (5) ADDRESSING EXTREME SECURITY RISKS.—
4 (A) HIGHLY CAPABLE CYBER THREAT AC-
5 TORS.—The framework developed under para-
6 graph (1) shall take into account that the most
7 highly capable artificial intelligence systems
8 may be of great interest to the most highly ca-
9 pable cyber threat actors, such as intelligence
10 and defense agencies of peer and near-peer na-
11 tions.
12 (B) SECURITY LEVELS.—The Secretary
13 shall ensure that cybersecurity frameworks pro-
14 vided for contractors contain security levels de-
15 signed to mitigate risks posed by cyber threat
16 actors described in subparagraph (A), with the
17 highest levels being similar in scope to the level
18 of protection offered by national security sys-
19 tems.
20 (C) GENERAL DESIGN WITH SPECIFIC
21 COMPONENTS.—To the extent feasible, any ad-
22 ditional security levels developed under subpara-
23 graph (B) shall be designed generally for all
24 software systems, but may contain components
†S 2296 ES

1275
1 designed specifically for highly capable artificial
2 intelligence systems.
3 (b) SECURITY REQUIREMENTS.—
4 (1) IN GENERAL.—The Secretary may amend
5 the Defense Federal Acquisition Regulation Supple-
6 ment, or take other similar action, to require covered
7 entities to implement the best practices described in
8 the framework developed under subsection (a).
9 (2) RISK-BASED RULES.—Requirements imple-
10 mented in rules developed under paragraph (1) shall
11 be as narrowly tailored as practicable to the specific
12 covered artificial intelligence and machine learning
13 technologies developed, deployed, stored, or hosted
14 by a covered entity, and shall be calibrated accord-
15 ingly to the different tasks involved in development,
16 deployment, storage, or hosting of components of
17 those covered artificial intelligence and machine
18 learning technologies.
19 (3) COST-BENEFIT CONSIDERATION.—
20 (A) IN GENERAL.—In implementing para-
21 graph (1), the Secretary shall—
22 (i) consider the costs and benefits to
23 the Department and to United States na-
24 tional security and technological leader-
†S 2296 ES

1276
1 ship, of imposing security requirements on
2 covered entities; and
3 (ii) to the extent feasible, design re-
4 quirements in a way that allows for trans-
5 parent trade space analysis between com-
6 peting requirements in order to minimize
7 costs and maximize benefits.
8 (B) WEIGHING COSTS OF SLOWING DOWN
9 DEVELOPMENT.—In carrying out subparagraph
10 (A), the Secretary shall, in particular, weigh the
11 costs of slowing down artificial intelligence and
12 machine learning development and deployment
13 against the benefits of mitigating national secu-
14 rity risks and potential security risks to the De-
15 partment of Defense from using commercial
16 software.
17 (c) IMPLEMENTATION PLAN.—The framework re-
18 quired by subsection (a)(1) shall include a detailed imple-
19 mentation plan that—
20 (1) establishes timelines and milestones for
21 achieving the objectives outlined in the framework;
22 (2) identifies resource requirements and fund-
23 ing mechanisms; and
24 (3) provides metrics for measuring progress and
25 effectiveness.
†S 2296 ES

1277
1 (d) REPORTING REQUIREMENTS.—Not later than
2 180 days after the date of the enactment of this Act, the
3 Secretary shall submit to the congressional defense com-
4 mittees an update on the status of implementation of the
5 requirements of this section.
6 (e) DEFINITIONS.—In this section:
7 (1) The term ‘‘artificial intelligence’’ has the
8 meaning given such term in 238(g) of the John S.
9 McCain National Defense Authorization Act for Fis-
10 cal Year 2019 (Public Law 115-232; 10 U.S.C. note
11 prec. 4061).
12 (2) The term ‘‘covered artificial intelligence and
13 machine learning technology’’ means an artificial in-
14 telligence or machine learning system procured by
15 the Department of Defense and all components of
16 the development and deployment lifecycle of that ar-
17 tificial intelligence system, including source code, nu-
18 merical parameters (such as model weights) of the
19 trained artificial intelligence or machine learning
20 system, details of any methods and algorithms used
21 to develop that system, data used in the development
22 of the system, and software used for evaluating the
23 trustworthiness of the artificial intelligence or ma-
24 chine learning system during development or deploy-
25 ment.
†S 2296 ES

1278
1 (3) The term ‘‘covered entity’’ means an entity
2 that enters into a Department of Defense contract
3 that engages in the development, deployment, stor-
4 age, or hosting of a covered artificial intelligence
5 technology.

SEC. 1628. GUIDANCE AND PROHIBITION ON USE OF CER-
7
TAIN ARTIFICIAL INTELLIGENCE.
8 (a) GUIDANCE AND PROHIBITIONS.—
9 (1) REQUIREMENT REQUIRED REGARDING EX-
10 CLUSION AND REMOVAL FROM DEPARTMENT SYS-
11 TEMS AND DEVICES.—Except as provided in sub-
12 section (b), not later than 30 days after the date of
13 the enactment of this Act, the Secretary of Defense
14 shall require all Department of Defense offices and
15 components to exclude or remove covered artificial
16 intelligence from all Department of Defense systems
17 and devices.
18 (2) CONSIDERATION OF GUIDANCE FOR DE-
19 PARTMENT SYSTEMS AND DEVICES.—Not later than
20 30 days after the date of the enactment of this Act,
21 the Secretary of Defense shall consider issuing guid-
22 ance to all Department offices and components to
23 exclude or remove artificial intelligence developed by
24 a foreign adversary entity in cases in which the Sec-
25 retary determines that the artificial intelligence
†S 2296 ES

1279
1 poses a national security risk for all Department
2 systems and devices.
3 (3) PROHIBITION FOR CONTRACTORS.—
4 (A) USE OF COVERED ARTIFICIAL INTEL-
5 LIGENCE.—Except as provided in subsection
6 (b), not later than 30 days after the date of en-
7 actment of this Act, no contractor with an ac-
8 tive Department contract may use covered arti-
9 ficial intelligence for fulfillment, assistance, exe-
10 cution, or otherwise support to complete, or
11 support in part, a contract with the Depart-
12 ment.
13 (B) USE OF ARTIFICIAL INTELLIGENCE
14 DEVELOPED BY A FOREIGN ADVERSARY.—Ex-
15 cept as provided in subsection (b), if the Sec-
16 retary issues guidance described in paragraph
17 (2) to exclude or remove an artificial intel-
18 ligence developed by a foreign adversary entity
19 that the Secretary determines poses a national
20 security risk as described in such paragraph, no
21 contractor with an active Department contract
22 may use the artificial intelligence for fulfill-
23 ment, assistance, execution, or otherwise sup-
24 port to complete, or support in part, a contract
25 with the Department.
†S 2296 ES

1280
1 (b) WAIVER.—
2 (1) IN GENERAL.—The Secretary may waive a
3 prohibition under subsection (a), on a case-by-case
4 basis, if the Secretary determines that the waiver is
5 necessary—
6 (A) for the purpose of scientifically valid
7 research (as defined in section 102 of the Edu-
8 cation Sciences Reform Act of 2002 (20 U.S.C.
9 9501));
10 (B) for the purpose of evaluation, training,
11 testing, or other analysis needed for national
12 security;
13 (C) for the purpose of conducting counter
14 terrorism, counterintelligence, or other oper-
15 ational military activities supporting national
16 security; or
17 (D) for the purpose of fulfilling mission
18 critical functions.
19 (2) MITIGATION OF RISKS.—In any case in
20 which the Secretary issues a waiver pursuant to
21 paragraph (1), the Secretary shall take such steps as
22 the Secretary considers necessary to mitigate any
23 risks due to the issuance of the waiver.
24 (c) DEFINITIONS.—In this section:

SEC. 1629. ROADMAP FOR ADVANCING DIGITAL CONTENT
14
PROVENANCE STANDARDS.
15 (a) IN GENERAL.—Not later than June 1, 2026, the
16 Secretary of Defense shall develop a roadmap to guide po-
17 tential future adoption and integration of digital content
18 provenance capabilities across the Department of Defense.
19 (b) ELEMENTS.—The roadmap developed pursuant
20 to subsection (a) shall—
21 (1) identify and assess current and proposed
22 open technical standards for digital content prove-
23 nance that could be applied to publicly released dig-
24 ital media assets produced by the Department of
†S 2296 ES

1283
1 Defense, the military components, and field activities
2 of the Department;
3 (2) identify strategic objectives relating to se-
4 curing and authenticating public-facing digital con-
5 tent;
6 (3) describe relevant roles and responsibilities
7 across military departments and components of the
8 Department;
9 (4) explore the establishment of standardized
10 processes to enable embedding and verification of
11 content credentials in appropriate public-facing De-
12 partment media;
13 (5) outline potential acquisition approaches for
14 supporting technologies and solutions;
15 (6) develop metrics, as appropriate, to assess
16 the effectiveness, reliability, and scalability of digital
17 content provenance technologies;
18 (7) establish an engagement mechanism for co-
19 ordination with relevant stakeholders, including fed-
20 erally funded research and development centers, in-
21 dustry, and academia, to align efforts with evolving
22 best practices and technical capabilities; and
23 (8) establish notional milestones and resource
24 needs, disaggregated by fiscal year, to inform longer-
25 term planning.
†S 2296 ES

1284
1 (c) BRIEFING TO CONGRESS.—Not later than July
2 1, 2026, the Secretary of Defense shall provide the con-
3 gressional defense committees a briefing on the Depart-
4 ment’s roadmap for adopting digital content provenance
5 standards. The briefing should address—
6 (1) initial findings regarding feasibility, oppor-
7 tunities, and potential barriers;
8 (2) stakeholder engagement to date; and
9 (3) any planned next steps or pilot efforts
10 under consideration.
11 (d) DEFINITION OF DIGITAL CONTENT PROVE-
12 NANCE.—In this section, the term ‘‘digital content prove-
13 nance’’ means the verifiable history and origin of a digital
14 asset, including information about its creation, ownership,
15 and modifications over time.

SEC. 1630. ENHANCED PROTECTION OF DATA AFFECTING
17
OPERATIONAL SECURITY OF DEPARTMENT
18
OF DEFENSE PERSONNEL.
19 (a) PRIORITIES FOR PROTECTION OF PERSONAL
20 DATA FOR OPERATIONAL SECURITY.—In carrying out the
21 duties of the Secretary of Defense, the Secretary shall
22 identify and prioritize the protection of personal data that
23 is related to or may have impacts on the operational secu-
24 rity of members of the Armed Forces and civilian employ-
25 ees of the Department of Defense through the prevention
†S 2296 ES

1285
1 of collection, use, dissemination, or retention of such data
2 that does not conform with provisions of law and practices
3 relating to privacy that were in effect on the day before
4 the date of the enactment of this Act.
5 (b) REVIEW AND ISSUANCE OF NEW GUIDANCE RE-
6 LATED TO PROTECTION OF PERSONAL DATA RELATED TO
7 OPERATIONAL SECURITY.—Not later than June 1, 2026,
8 the Secretary of Defense will review all applicable guid-
9 ance and policy relating to the protection of personal data
10 that is related to or may have impacts on the operational
11 security of Department personnel and, if necessary, issue
12 revised or new guidance for enhanced protection measures
13 for such data. Such guidance shall cover provisions of law
14 and practices relating to privacy and personnel security
15 that were in effect on the day before the date of the enact-
16 ment of this Act.
17 (c) STORAGE OF DATA.—
18 (1) LIMITATION.—The Secretary shall ensure
19 that no Department personal data related to or that
20 may have impacts on the operational security of De-
21 partment personnel is stored on a non-Department
22 server or cloud service except pursuant to a contract
23 or other agreement entered into by the Secretary
24 and a contractor or subcontractor of the Department
†S 2296 ES

1286
1 or, for personnel data, with the permission of the
2 data subject.
3 (2) WAIVERS.—The Secretary may waive para-
4 graph (1) in a case in which the Secretary certifies
5 in writing that such waiver—
6 (A) appropriately considers the operational
7 security risks to an employee of the Department
8 with respect to whom such data may relate;
9 (B) does not pose a risk to national secu-
10 rity; and
11 (C) is necessary in the interest of national
12 security.
13 (d) CONGRESSIONAL NOTIFICATION OF CHANGES TO
14 DEPARTMENTAL ISSUANCES.—
15 (1) IN GENERAL.—Not later than 30 days after
16 the date on which the Secretary changes a Depart-
17 ment issuance relating to the protection of personal
18 data that is related to or may have impacts on the
19 operational security of Department personnel, the
20 Secretary shall submit to Congress notice of the
21 change.
22 (2) SUNSET.—The requirement of paragraph
23 (1) shall terminate on the date that is five years
24 after the date of the enactment of this Act.
25 (e) CONGRESSIONAL NOTIFICATION OF EVENTS.—

TITLE XVII—FIGHT CHINA ACT
1
OF 2025
2
3
SEC. 1701. SHORT TITLE.
4 This title may be cited as the ‘‘Foreign Investment
5 Guardrails to Help Thwart China Act of 2025’’ or
6 ‘‘FIGHT China Act of 2025’’.
7
SEC. 1702. SECRETARY DEFINED.
8 Except as otherwise provided, in this title, the term
9 ‘‘Secretary’’ means the Secretary of the Treasury.
10
SEC. 1703. SEVERABILITY.
11 If any provision of this title, or the application there-
12 of, is held invalid, the validity of the remainder of this
13 title and the application of such provision to other persons
14 and circumstances shall not be affected thereby.
15
SEC. 1704. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS.
16 (a) IN GENERAL.—There is authorized to be appro-
17 priated $150,000,000 to the Department of the Treasury,
18 out of which amounts may be transferred to the Depart-
19 ment of Commerce to jointly conduct outreach to industry
20 and persons affected by this title, for each of the first two
21 fiscal years beginning on or after the date of the enact-
22 ment of this Act, to carry out this title.
23 (b) HIRING AUTHORITY.—
24 (1) BY THE PRESIDENT.—The President may
25 appoint, without regard to the provisions of sections
†S 2296 ES

1290
1 3309 through 3318 of title 5, United States Code,
2 not more than 15 individuals directly to positions in
3 the competitive service (as defined in section 2102 of
4 that title) to carry out this title.
5 (2) BY AGENCIES.—The Secretary and the Sec-
6 retary of Commerce may appoint, without regard to
7 the provisions of sections 3309 through 3318 of title
8 5, United States Code, individuals directly to posi-
9 tions in the competitive service (as defined in section
10 2102 of that title) of the Department of the Treas-
11 ury and the Department of Commerce, respectively,
12 to carry out this title.
13
SEC. 1705. TERMINATION.
14 This title shall cease to have any force or effect on
15 the date on which the Secretary of Commerce revises sec-
16 tion 791.4 of title 15, Code of Federal Regulations, to re-
17 move the People’s Republic of China from the list of for-
18 eign adversaries contained in such section.
Subtitle A—Imposition of Sanctions

SEC. 1711. IMPOSITION OF SANCTIONS.
21 (a) IN GENERAL.—The President may impose the
22 sanctions described in subsection (b) with respect to any
23 foreign person determined by the Secretary, in consulta-
24 tion with the Secretary of State, to be a covered foreign
25 person.
†S 2296 ES

1291
1 (b) SANCTIONS DESCRIBED.—The President may ex-
2 ercise all of the powers granted to the President under
3 the International Emergency Economic Powers Act (50
4 U.S.C. 1701 et seq.) to the extent necessary to block and
5 prohibit all transactions in property and interests in prop-
6 erty of a foreign person that is determined to be a covered
7 foreign person pursuant to subsection (a) if such property
8 and interests in property are in the United States, come
9 within the United States, or are or come within the posses-
10 sion or control of a United States person.
11 (c) PENALTIES.—The penalties provided for in sub-
12 sections (b) and (c) of section 206 of the International
13 Emergency Economic Powers Act (50 U.S.C. 1705) shall
14 apply to any person who violates, attempts to violate, con-
15 spires to violate, or causes a violation of any prohibition
16 of this section, or an order or regulation prescribed under
17 this section, to the same extent that such penalties apply
18 to a person that commits an unlawful act described in sec-
19 tion 206(a) of such Act (50 U.S.C. 1705(a)).
20 (d) EXCEPTION FOR INTELLIGENCE AND LAW EN-
21 FORCEMENT ACTIVITIES.—Sanctions under this section
22 shall not apply with respect to any activity subject to the
23 reporting requirements under title V of the National Secu-
24 rity Act of 1947 (50 U.S.C. 3091 et seq.) or any author-
25 ized intelligence activities of the United States.
†S 2296 ES

1292
1 (e) EXCEPTION FOR UNITED STATES GOVERNMENT
2 ACTIVITIES.—Nothing in this section shall prohibit trans-
3 actions for the conduct of the official business of the Fed-
4 eral Government by employees, grantees, or contractors
5 thereof.
6 (f) REPORT TO CONGRESS.—Not later than 365 days
7 after the date of the enactment of this Act, and annually
8 thereafter for 7 years, the Secretary shall submit to the
9 appropriate congressional committees a report that—
10 (1) states whether each foreign person on the
11 Non-SDN Chinese Military-Industrial Complex Com-
12 panies List is a covered foreign person; and
13 (2) shall be submitted in unclassified form, but
14 may include a classified annex.
15 (g) CONSIDERATION OF CERTAIN INFORMATION IN
16 IMPOSING SANCTIONS.—In determining whether a foreign
17 person is a covered foreign person, the President—
18 (1) may consider credible information obtained
19 by other countries, nongovernmental organizations,
20 or the appropriate congressional committees that re-
21 lates to the foreign person; and
22 (2) may consider any other information that the
23 Secretary deems relevant.
24 (h) ADMINISTRATIVE PROVISIONS.—The President
25 may exercise all authorities provided under sections 203
†S 2296 ES

1293
1 and 205 of the International Emergency Economic Powers
2 Act (50 U.S.C. 1702 and 1704) to carry out this section.
3 (i) DELEGATION.—The President shall delegate the
4 authorities granted by this section to the Secretary.

SEC. 1712. DEFINITIONS.
6 In this subtitle:
7 (1) APPROPRIATE CONGRESSIONAL COMMIT-
8 TEES.—The term ‘‘appropriate congressional com-
9 mittees’’ means—
10 (A) the Committee on Financial Services
11 and the Committee on Foreign Affairs of the
12 House of Representatives; and
13 (B) the Committee on Banking, Housing,
14 and Urban Affairs and the Committee on For-
15 eign Relations of the Senate.
16 (2) COUNTRY OF CONCERN.—The term ‘‘coun-
17 try of concern’’—
18 (A) means the People’s Republic of China;
19 and
20 (B) includes the Hong Kong Special Ad-
21 ministrative Region and the Macau Special Ad-
22 ministrative Region.
23 (3) COVERED FOREIGN PERSON.—The term
24 ‘‘covered foreign person’’ means a foreign person—
†S 2296 ES

1294
1 (A)(i) that is incorporated in, has a prin-
2 cipal place of business in, or is organized under
3 the laws of a country of concern;
4 (ii) the equity securities of which are pri-
5 marily traded in the ordinary course of business
6 on one or more exchanges in a country of con-
7 cern;
8 (iii) that is a member of the Central Com-
9 mittee of the Chinese Communist Party;
10 (iv) that is the state or the government of
11 a country of concern, as well as any political
12 subdivision, agency, or instrumentality thereof;
13 (v) that is subject to the direction or con-
14 trol of any entity described in clause (i), (ii),
15 (iii), or (iv); or
16 (vi) that is owned in the aggregate, directly
17 or indirectly, 50 percent or more by an entity
18 or a group of entities described in clause (i),
19 (ii), (iii), or (iv); and
20 (B) that knowingly engaged in significant
21 operations in the defense and related materiel
22 sector or the surveillance technology sector of
23 the economy of a country of concern.
24 (4) FOREIGN PERSON.—The term ‘‘foreign per-
25 son’’ means a person, country, state, or government
†S 2296 ES

1295
1 (and any political subdivision, agency, or instrumen-
2 tality thereof) that is not a United States person.
3 (5) NON-SDN CHINESE MILITARY-INDUSTRIAL
4 COMPLEX COMPANIES LIST.—The term ‘‘Non-SDN
5 Chinese Military-Industrial Complex Companies
6 List’’ means the list maintained by the Office of
7 Foreign Assets Control of the Department of the
8 Treasury under Executive Order 13959, as amended
9 by Executive Order 14032 (50 U.S.C. 1701 note; re-
10 lating to addressing the threat from securities in-
11 vestments that finance certain companies of the Peo-
12 ple’s Republic of China), or any successor order.
13 (6) UNITED STATES PERSON.—The term
14 ‘‘United States person’’ means—
15 (A) any United States citizen or an alien
16 lawfully admitted for permanent residence to
17 the United States;
18 (B) an entity organized under the laws of
19 the United States or of any jurisdiction within
20 the United States (including any foreign branch
21 of such an entity); or
22 (C) any person in the United States.

17 ‘‘(a) IN GENERAL.—The Secretary may prohibit, in

24 has the purpose of evading or avoiding, causes a violation
†S 2296 ES

1 of, or attempts to violate the prohibition set forth in sub-

5 forth in subsection (a) any activity determined by the
6 President, in consultation with the Secretary, the Sec-

9 the national interest of the United States.

14 prohibit the disclosure of the following:

16 trative or judicial action or proceeding.
17 ‘‘(B) Information to Congress or any duly

SEC. 2824. ELIMINATION OF INDOOR RESIDENTIAL MOLD
19
IN HOUSING OF DEPARTMENT OF DEFENSE.
20 (a) STUDY AND REPORT ON HEALTH IMPACTS OF
21 INDOOR RESIDENTIAL MOLD.—
22 (1) STUDY.—
23 (A) IN GENERAL.—As soon as practicable
24 after the date of the enactment of this Act, the
25 Secretary of Defense, in consultation with the
26 Assistant Secretary of Defense for Health Af-
†S 2296 ES

1394
1 fairs, the Secretary of Housing and Urban De-
2 velopment, the Director of the Centers for Dis-
3 ease Control and Prevention, the Administrator
4 of the Environmental Protection Agency, and
5 the Secretary of Health and Human Services,
6 shall conduct a comprehensive study on the
7 health effects of indoor residential mold growth
8 in military unaccompanied housing or other
9 housing on military installations, using the
10 most up-to-date scientific peer-reviewed medical
11 literature.
12 (B) ELEMENTS.—The study conducted
13 under subparagraph (A) shall ascertain—
14 (i) detailed information about harmful
15 or toxigenic mold that may impact the
16 military departments and individuals living
17 on military installations, as well as any
18 toxin or toxic compound such mold can
19 produce;
20 (ii) the most accurate research-based
21 methods of detecting harmful or toxigenic
22 mold;
23 (iii) improved understanding of the
24 different health symptomology that can re-
25 sult from exposure to mold in indoor resi-
†S 2296 ES

1395
1 dential environments on military installa-
2 tions, including military unaccompanied
3 housing;
4 (iv) the ability to conduct and the cost
5 of conducting ongoing surveillance of the
6 prevalence of idiopathic pulmonary hemor-
7 rhage in infants living on military installa-
8 tions; and
9 (v) longitudinal studies on the effects
10 of indoor mold exposure in early childhood
11 on the development of asthma and other
12 respiratory illnesses of children living on
13 military installations.
14 (2) REPORTS REQUIRED.—
15 (A) INTERIM FINDINGS.—Not later than
16 one year after the date of the enactment of this
17 Act, the Secretary of Defense shall submit to
18 the congressional defense committees a report
19 that contains the interim findings of the study
20 conducted under paragraph (1).
21 (B) FINAL REPORT.—Not later than two
22 years after the date of the enactment of this
23 Act, the Secretary of Defense shall submit to
24 the congressional defense committees a final re-
†S 2296 ES

1396
1 port detailing the results of the study conducted
2 under paragraph (1).
3 (b) IMPLEMENTATION ACTIONS.—The Secretary of
4 Defense shall implement mitigation measures at military
5 installations found to have hazardous mold conditions fol-
6 lowing the submission of the interim findings under sub-
7 section (a)(2)(A).
8 (c) CONSTRUCTION REQUIREMENTS FOR NEW HOUS-
9 ING ON MILITARY INSTALLATIONS.—
10 (1) IN GENERAL.—The Secretary of Defense, in
11 consultation with the Secretary of Housing and
12 Urban Development, may develop model construction
13 standards and techniques for preventing and control-
14 ling indoor residential mold in new residential prop-
15 erties on a military installation if existing facilities
16 at the military installation are found to be inappro-
17 priately constructed for the environment.
18 (2) CONTENTS.—The model standards and
19 techniques developed under paragraph (1) shall pro-
20 vide for geographic differences in construction types
21 and materials, geology, weather, and other variables
22 that may affect indoor residential mold levels in new
23 buildings and on various military installations.
24 (3) CONSULTATION.—To the maximum extent
25 possible, model standards and techniques shall be
†S 2296 ES

1397
1 developed under paragraph (1) with the assistance
2 of organizations involved in establishing national
3 building construction standards and techniques.
4 (4) APPLICABILITY TO NEW CONSTRUCTION
5 AND REHABILITATION.—If the Secretary of Defense
6 develops model construction standards and tech-
7 niques under paragraph (1), not later than one year
8 after deciding to develop such standards and tech-
9 niques, the Secretary shall include such model stand-
10 ards and techniques as a requirement for residential
11 rehabilitation or new construction projects conducted
12 by the Department of Defense with amounts appro-
13 priated to the Department.
14 (d) EDUCATION FOR MILITARY HEALTH PROFES-
15 SIONALS.—The Secretary of Defense shall include edu-
16 cation for military health professions on mold-related ill-
17 ness, including signs and symptoms of toxigenic mold ex-
18 posure, in recurring training received by miliary health
19 practitioners at such time and in such manner as the Sec-
20 retary chooses.
21 (e) DEFINITIONS.—In this section:
22 (1) INDOOR RESIDENTIAL MOLD.—The term
23 ‘‘indoor residential mold’’ means any form of multi-
24 cellular fungi found in water-damaged indoor envi-
25 ronments and building materials, including
†S 2296 ES

1398
1 cladosporium, penicillium, alternaria, aspergillus, fu-
2 sarium, trichoderma, memnoniella, mucor,
3 stachybotrys chartarum, streptomyces, and
4 epicoccumoften.
5 (2) MILITARY INSTALLATION.—The term ‘‘mili-
6 tary installation’’ has the meaning given that term
7 in section 2801(c) of title 10, United States Code.
8 (3) MILITARY UNACCOMPANIED HOUSING.—The
9 term ‘‘military unaccompanied housing’’ has the
10 meaning given that term in section 2871 of title 10,
11 United States Code.
12 (4) TOXIGENIC MOLD.—The term ‘‘toxigenic
13 mold’’ means any indoor mold growth that may be
14 capable of producing a toxin or toxic compound, in-
15 cluding mycotoxins and microbial volatile organic
16 compounds, that can cause pulmonary, respiratory,
17 neurological, gastrointestinal, or dermatological ill-
18 nesses, or other major adverse health impacts, as de-
19 termined by the Secretary of Defense in consultation
20 with the Director of the National Institutes of
21 Health, the Secretary of Housing and Urban Devel-
22 opment, the Administrator of the Environmental
23 Protection Agency, and the Director of the Centers
24 for Disease Control and Prevention.

13 Should Address Critical Supply and Affordability Chal-
14 lenges for Service Members’’ (GAO–25–106208), as those
15 recommendations are modified under subsection (b).
16 (b) RECOMMENDATIONS TO BE IMPLEMENTED.—In
17 carrying out the requirements under subsection (a), the
18 Secretary of Defense shall implement the recommenda-
19 tions specified under such subsection as follows:
20 (1) The Secretary shall—
21 (A) perform a structured analysis to de-
22 velop a comprehensive list of housing areas in
23 which members of the Armed Forces and their
24 families may face the most critical challenges in
†S 2296 ES

1401
1 finding and affording private sector housing in
2 the community;
3 (B) in conducting the analysis under sub-
4 paragraph (A), consider the unique characteris-
5 tics of a location, such as vacation rental areas;
6 and
7 (C) regularly update the list required
8 under subparagraph (A) not less frequently
9 than once every two years.
10 (2) The Secretary shall obtain and use feedback
11 on the financial and quality-of-life effects of limited
12 supply or unaffordable housing on members of the
13 Armed Forces, through the status of forces survey

15 mechanisms.

19 of Defense can respond to and address the fi-
20 nancial and quality-of-life effects in housing

22 (B) in developing the plan under subpara-
23 graph (A), examine strategies for increasing
24 housing supply or providing alternative com-
25 pensation to offset the effects of limited supply
†S 2296 ES

1402
1 or unaffordable housing in housing areas identi-
2 fied under paragraph (1).
3 (4) The Secretary shall clarify, through the
4 issuance of guidance to the military departments,
5 the role of the Office of the Secretary of Defense in
6 oversight of the Housing Requirements and Market
7 Analysis process of the military departments to en-
8 sure that—
9 (A) the military departments conduct such
10 process in a timely manner; and
11 (B) the Secretary submits to Congress any
12 plans or other matters relating to such process

17 ‘‘§5612. Management structure for nuclear security
18 enterprise
19 ‘‘(a) IN GENERAL.—The Administrator shall estab-
20 lish a management structure for the nuclear security en-
21 terprise in accordance with the National Nuclear Security
22 Administration Act (50 U.S.C. 2401 et seq.).
23 ‘‘(b) NATIONAL NUCLEAR SECURITY ADMINISTRA-
24 TION COUNCIL.—
†S 2296 ES

1433
1 ‘‘(1) The Administrator shall establish a council
2 to be known as the ‘National Nuclear Security Ad-
3 ministration Council’. The Council may advise the
4 Administrator on—
5 ‘‘(A) scientific and technical issues relating
6 to policy matters;
7 ‘‘(B) operational concerns;
8 ‘‘(C) strategic planning;
9 ‘‘(D) the development of priorities relating
10 to the mission and operations of the Adminis-
11 tration and the nuclear security enterprise; and
12 ‘‘(E) such other matters as the Adminis-
13 trator determines appropriate.
14 ‘‘(2) The Council shall be composed of the di-
15 rectors of the national security laboratories and the
16 nuclear weapons production facilities.
17 ‘‘(3) The Council may provide the Adminis-
18 trator or the Secretary of Energy recommenda-
19 tions—
20 ‘‘(A) for improving the governance, man-
21 agement, effectiveness, and efficiency of the Ad-
22 ministration; and
23 ‘‘(B) relating to any other matter in ac-
24 cordance with paragraph (1).
†S 2296 ES

1434
1 ‘‘(4) Not later than 60 days after the date on
2 which any recommendation under paragraph (3) is
3 received, the Administrator or the Secretary, as the
4 case may be, shall respond to the Council with re-
5 spect to whether such recommendation will be imple-
6 mented and the reasoning for implementing or not
7 implementing such recommendation.
8 ‘‘(c) RULE OF CONSTRUCTION.—This section may
9 not be construed as affecting the authority of the Sec-
10 retary of Energy, in carrying out national security pro-
11 grams, with respect to the management, planning, and
12 oversight of the Administration or as affecting the delega-
13 tion by the Secretary of authority to carry out such activi-
14 ties, as set forth under subsection (a) of section 4102 of
15 the Atomic Energy Defense Act (50 U.S.C. 2512) as it
16 existed before the date of the enactment of the National
17 Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2013 (Public
18 Law 112–239; 126 Stat. 2169).

†S 2296 ES

1435
1 weapons components, subsystems, and materials of the

3 ‘‘(1) the consistent monitoring of the current
4 status of the industrial base;
5 ‘‘(2) tracking of industrial base issues over
6 time; and
7 ‘‘(3) proactively identifying gaps or risks in spe-
8 cific areas relating to the industrial base.
9 ‘‘(b) PROVISION OF RESOURCES.—The Adminis-
10 trator shall ensure that the official designated under sub-
11 section (a) is provided with resources sufficient to conduct
12 the monitoring required by that subsection.
13 ‘‘(c) CONSULTATIONS.—The Administrator, acting
14 through the official designated under subsection (a), shall,
15 to the extent practicable and beneficial, in conducting the
16 monitoring required by that subsection, consult with—
17 ‘‘(1) officials of the Department of Defense who
18 are members of the Nuclear Weapons Council estab-
19 lished under section 179;
20 ‘‘(2) officials of the Department of Defense re-
21 sponsible for the defense industrial base; and
22 ‘‘(3) other components of the Department of
23 Energy that rely on similar components, subsystems,
24 or materials.

1 the implementation of a common financial reporting sys-

3 ‘‘(b) ELEMENTS.—The common financial reporting
4 system implemented pursuant to subsection (a) shall in-
5 clude the following:
6 ‘‘(1) Common data reporting requirements for
7 work performed using funds of the Administration,
8 including reporting of financial data by standardized
9 labor categories, labor hours, functional elements,

11 ‘‘(2) A common work breakdown structure for

14 the Administration.

16 fying and reporting costs for programs of records

18 ‘‘(4) A capability to leverage, where appro-
19 priate, the Defense Cost Analysis Resource Center

5 ‘‘§5615. Restriction on licensing requirement for cer-
6 tain defense activities and facilities
7 ‘‘None of the funds authorized to be appropriated by
8 the Department of Energy National Security and Military
9 Applications of Nuclear Energy Authorization Act of 1981
10 (Public Law 96–540; 94 Stat. 3197) or any other Act may
11 be used for any purpose related to licensing of any defense
12 activity or facility of the Department of Energy by the
13 Nuclear Regulatory Commission.
14 ‘‘§5616. Establishment of Center for Security Tech-
15 nology, Analysis, Response, and Testing
16 ‘‘(a) ESTABLISHMENT.—The Administrator for Nu-
17 clear Security shall establish within the nuclear security
18 enterprise a Center for Security Technology, Analysis, Re-
19 sponse, and Testing.
20 ‘‘(b) DUTIES.—The center established under sub-
21 section (a) shall carry out the following:
22 ‘‘(1) Provide to the Administrator, the Chief of
23 Defense Nuclear Security, and the management and
24 operating contractors of the nuclear security enter-
25 prise a wide range of objective expertise on security
†S 2296 ES

1441
1 technologies, systems, analysis, testing, and response
2 forces.
3 ‘‘(2) Assist the Administrator in developing
4 standards, requirements, analysis methods, and test-
5 ing criteria with respect to security.
6 ‘‘(3) Collect, analyze, and distribute lessons
7 learned with respect to security.
8 ‘‘(4) Support inspections and oversight activi-
9 ties with respect to security.
10 ‘‘(5) Promote professional development and
11 training for security professionals.
12 ‘‘(6) Provide for advance and bulk procurement
13 for security-related acquisitions that affect multiple
14 facilities of the nuclear security enterprise.
15 ‘‘(7) Advocate for continual improvement and
16 security excellence throughout the nuclear security
17 enterprise.
18 ‘‘(8) Such other duties as the Administrator
19 may assign.

1 ‘‘SUBCHAPTER II—NUCLEAR WEAPONS
2 STOCKPILE MATTERS
3 ‘‘PART A—STOCKPILE STEWARDSHIP AND
4 WEAPONS PRODUCTION
5 ‘‘§5621. Stockpile stewardship program
6 ‘‘(a) ESTABLISHMENT.—The Secretary of Energy,
7 acting through the Administrator, shall establish a stew-
8 ardship program to ensure—
9 ‘‘(1) the preservation of the core intellectual
10 and technical competencies of the United States in
11 nuclear weapons, including weapons design, system
12 integration, manufacturing, security, use control, re-
13 liability assessment, and certification; and
14 ‘‘(2) that the nuclear weapons stockpile is safe,
15 secure, and reliable without the use of underground
16 nuclear weapons testing.
17 ‘‘(b) PROGRAM ELEMENTS.—The program shall in-
18 clude the following:
19 ‘‘(1) An increased level of effort for the con-
20 struction of new facilities and the modernization of
21 existing facilities with production and manufacturing
22 capabilities that are necessary to support the deter-
23 rence of strategic attacks against the United States
24 by maintaining and enhancing the performance, reli-
†S 2296 ES

1443
1 ability, and security of the United States nuclear
2 weapons stockpile, including—
3 ‘‘(A) the nuclear weapons production facili-
4 ties; and
5 ‘‘(B) production and manufacturing capa-
6 bilities resident in the national security labora-
7 tories.
8 ‘‘(2) Support for advanced computational capa-
9 bilities to enhance the simulation and modeling ca-
10 pabilities of the United States with respect to the
11 performance over time of nuclear weapons.
12 ‘‘(3) Support for above-ground experimental
13 programs, such as hydrotesting, high-energy lasers,
14 inertial confinement fusion, plasma physics, and ma-
15 terials research.
16 ‘‘(4) Support for the modernization of facilities
17 and projects that contribute to the experimental ca-
18 pabilities of the United States that support the
19 sustainment and modernization of the United States
20 nuclear weapons stockpile and the capabilities re-
21 quired to assess nuclear weapons effects.
22 ‘‘(5) Support for the use of, and experiments
23 facilitated by, the advanced experimental facilities of
24 the United States, including—
†S 2296 ES

1444
1 ‘‘(A) the National Ignition Facility at Law-
2 rence Livermore National Laboratory;
3 ‘‘(B) the Dual Axis Radiographic Hydro-
4 dynamic Test Facility at Los Alamos National
5 Laboratory;
6 ‘‘(C) the Z Machine at Sandia National
7 Laboratories; and
8 ‘‘(D) the experimental facilities at the Ne-
9 vada National Security Site.
