SEC. 5723. EVALUATION OF CERTAIN RESEARCH RELATED
21
TO MENOPAUSE, PERIMENOPAUSE, OR MID-
22
LIFE WOMEN’S HEALTH.
23 (a) IN GENERAL.—The Secretary of Defense, in co-
24 ordination with Secretary of Veterans Affairs, shall evalu-
25 ate—
†S 2296 ES

1858
1 (1) the results of completed research related to
2 menopause, perimenopause, or mid-life women’s
3 health among women who are members of the uni-
4 formed services or veterans;
5 (2) the status of such research that is ongoing;
6 (3) any gaps in knowledge and research on—
7 (A) treatments for menopause-related
8 symptoms, including hormone and non-hormone
9 treatments;
10 (B) the safety and effectiveness of treat-
11 ments for menopause-related symptoms;
12 (C) the relation of service in the uniformed
13 services to perimenopause and menopause and
14 the impact of such service on perimenopause
15 and menopause; and
16 (D) the impact of perimenopause and
17 menopause on the mental health of women who
18 are members of the uniformed services or vet-
19 erans;
20 (4) the availability of and uptake of professional
21 training resources for covered providers relating to
22 mid-life women’s health with respect to the care,
23 treatment, and management of perimenopause and
24 menopausal symptoms, and related support services;
25 and
†S 2296 ES

1859
1 (5) the availability of and uptake of treatments
2 for women who are members of the uniformed serv-
3 ices or veterans who are experiencing perimenopause
4 or menopause.
5 (b) REPORT; STRATEGIC PLAN.—Not later than 180
6 days after the date of the enactment of this Act, the Sec-
7 retary of Defense and the Secretary of Veterans Affairs
8 shall each submit to Congress a report containing—
9 (1) the findings of the evaluation conducted
10 under subsection (a);
11 (2) recommendations for improving professional
12 training resources described in subsection (a)(4) for
13 covered providers; and
14 (3) a strategic plan that—
15 (A) resolves the gaps in knowledge and re-
16 search identified in the report; and
17 (B) identifies topics in need of further re-
18 search relating to potential treatments for
19 menopause-related symptoms of women who are
20 members of the uniformed services or veterans.
21 (c) NONDUPLICATION AND SUPPLEMENTATION OF
22 EFFORTS.—In carrying out activities under this section,
23 the Secretary of Defense and the Secretary of Veterans
24 Affairs shall ensure that such activities minimize duplica-
25 tion and supplement, not supplant, existing information-
†S 2296 ES

1860
1 sharing efforts of the Department of Health and Human
2 Services.
3 (d) SENSE OF CONGRESS ON ADDITIONAL RESEARCH
4 RELATED TO MENOPAUSE, PERIMENOPAUSE, OR MID-
5 LIFE WOMEN’S HEALTH.—It is the sense of Congress that
6 the Secretary of Defense and the Secretary of Veterans
7 Affairs should each conduct research related to meno-
8 pause, perimenopause, or mid-life health regarding women
9 who are members of the uniformed services or veterans.
10 (e) DEFINITIONS.—In this section:
11 (1) COVERED PROVIDER.—The term ‘‘covered
12 provider’’ means a health care provider employed by
13 the Department of Defense or the Department of
14 Veterans Affairs.
15 (2) MENOPAUSE.—The term‘‘menopause’’
16 means the stage of a woman’s life—
17 (A) when menstrual periods stop perma-
18 nently and she can no longer get pregnant; and
19 (B) that is not a disease state, but a nor-
20 mal part of aging for women.
21 (3) MID-LIFE.—The term‘‘mid-life’’ means a
22 life stage that—
23 (A) coincides with the menopausal transi-
24 tion in women, which may be physical or emo-
25 tional;
†S 2296 ES

1861
1 (B) encompasses the late reproductive age,
2 which can begin at approximately 35 years of
3 age, to the late postmenopausal stages of repro-
4 ductive aging, which can extend to approxi-
5 mately 65 years of age; and
6 (C) often marks the onset of many chronic
7 diseases.
8 (4) PERIMENOPAUSE.—The term
9 ‘‘perimenopause’’ means the time during a woman’s
10 life when levels of the hormone estrogen fall un-
11 evenly in a woman’s body and is also called the men-
12 opausal transition.
13 (5) POSTMENOPAUSAL.—The term ‘‘post-
14 menopausal’’ means the stage of a woman’s life after
15 a woman has been without a menstrual period for 12
16 months that lasts for the rest of a woman’s life and
17 reflects a time when women are at increased risk for
18 osteoporosis and heart disease.

SEC. 6023. INTERNATIONAL NUCLEAR ENERGY.
21 (a) SHORT TITLE.—This section may be cited as the
22 ‘‘International Nuclear Energy Act of 2025’’.
23 (b) DEFINITIONS.—In this section:
24 (1) ADVANCED NUCLEAR REACTOR.—The term
25 ‘‘advanced nuclear reactor’’ means—
†S 2296 ES

1878
1 (A) a nuclear fission reactor, including a
2 prototype plant (as defined in sections 50.2 and
3 52.1 of title 10, Code of Federal Regulations
4 (or successor regulations)), with significant im-
5 provements compared to reactors operating on
6 October 19, 2016, including improvements such
7 as—
8 (i) additional inherent safety features;
9 (ii) lower waste yields;
10 (iii) improved fuel and material per-
11 formance;
12 (iv) increased tolerance to loss of fuel
13 cooling;
14 (v) enhanced reliability or improved
15 resilience;
16 (vi) increased proliferation resistance;
17 (vii) increased thermal efficiency;
18 (viii) reduced consumption of cooling
19 water and other environmental impacts;
20 (ix) the ability to integrate into elec-
21 tric applications and nonelectric applica-
22 tions;
23 (x) modular sizes to allow for deploy-
24 ment that corresponds with the demand
25 for electricity or process heat; and
†S 2296 ES

1879
1 (xi) operational flexibility to respond
2 to changes in demand for electricity or
3 process heat and to complement integra-
4 tion with intermittent renewable energy or
5 energy storage;
6 (B) a fusion machine (as defined in section
7 11 of the Atomic Energy Act of 1954 (42
8 U.S.C. 2014)); and
9 (C) a radioisotope power system that uti-
10 lizes heat from radioactive decay to generate
11 energy.
12 (2) ALLY OR PARTNER NATION.—The term
13 ‘‘ally or partner nation’’ means—
14 (A) the Government of any country that is
15 a member of the Organisation for Economic Co-
16 operation and Development;
17 (B) the Government of the Republic of
18 India; and
19 (C) the Government of any country des-
20 ignated as an ally or partner nation by the Sec-
21 retary of State for purposes of this section.
22 (3) APPROPRIATE COMMITTEES OF CON-
23 GRESS.—The term ‘‘appropriate committees of Con-
24 gress’’ means—
†S 2296 ES

1880
1 (A) the Committees on Foreign Relations,
2 Homeland Security and Governmental Affairs,
3 and Energy and Natural Resources of the Sen-
4 ate; and
5 (B) the Committees on Foreign Affairs
6 and Energy and Commerce of the House of
7 Representatives.
8 (4) ASSOCIATED ENTITY.—The term ‘‘associ-
9 ated entity’’ means an entity that—
10 (A) is owned, controlled, or operated by—
11 (i) an ally or partner nation; or
12 (ii) an associated individual; or
13 (B) is organized under the laws of, or oth-
14 erwise subject to the jurisdiction of, a country
15 described in paragraph (2), including a corpora-
16 tion that is incorporated in a country described
17 in that paragraph.
18 (5) ASSOCIATED INDIVIDUAL.—The term ‘‘asso-
19 ciated individual’’ means a foreign national who is a
20 national of a country described in paragraph (2).
21 (6) CIVIL NUCLEAR.—The term ‘‘civil nuclear’’
22 means activities relating to—
23 (A) nuclear plant construction;
24 (B) nuclear fuel services;
25 (C) nuclear energy financing;
†S 2296 ES

1881
1 (D) nuclear plant operations;
2 (E) nuclear plant regulation;
3 (F) nuclear medicine;
4 (G) nuclear safety;
5 (H) community engagement in areas in
6 reasonable proximity to nuclear sites;
7 (I) infrastructure support for nuclear en-
8 ergy;
9 (J) nuclear plant decommissioning;
10 (K) nuclear liability;
11 (L) safe storage and safe disposal of spent
12 nuclear fuel;
13 (M) environmental safeguards;
14 (N) nuclear nonproliferation and security;
15 and
16 (O) technology related to the matters de-
17 scribed in subparagraphs (A) through (N).
18 (7) EMBARKING CIVIL NUCLEAR NATION.—
19 (A) IN GENERAL.—The term ‘‘embarking
20 civil nuclear nation’’ means a country that—
21 (i) does not have a civil nuclear en-
22 ergy program;
23 (ii) is in the process of developing or
24 expanding a civil nuclear energy program,
†S 2296 ES

1882
1 including safeguards and a legal and regu-
2 latory framework, for—
3 (I) nuclear safety;
4 (II) nuclear security;
5 (III) radioactive waste manage-
6 ment;
7 (IV) civil nuclear energy;
8 (V) environmental safeguards;
9 (VI) community engagement in

11 clear sites;

19 technologies; or

1 partment of Commerce, the Nuclear Energy Advi-

17 sion of law, the Administrator of the National Aeronautics
18 and Space Administration may enter into an agreement,
19 as appropriate, with the Town of Chincoteague, Virginia,
20 for a period of up to five years, for reimbursement of the
21 Town of Chincoteague’s costs directly associated with—
22 (1) the development of a plan for removal of
23 drinking water wells currently situated on property
24 administered by the National Aeronautics and Space
25 Administration; and
†S 2296 ES

1927
1 (2) the establishment of alternative drinking
2 water wells on property under the administrative
3 control, through lease, ownership, or easement, of
4 the Town of Chincoteague.
5 (b) ELEMENTS.—An agreement under subsection (a)
6 shall include, to the extent practicable—
7 (1) a provision for the removal and relocation
8 of the three remaining wells described in that sub-
9 section;
10 (2) a description of the location of the site to
11 which such wells will be relocated or are planned to
12 be relocated; and
13 (3) a current estimated cost of such relocation,
14 including for the purchase, lease, or use of addi-
15 tional property, engineering, design, permitting, and
16 construction.
17 (c) SUBMISSION TO CONGRESS.—Not later than 18
18 months after the date of the enactment of this Act, the
19 Administrator of the National Aeronautics and Space Ad-

23 entered into under subsection (a).

1929
1 (1) The types of investigations in which artifi-

6 would be best placed to detect.

SEC. 6033. KEEPING DRUGS OUT OF SCHOOLS.
10 (a) DEFINITIONS.—In this section:
11 (1) DIRECTOR.—The term ‘‘Director’’ means
12 the Director of the Office of National Drug Control
13 Policy.
14 (2) DRUG-FREE COMMUNITIES FUNDED COALI-
15 TION.—The term ‘‘Drug-Free Communities funded
16 coalition’’ means a recipient of a grant under section
17 1032 of the Anti-Drug Abuse Act of 1988 (21
18 U.S.C. 1532).
19 (3) EFFECTIVE DRUG PREVENTION PRO-
20 GRAMS.—The term ‘‘effective drug prevention pro-
21 grams’’, with respect to a school-community partner-
22 ship between a Drug-Free Communities funded coa-
23 lition and a local school, means strategies, policies,
24 and activities that—
†S 2296 ES

1930
1 (A) are tailored to meet the needs of the
2 student population of the school, based on the
3 environment of the school and the community
4 surrounding the school; and
5 (B) prevent and reduce substance use and
6 misuse among local youth.
7 (4) ELIGIBLE ENTITY.—The term ‘‘eligible enti-
8 ty’’ means a coalition (within the meaning of section
9 1032 of the Anti-Drug Abuse Act of 1988 (21
10 U.S.C. 1532)) that—
11 (A) receives or has received a grant under
12 subchapter I of chapter 2 of title I of the Anti-
13 Drug Abuse Act of 1988 (21 U.S.C. 1523 et
14 seq.); and
15 (B) has a memorandum of understanding
16 in effect with not less than 1 local school to es-
17 tablish a school-community partnership.
18 (5) LOCAL SCHOOL.—The term ‘‘local school’’
19 means an elementary, middle, or high school located
20 in an area served by an eligible entity.
21 (6) SCHOOL-COMMUNITY PARTNERSHIP.—The
22 term ‘‘school-community partnership’’ means a part-
23 nership between a Drug-Free Communities funded
24 coalition and not less than 1 local school for the pur-
†S 2296 ES

1931
1 pose of implementing effective drug prevention pro-
2 grams.
3 (7) SUBSTANCE USE AND MISUSE.—The term
4 ‘‘substance use and misuse’’—
5 (A) has the meaning given the term in
6 paragraph (9) of section 1023 of the Anti-Drug
7 Abuse Act of 1988 (21 U.S.C. 1523); and
8 (B) includes the use of electronic or other
9 delivery mechanisms to consume a substance
10 described in subparagraph (A), (B), or (C) of
11 that paragraph.
12 (b) GRANTS AUTHORIZED.—
13 (1) IN GENERAL.—
14 (A) INITIAL GRANTS.—Subject to para-
15 graph (2), the Director may award grants to el-
16 igible entities for the purpose of implementing
17 a school-community partnership.
18 (B) RENEWAL GRANTS.—Subject to para-
19 graph (2), the Director may award to an eligi-
20 ble entity who has received a grant under sub-
21 paragraph (A) an additional grant for each fis-
22 cal year during the 3-fiscal-year period fol-
23 lowing the fiscal year for which the grant was
24 awarded under subparagraph (A), for the pur-
†S 2296 ES

1932
1 pose of continuing the school-community part-
2 nership.
3 (2) LIMITATIONS.—

7 (B) RECIPIENTS.—Not more than 1 eligi-

9 section to establish a school-community partner-
10 ship with a particular local school.
11 (c) INTERAGENCY AGREEMENT.—The Director may

15 Act of 1998 (21 U.S.C. 1701), to delegate authority for—
16 (1) the execution of grants under this section;

21 (1) IN GENERAL.—An eligible entity desiring a

11 (A) to implement the plan described in

Subtitle H—Export Controls for
13
Advanced Artificial Intelligence
14
Chips
15
16
SEC. 6081. SHORT TITLE.
17 This subtitle may be cited as the ‘‘Guaranteeing Ac-
18 cess and Innovation for National Artificial Intelligence Act
19 of 2025’’ or the ‘‘GAIN AI Act of 2025’’.
20
SEC. 6082. SENSE OF CONGRESS.
21 It is the sense of Congress that—
22 (1) artificial intelligence is a transformative
23 technology and United States policy should ensure
24 that United States persons, including small busi-
25 nesses, startups, and universities, are in the best po-
†S 2296 ES

1964
1 sition to innovate and harness the potential of artifi-
2 cial intelligence;
3 (2) the demand for advanced artificial intel-
4 ligence chips far exceeds the supply, and United
5 States persons are forced to wait many months, if
6 not longer, to acquire the latest chips;
7 (3) at the same time, United States chip devel-
8 opers are selling advanced artificial intelligence chips
9 to entities in countries that are subject to a United
10 States arms embargo or countries that have a close
11 relationship with such countries, so that United
12 States persons are unable to acquire such chips;
13 (4) the production of such chips for sale to enti-
14 ties in countries described in paragraph (3) is taking
15 up production capacity that would otherwise be used
16 to fabricate chips for United States persons; and
17 (5) it should be the policy of the United States
18 and the Department of Commerce—
19 (A) to deny licenses for the export of the
20 most powerful artificial intelligence chips, in-
21 cluding such chips with a total processing power
22 of 4,800 or above; and
23 (B) to restrict the export of less advanced
24 artificial intelligence chips to foreign entities in
25 countries of concern so long as United States
†S 2296 ES

1965
1 entities are waiting and unable to acquire those
2 same chips.
3

16 (a) FINDINGS.—Congress finds the following:
17 (1) Since the Russian Federation’s full-scale in-
18 vasion of Ukraine in February 2022, the Russian
19 Federation military forces and the Government of
20 the Russian Federation have abducted, forcibly
21 transferred, or facilitated the illegal deportation of
22 at least 20,000 Ukrainian children.
23 (2) The Russian Federation’s abduction, forc-
24 ible transfer, and facilitation of the illegal deporta-
25 tion of Ukrainian children has left countless children
†S 2296 ES

1976
1 and families with devastating physical and psycho-
2 logical trauma.
3 (b) SENSE OF CONGRESS.—It is the sense of Con-
4 gress that Congress—
5 (1) condemns the Russian Federation’s abduc-
6 tion, forcible transfer, and facilitation of the illegal
7 deportation of Ukrainian children; and
8 (2) implores the Russian Federation to work
9 with the international community to ensure the re-
10 turn, without delay, of all forcibly transferred
11 Ukrainian children to their families.

SEC. 6232. STRATEGY TO RESPOND TO THE PRC’S GLOBAL
2
BASING INTENTIONS.
3 (a) SHORT TITLES.—This section may be cited as the
4 ‘‘Combating PRC Overseas and Unlawful Networked
5 Threats through Enhanced Resilience Act of 2025’’ or the
6 ‘‘COUNTER Act of 2025’’.
7 (b) FINDINGS.—According to multiple sources, in-
8 cluding the 2024 annual report to Congress, titled ‘‘Mili-
9 tary and Security Developments Involving the People’s
10 Republic of China’’ and known informally as the ‘‘China
11 Military Power Report’’—
12 (1) the PRC is seeking to expand its overseas
13 logistics and basing infrastructure to allow the PLA
14 to project and sustain military power at greater dis-
15 tances;
16 (2) a global PLA logistics network could give
17 the PRC increased capabilities to surveil or disrupt
18 United States military operations;
19 (3) in August 2017, the PRC officially opened
20 the first overseas PLA military base near the com-
21 mercial port of Doraleh in Djibouti;
22 (4) in 2019, the PRC also attempted to acquire
23 strategically important port infrastructure at Subic
24 Bay in the Philippines, but was stopped by the Gov-
25 ernments of the United States, the Philippines, and
26 Japan, and by private investors;
†S 2296 ES

1989
1 (5) in April 2025, officials from the PRC and
2 Cambodia officially inaugurated the China-Cambodia
3 Ream Naval Base Joint Support and Training Cen-
4 ter and celebrated the expansion of port facilities at
5 Ream Naval Base, some of which appear to have
6 been reserved for the use of PRC ships that have
7 been continuously stationed at Ream Naval Base
8 since December 2023; and
9 (6) in addition to the base in Djibouti and the
10 PRC’s access to the port at the Ream Naval Base
11 in Cambodia, the PRC is likely pursuing access to
12 additional military facilities to support naval, air,
13 and ground forces projection in many countries.
14 (c) SENSE OF CONGRESS.—While the executive
15 branch has undertaken case-by-case efforts to forestall the
16 establishment of new PRC permanent military presence
17 in several countries, it is the sense of Congress that future
18 efforts to counter the PRC’s global basing intentions
19 must—
20 (1) proceed with the urgency required to ad-
21 dress the strategic implications of the PRC’s actions;
22 (2) reflect sufficient interagency coordination
23 with respect to a problem that necessitates a whole-
24 of-government approach;
†S 2296 ES

1990
1 (3) ensure that the United States Government
2 maintains a proactive posture rather than a reactive
3 posture in order to maximize strategic decision
4 space;
5 (4) identify a comprehensive menu of actions
6 that would be influential in shaping a partner’s deci-
7 sion making regarding giving the PRC military ac-
8 cess to its sovereign territory;
9 (5) appropriately prioritize the subject of the
10 PRC’s global basing intentions within the context of
11 the overall United States strategic competition with
12 the PRC;
13 (6) consider how the PRC uses commercial and
14 scientific cooperation as a guise for establishing ac-
15 cess for the PLA and other PRC security forces in
16 foreign countries;
17 (7) factor in the potential contributions of key
18 allies and partners to help respond to the PRC’s
19 pursuit of global basing, many of which—
20 (A) have historic ties and influence in
21 many of the geographic areas the PRC is tar-
22 geting for potential future bases; and
23 (B) rely on the same basic intelligence pic-
24 ture to form our baseline understanding of the
25 PRC’s global intentions;
†S 2296 ES

1991
1 (8) establish and ensure sufficient resourcing
2 for enduring organizational structures and security
3 and foreign assistance and cooperation efforts to ef-
4 fectively address the issue of PRC global basing in-
5 tentions; and
6 (9) ensure that future force posture, freedom of
7 movement, and other interests of the United States
8 and our allies are not jeopardized by the continued
9 expansion of PRC bases.
10 (d) DEFINITIONS.—In this section:
11 (1) APPROPRIATE CONGRESSIONAL COMMIT-
12 TEES.—The term ‘‘appropriate congressional com-
13 mittees’’ means—
14 (A) the Committee on Foreign Relations of
15 the Senate;
16 (B) the Committee on Armed Services of
17 the Senate;
18 (C) the Select Committee on Intelligence of
19 the Senate;
20 (D) the Committee on Appropriations of
21 the Senate;
22 (E) the Committee on Foreign Affairs of
23 the House of Representatives;
24 (F) the Committee on Armed Services of
25 the House of Representatives;
†S 2296 ES

1992
1 (G) the Permanent Select Committee on
2 Intelligence of the House of Representatives;
3 and
4 (H) the Committee on Appropriations of
5 the House of Representatives.
6 (2) PLA.—The term ‘‘PLA’’ means the Peo-
7 ple’s Liberation Army of the PRC.
8 (3) PRC.—The term ‘‘PRC’’ means the Peo-
9 ple’s Republic of China.
10 (4) PRC GLOBAL BASING.—The term ‘‘PRC
11 global basing’’ means the establishment of physical
12 locations outside the geographic boundaries of the
13 PRC where the PRC maintains some element of the
14 People’s Liberation Army, PRC intelligence or secu-
15 rity forces, or infrastructure designed to support the
16 presence of PRC military, intelligence, or security
17 forces, for the purposes of potential power projec-
18 tion.
19 (e) ASSESSMENT OF EXECUTIVE BRANCH’S C–PRC
20 GLOBAL BASING STRATEGY.—Not later than 180 days
21 after the date of the enactment of this Act, the Director
22 of National Intelligence shall submit an intelligence as-
23 sessment, in classified form, if needed, to the appropriate
24 congressional committees. The assessment shall analyze
25 the risk posed by PRC global basing to the United States
†S 2296 ES

1993
1 or to any United States allies with respect to their ability
2 to project power, maintain freedom of movement, and pro-
3 tect other interests as a function of the PRC’s current
4 or potential locations identified pursuant to subsection
5 (f)(2)(A).
6 (f) STRATEGY.—
7 (1) IN GENERAL.—Not later than 180 days
8 after the date of the enactment of this Act, the Sec-
9 retary of State, in coordination with the Secretary of
10 Defense and other appropriate senior Federal offi-
11 cials, shall submit a strategy to the appropriate con-
12 gressional committees that contains the information
13 described in paragraph (2).
14 (2) CONTENTS.—The strategy required under
15 paragraph (1) shall—
16 (A) identify not fewer than 5 locations that
17 pose the greatest potential risks, as identified in
18 the assessment required under subsection (e),
19 where the PRC maintains a physical presence,
20 or is suspected to be seeking a physical pres-
21 ence, which could ultimately transition into a
22 PRC global base;
23 (B) include a comprehensive listing of ex-
24 ecutive branch entities currently involved in ad-
25 dressing aspects of PRC global basing, includ-
†S 2296 ES

1994
1 ing estimated programmatic and personal re-
2 source requirements on an agency-by-agency
3 basis to effectively address the issue of PRC
4 global basing intentions, and any relevant re-
5 source constraints;
6 (C) describe in detail all executive branch
7 efforts to mitigate the impacts to the national
8 interests of the United States and partner
9 countries of the locations referred to in sub-
10 paragraph (A) and prevent the PRC from es-
11 tablishing new global bases, including with re-
12 sources described in subparagraph (B); and
13 (D) for each of the locations referred to in
14 subparagraph (A), identify the actions by the
15 United States or its allies that would be most
16 effective in ensuring the respective foreign gov-
17 ernments terminate plans for hosting a PRC
18 base.
19 (g) TASK FORCE.—Not later than 90 days after sub-
20 mitting the strategy described in subsection (f), the Sec-
21 retary of State, in coordination with the Secretary of De-
22 fense and other appropriate senior Federal officials, shall
23 establish an interagency task force—
24 (1) to implement such strategy to counter the
25 PRC’s efforts at the locations of chief concern; and
†S 2296 ES

1995
1 (2) to identify mitigation measures that would
2 prevent the PRC from establishing new bases in lo-
3 cations beyond the locations of chief concern identi-
4 fied pursuant to subsection (f)(2)(A).
5 (h) QUADRENNIAL REVIEWS AND REPORTS.—Not
6 later than 4 years after the submission of the strategy re-
7 quired under subsection (f), and not less frequently than

17 appropriate congressional committees.

SEC. 6251. SHORT TITLE.

SEC. 6252. FINDINGS.
8 Congress finds as follows:
9 (1) As enshrined in its Articles of Agreement,
10 the International Monetary Fund (IMF) is devoted
11 to promoting international monetary cooperation, fa-
12 cilitating the expansion and balanced growth of
13 international trade, encouraging exchange stability,
14 and avoiding competitive exchange depreciation.
15 (2) Taiwan is the 21st largest economy in the
16 world and the 10th largest goods trading partner of
17 the United States.
18 (3) Although Taiwan is not an IMF member, it
19 is a member of the World Trade Organization, the
20 Asian Development Bank, and the Asia-Pacific Eco-
21 nomic Cooperation forum.
22 (4) According to the January 2020 Report on
23 Macroeconomic and Foreign Exchange Policies of
24 Major Trading Partners of the United States, pub-
25 lished by the Department of the Treasury, Taiwan
†S 2296 ES

2006
1 held $471,900,000,000 in foreign exchange reserves,
2 more than major economies such as India, South
3 Korea, and Brazil.
4 (5) According to section 4(d) of the Taiwan Re-
5 lations Act (Public Law 96–8), enacted on April 10,
6 1979, ‘‘Nothing in this Act may be construed as a
7 basis for supporting the exclusion or expulsion of
8 Taiwan from continued membership in any inter-
9 national financial institution or any other inter-
10 national organization.’’.
11 (6) Taiwan held membership in the IMF for 9
12 years following the recognition of the People’s Re-
13 public of China (PRC) by the United Nations, and
14 16 Taiwan staff members at the Fund were allowed
15 to continue their employment after the PRC was
16 seated at the IMF in 1980. As James M. Boughton
17 has noted in his Silent Revolution: The International
18 Monetary Fund 1979–1989, even as the PRC was
19 seated, the United States Executive Director to the
20 IMF, Sam Y. Cross, expressed support on behalf of
21 the United States Government for ‘‘some kind of as-
22 sociation between Taiwan and the Fund’’.
23 (7) On September 27, 1994, in testimony be-
24 fore the Senate Committee on Foreign Relations re-
25 garding the 1994 Taiwan Policy Review, then-As-
†S 2296 ES

2007
1 sistant Secretary of State for East Asian and Pacific
2 Affairs Winston Lord stated: ‘‘Recognizing Taiwan’s
3 important role in transnational issues, we will sup-
4 port its membership in organizations where state-
5 hood is not a prerequisite, and we will support op-
6 portunities for Taiwan’s voice to be heard in organi-
7 zations where its membership is not possible.’’.
8 (8) The Congress has repeatedly reaffirmed
9 support for this policy, including in Public Laws
10 107–10, 107–158, 108–28, 108–235, 113–17, and
11 114–139, and the unanimous House and Senate
12 passage of the Taiwan Allies International Protec-
13 tion and Enhancement Initiative (TAIPEI) Act of
14 2019.
15 (9) In its fact sheet, entitled ‘‘U.S. Relations
16 with Taiwan’’, published on August 31, 2018, the
17 Department of State asserts: ‘‘The United States
18 supports Taiwan’s membership in international orga-
19 nizations that do not require statehood as a condi-
20 tion of membership and encourages Taiwan’s mean-
21 ingful participation in international organizations
22 where its membership is not possible.’’.
23 (10) According to the Articles of Agreement of
24 the IMF, ‘‘membership shall be open to other coun-
†S 2296 ES

2008
1 tries’’, subject to conditions prescribed by the Board
2 of Governors of the IMF.
3 (11) In the IMF publication ‘‘Membership and
4 Nonmembership in the International Monetary
5 Fund: A Study in International Law and Organiza-
6 tion’’, Joseph Gold, the then-General Counsel and
7 Director of the Legal Department of the IMF, elabo-
8 rated on the differences between the terms ‘‘coun-
9 tries’’ and ‘‘states’’, noting that ‘‘the word ‘country’
10 may have been adopted because of the absence of
11 agreement on the definition of a ‘state’’’ and, with
12 respect to the use of ‘‘countries’’ and applications
13 for IMF membership, ‘‘the absence of any adjective
14 in the Articles emphasizes the breadth of the discre-
15 tion that the Fund may exercise in admitting coun-
16 tries to membership’’. According to Mr. Gold, ‘‘the
17 desire to give the Fund flexibility in dealing with ap-
18 plications may explain not only the absence of any
19 adjective that qualifies ‘countries’ but also the choice
20 of that word itself’’.
21 (12) In his IMF study, Mr. Gold further ob-
22 serves, ‘‘in the practice of the Fund the concepts of
23 independence and sovereignty have been avoided on
24 the whole as a mode of expressing a criterion for
25 membership in the Fund’’. He continues, ‘‘Although
†S 2296 ES

2009
1 the Fund usually takes into account the recognition
2 or nonrecognition of an entity as a state, there are
3 no rules or even informal understandings on the ex-
4 tent to which an applicant must have been recog-
5 nized by members or other international organiza-
6 tions before the Fund will regard it as eligible for
7 membership.’’. In fact, when considering an applica-
8 tion for membership where the status of an appli-
9 cant may not be resolved, Mr. Gold writes ‘‘there
10 have been occasions on which the Fund has made a
11 finding before decisions had been taken by the
12 United Nations or by most members or by members
13 with a majority of the total voting power.’’ Mr. Gold
14 concludes, ‘‘the Fund makes its own findings on
15 whether an applicant is a ‘country’, and makes them
16 solely for its own purposes.’’.
17 (13) Although not a member state of the
18 United Nations, the Republic of Kosovo is a member
19 of both the IMF and the World Bank, having joined
20 both organizations on June 29, 2009.
21 (14) On October 26, 2021, Secretary of State
22 Antony Blinken issued a statement in support of
23 Taiwan’s ‘‘robust, meaningful participation’’ in the
24 United Nations system, which includes the IMF, the
25 World Bank, and other specialized United Nations
†S 2296 ES

2010
1 agencies. Secretary of State Blinken noted, ‘‘As the
2 international community faces an unprecedented
3 number of complex and global issues, it is critical for
4 all stakeholders to help address these problems. This
5 includes the 24 million people who live in Taiwan.
6 Taiwan’s meaningful participation in the UN system
7 is not a political issue, but a pragmatic one.’’. He
8 continued, ‘‘Taiwan’s exclusion undermines the im-
9 portant work of the UN and its related bodies, all
10 of which stand to benefit greatly from its contribu-
11 tions.’’.
12 (15) In October 2024, Taiwan announced it
13 would seek IMF membership, with the Taipei Eco-
14 nomic and Cultural Representative Office in the
15 United States stating, ‘‘Taiwan’s membership at the
16 IMF would help boost financial resilience.’’.
17

†S 2296 ES

SEC. 6254. SUPPORT FOR TAIWAN ADMISSION TO THE IMF.
6 (a) IN GENERAL.—The United States Governor of
7 the International Monetary Fund (in this section referred
8 to as the ‘‘Fund’’) shall use the voice and vote of the
9 United States to vigorously support—
10 (1) the admission of Taiwan as a member of
11 the Fund, to the extent that admission is sought by
12 Taiwan;
13 (2) participation by Taiwan in regular surveil-
14 lance activities of the Fund with respect to the eco-
15 nomic and financial policies of Taiwan, consistent
16 with Article IV consultation procedures of the Fund;
17 (3) employment opportunities for Taiwan na-
18 tionals, without regard to any consideration that, in
19 the determination of the United States Governor,
20 does not generally restrict the employment of nation-
21 als of member countries of the Fund; and
22 (4) the ability of Taiwan to receive appropriate
23 technical assistance and training by the Fund.
†S 2296 ES

2012
1 (b) UNITED STATES POLICY.—It is the policy of the
2 United States not to discourage or otherwise deter Taiwan
3 from seeking admission as a member of the Fund.
4 (c) WAIVER.—The Secretary of the Treasury may
5 waive any requirement of subsection (a) for up to 1 year
6 at a time on reporting to Congress that providing the
7 waiver will substantially promote the objective of securing
8 the meaningful participation of Taiwan at each inter-
9 national financial institution (as defined in section
10 1701(c)(2) of the International Financial Institutions
11 Act).
12 (d) SUNSET.—This section shall have no force or ef-
13 fect on the earlier of—
14 (1) the date of approval by the Board of Gov-
15 ernors of the Fund for the admission of Taiwan as
16 a member of the Fund; or
17 (2) the date that is 10 years after the date of
18 the enactment of this Act.

SEC. 6611. STRATEGY ON QUANTUM READINESS.
17 (a) STRATEGY REQUIRED.—Not later than 180 days
18 after the date of the enactment of this Act, the Secretary
19 of Defense shall, in coordination with the Chief Informa-
20 tion Officer of the Department of Defense, submit to the
21 congressional defense committees a strategy on quantum
22 readiness. Such strategy shall include each of the fol-
23 lowing:
†S 2296 ES

2026
1 (1) An assessment of the risks that quantum
2 computing pose to Department of Defense systems
3 and data.
4 (2) A determination of which Department sys-
5 tems and data are most vulnerable to quantum
6 threats and critical to protect, and timelines for the
7 transition of such systems and data.
8 (3) An identification of the progress made by
9 organizations and elements of the Department of
10 Defense in inventorying and migrating all cryp-
11 tographic systems to post-quantum cryptography by
12 2035 or earlier.
13 (4) A plan to adopt and deploy automated
14 quantum readiness platform tools, including capa-
15 bilities that—
16 (A) provide continuous visibility into an or-
17 ganization’s cryptographic landscape;
18 (B) automate the prioritization of cryp-
19 tographic risks; and
20 (C) facilitate the remediation of insecure
21 cryptography.
22 (5) An identification of the methodology used
23 for evaluating and validating Department cryp-
24 tographic modules as quantum ready.
†S 2296 ES

2027
1 (6) An estimate of resources needed to achieve
2 quantum readiness by the target deadline of 2035,
3 as well as an additional estimate of resources needed
4 to achieve quantum readiness earlier than 2035.
5 (7) A detailed breakdown of how the funds pro-
6 vided in section 20005(a)(29) of the Act entitled
7 ‘‘An Act to provide for reconciliation pursuant to
8 title II of H. Con. Res. 14’’, approved July 4, 2025
9 (Public Law 119–21) will be allocated and obligated
10 across specific programs, projects, and activities.
11 (8) Any other matter the Secretary of Defense
12 considers relevant.
13 (b) FORM OF STRATEGY.—The strategy required by
14 subsection (a) shall be submitted in unclassified form but
15 may contain a classified annex.
16 (c) BRIEFING.—Not later than 240 days after the
17 date of the enactment of this Act, the Secretary shall, in
18 coordination with the Chief Information Officer, submit
19 to the congressional defense committees a briefing on the
20 strategy required under subsection (a).
21 (d) DEFINITIONS.—In this section:
22 (1) The term ‘‘post-quantum cryptography’’ has
23 the meaning given that term in section 3 of the
24 Quantum Computing Cybersecurity Preparedness
25 Act (Public Law 117–260; 6 U.S.C. 1526 note).
†S 2296 ES

2028
1 (2) The term ‘‘quantum readiness’’ means the
2 state in which an agency’s cryptographic systems
3 have been inventoried, continuously assessed for
4 quantum vulnerabilities, and remediated through the
5 adoption of quantum-resistant cryptographic algo-
6 rithms and other practices.

SEC. 6612. SECURE AND INTEROPERABLE DEFENSE COL-
8
LABORATION TECHNOLOGY.
9 (a) DEFINITIONS.—In this section:
10 (1) CHIEF INFORMATION OFFICER.—The term
11 ‘‘Chief Information Officer’’ means the Chief Infor-
12 mation Officer of the Department of Defense.
13 (2) COLLABORATION TECHNOLOGY.—The term
14 ‘‘collaboration technology’’ means a software system
15 or application that offers 1 or more primary collabo-
16 ration technology features.
17 (3) DEPARTMENT.—The term ‘‘Department’’
18 means the Department of Defense.
19 (4) END-TO-END ENCRYPTION.—The term
20 ‘‘end-to-end encryption’’ means communications
21 encryption in which data is encrypted when being
22 passed through a network such that no party, other
23 than the sender and each intended recipient of the
24 communication, can access the decrypted commu-
25 nication, regardless of the transport technology used
†S 2296 ES

2029
1 and the intermediaries or intermediate steps along
2 the sending path.
3 (5) IDENTIFIED STANDARDS.—The term ‘‘iden-
4 tified standards’’ means the standard, or set of
5 standards, identified under subsection (b)(2).
6 (6) INTEROPERABILITY.—The term ‘‘interoper-
7 ability’’ has the meaning given the term in section
8 3601 of title 44, United States Code.
9 (7) OPEN STANDARD.—The term ‘‘open stand-
10 ard’’ means a standard, or a set of standards,
11 that—
12 (A) is available for any individual to read
13 and implement;
14 (B) does not impose any royalty or other
15 fee for use; and
16 (C) can be certified for low or no cost to
17 users of the standard or set of standards.
18 (8) PRIMARY COLLABORATION TECHNOLOGY
19 FEATURE.—The term ‘‘primary collaboration tech-
20 nology feature’’ means a technology feature or func-
21 tion that—
22 (A) facilitates remote work or collaboration
23 within the Department;
24 (B) facilitates the work or collaboration de-
25 scribed in subparagraph (A) by providing
†S 2296 ES

2030
1 functionality that is core or essential, rather
2 than ancillary or secondary; and
3 (C) is identified by the Chief Information
4 Officer under subsection (b)(1).
5 (9) STANDARDS-COMPATIBLE COLLABORATION
6 TECHNOLOGY.—The term ‘‘standards-compatible col-
7 laboration technology’’ means collaboration tech-
8 nology—
9 (A) each primary collaboration technology
10 feature of which is compatible with the identi-
11 fied standards for such a primary collaboration
12 technology feature; and
13 (B) that has demonstrated compliance
14 under subsection (d)(2).
15 (10) VOLUNTARY CONSENSUS STANDARD.—The
16 term ‘‘voluntary consensus standard’’ has the mean-
17 ing given such term in Circular A–119 of the Office
18 of Management and Budget entitled ‘‘Federal Par-
19 ticipation in the Development and Use of Voluntary
20 Consensus Standards and in Conformity Assessment
21 Activities’’, issued in revised form on January 27,
22 2016.

5 (1) The term ‘‘cloud computing’’ has the mean-
6 ing given such term in section 239.7601 of the De-
7 fense Federal Acquisition Regulation Supplement, or
8 successor regulation.
9 (2) The term ‘‘cloud-based software’’ means a
10 software application, platform, or computational
11 service that is—
12 (A) delivered to end users via internet-
13 based cloud computing infrastructure;
14 (B) hosted, operated, maintained, and con-
15 trolled by a third-party service provider; and
16 (C) accessed remotely by users without re-
17 quiring local installation or deployment of the
18 software on user devices or Department-con-
19 trolled systems.
20 (3) The terms ‘‘Department data’’ and ‘‘De-
21 partment-related data’’ have the meanings given the
22 terms ‘‘Government data’’ and ‘‘Government-related
23 data’’, respectively, in section 239.7601 of the De-
24 fense Federal Acquisition Regulation Supplement, or
†S 2296 ES

2049
1 successor regulation, except in this section, such
2 terms apply only to the Department of Defense.
3 (4) The term ‘‘directly access’’, with respect to
4 a system, software, or data, means—
5 (A) to physically access the system, soft-
6 ware, or data; or
7 (B) to logically access the system, soft-
8 ware, or data, through proxy, virtual, adminis-
9 trative, or programmatic means such that an
10 individual can modify, alter, control, administer,
11 configure, or deploy the system, software, or
12 data.
13 (5) The term ‘‘Five Eyes intelligence-sharing
14 alliance’’ includes the following:
15 (A) The Commonwealth of Australia.
16 (B) Canada.
17 (C) New Zealand.
18 (D) The United Kingdom of Great Britain
19 and Northern Ireland.
20 (E) The United States of America.
21 (6) The term ‘‘foreign country of concern’’ has
22 the meaning given that term in section 9901 of the
23 William M. (Mac) Thornberry National Defense Au-
24 thorization Act for Fiscal Year 2021 (15 U.S.C.
25 4651).
†S 2296 ES

2050
1 (7) The term ‘‘indirectly access’’, with respect
2 to a system, software, or data, means to obtain, re-
3 ceive, collect, or derive information from the system,
4 software, or data regarding technical details, oper-
5 ational characteristics, or security-related attributes,
6 including—
7 (A) system configurations;
8 (B) network architecture;
9 (C) security controls;
10 (D) data schemas;
11 (E) performance metrics; and
12 (F) access logs or other information that
13 could compromise the confidentiality, integrity,
14 or availability of the system, software, or data.

SEC. 8111. SENSE OF CONGRESS ON GROUND-BASED LEG
9
OF NUCLEAR TRIAD.
10 It is the sense of Congress that—
11 (1) the modernization of the ground-based leg
12 of the nuclear triad of the United States is vital to
13 the security of the homeland and a core component
14 of the homeland defense mission;
15 (2) extending the lifecycle of the current Min-
16 uteman III platform is both costly and an
17 unsustainable long-term option for maintaining a
18 ready and capable ground-based leg of the nuclear
19 triad;
20 (3) the breach of chapter 325 of title 10,
21 United States Code (commonly known as the
22 ‘‘Nunn-McCurdy Act’’) by the program to modernize
23 the ground-based leg of the nuclear triad should be
24 addressed in a way that balances the national secu-
25 rity need with fiscally responsible modifications to
†S 2296 ES

2061
1 the program that prevent future unanticipated cost
2 overruns;
3 (4) that breach does not alter the fundamental
4 national security need for the modernization pro-
5 gram; and
6 (5) the modernization program should remain
7 funded and active.

SEC. 301. UNAUTHORIZED ACCESS TO INTELLIGENCE COM-
12
MUNITY PROPERTY.
13 (a) IN GENERAL.—The National Security Act of
14 1947 (50 U.S.C. 3001 et seq.) is amended by adding at
15 the end the following:
16
‘‘SEC. 1115. UNAUTHORIZED ACCESS TO INTELLIGENCE
17
COMMUNITY PROPERTY.
18 ‘‘(a) IN GENERAL.—It shall be unlawful, within the
19 jurisdiction of the United States, without authorization to
20 willfully go upon any property, while knowing that such
21 property is—
22 ‘‘(1) under the jurisdiction of an element of the
23 intelligence community; and
24 ‘‘(2) closed or restricted.
†S 2296 ES

2068
1 ‘‘(b) PENALTIES.—Any person who violates sub-
2 section (a) with intent to gather intelligence or informa-
3 tion to the detriment of the United States shall—
4 ‘‘(1) in the case of the first offense, be fined
5 under section 3517 of title 18, United States Code,
6 imprisoned not more than 6 months, or both;
7 ‘‘(2) in the case of a second offense after a
8 prior conviction under subsection (a) has become
9 final, be fined under such title, imprisoned not more
10 than 2 years, or both; and
11 ‘‘(3) in the case of a third or subsequent of-
12 fense after a prior conviction under subsection (a)
13 has become final, be fined under such title, impris-
14 oned not more than 5 years, or both.’’.
15 (b) CLERICAL AMENDMENT.—The table of contents
16 preceding section 2 of such Act is amended by adding at
17 the end the following:
‘‘Sec. 1115. Unauthorized access to intelligence community property.’’.
18
SEC. 302. ANNUAL SURVEY OF ANALYTIC OBJECTIVITY
19
AMONG OFFICERS AND EMPLOYEES OF ELE-
20
MENTS OF THE INTELLIGENCE COMMUNITY.
21 (a) IN GENERAL.—Not less frequently than once
22 each year, each head of an element of the intelligence com-
23 munity specified in subsection (c) shall—
24 (1) conduct a survey of analytic objectivity
25 among officers and employees of the element of the
†S 2296 ES

2069
1 head who are involved in the production of intel-
2 ligence products; and
3 (2) submit to the congressional intelligence
4 committees a report on the findings of the head with
5 respect to the most recently completed survey under
6 paragraph (1).
7 (b) ELEMENTS.—Each survey conducted pursuant to
8 subsection (a)(1) for an element of the intelligence com-
9 munity shall cover the following:
10 (1) Perceptions of the officers and employees
11 regarding the presence of bias or politicization af-
12 fecting the intelligence cycle.
13 (2) Types of intelligence products perceived by
14 the officers and employees as most prone to objec-
15 tivity concerns.
16 (3) Whether objectivity concerns identified by
17 responders to the survey were otherwise raised with
18 an analytic ombudsman or appropriate entity.
19 (c) ELEMENTS OF THE INTELLIGENCE COMMUNITY
20 SPECIFIED.—The elements of the intelligence community
21 specified in this subsection are the following:
22 (1) The National Security Agency.
23 (2) The Defense Intelligence Agency.
24 (3) The National Geospatial-Intelligence Agen-
25 cy.
†S 2296 ES

2070
1 (4) Each intelligence element of the Army, the
2 Navy, the Air Force, the Marine Corps, the Space
3 Force, and the Coast Guard.
4 (5) The Directorate of Intelligence of the Fed-
5 eral Bureau of Investigation.
6 (6) The Office of Intelligence and Counterintel-
7 ligence of the Department of Energy.
8 (7) The Bureau of Intelligence and Research of
9 the Department of State.
10 (8) The Office of Intelligence and Analysis of
11 the Department of Homeland Security.
12 (9) The Office of Intelligence and Analysis of
13 the Department of the Treasury.

SEC. 314. PROHIBITION ON CONTRACTORS COLLECTING OR
17
SELLING LOCATION DATA OF INDIVIDUALS
18
AT INTELLIGENCE COMMUNITY LOCATIONS.
19 (a) PROHIBITION.—A contractor or subcontractor of
20 an element of the intelligence community, as a condition
21 on contracting with an element of the intelligence commu-
22 nity, may not, while a contract or subcontract for an ele-
23 ment of the intelligence community is effective—
24 (1) collect, retain, or knowingly or recklessly fa-
25 cilitate the collection or retention of location data
†S 2296 ES

2090
1 from phones, wearable fitness trackers, and other
2 cellular-enabled or cellular-connected devices located
3 in any covered location, regardless of whether service
4 for such device is provided under contract with an
5 element of the intelligence community, except as nec-
6 essary for the provision of the service as specifically
7 contracted; or
8 (2) sell, monetize, or knowingly or recklessly fa-
9 cilitate the sale of, location data described in para-
10 graph (1) to any individual or entity that is not an
11 element of the intelligence community.
12 (b) COVERED LOCATIONS.—For purposes of sub-
13 section (a), a covered location is any location described
14 in section 202.222(a)(1) of title 28, Code of Federal Regu-
15 lations, or successor regulations.
16 (c) CERTIFICATION.—Not later than 60 days after
17 the date of the enactment of this Act, each head of an
18 element of the intelligence community shall require each
19 contractor and subcontractor of the element to submit to
20 the head a certification as to whether the contractor or
21 subcontractor is in compliance with subsection (a).
22 (d) TREATMENT OF CERTIFICATIONS.—The veracity
23 of a certification under subsection (c) shall be treated as
24 ‘‘material’’ for purposes of section 3729 of title 31, United
25 States Code.
†S 2296 ES

2091

SEC. 316. THREAT BRIEFING TO PROTECT FEDERAL RE-
8
SERVE INFORMATION.
9 The Director of National Intelligence, in coordination
10 with the Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation,
11 and in consultation with the relevant heads of the elements
12 of the intelligence community, as determined by the Direc-
13 tors, shall brief the Board of Governors of the Federal
14 Reserve System on foreign threats to the Federal Reserve
15 System.
16

20 policies, procedures, manuals, circulars, courses, training,

25 be appropriated by any law for the National Intelligence

1 Program shall be used for the purposes of implementing
2 covered practices in the intelligence community.
3 (c) COVERED PRACTICE DEFINED.—In this section,
4 the term ‘‘covered practice’’ means any practice that dis-
5 criminates for or against any person in a manner prohib-
6 ited by the Constitution of the United States, the Civil
7 Rights Act of 1964 (42 U.S.C. 2000 et seq.), or any other
8 Federal law.

14
‘‘SEC. 119B. NATIONAL INTELLIGENCE TASK FORCES.
15 ‘‘(a) AUTHORITY TO CONVENE.—The Director of Na-
16 tional Intelligence may convene 1 or more national intel-
17 ligence task forces, as the Director considers necessary,
18 to address intelligence priorities.
19 ‘‘(b) TASK FORCE AUTHORITIES.—Pursuant to the
20 direction of the Director of National Intelligence, a na-
21 tional intelligence task force convened under subsection
22 (a) may—
23 ‘‘(1) be comprised of select employees of ele-
24 ments of the intelligence community, other than the
25 Office of the Director of National Intelligence, as de-
†S 2296 ES

2132
1 termined by the Director of National Intelligence to
2 be necessary and appropriate for the task force;
3 ‘‘(2) convene at the Office of the Director of
4 National Intelligence for a limited time in support of
5 a specific intelligence matter recognized by the Di-
6 rector; and
7 ‘‘(3) be dissolved by the Director of National
8 Intelligence not later than 540 days after the conclu-
9 sion of support to a specific intelligence matter.
10 ‘‘(c) TRANSFER OF RESPONSIBILITY.—If the specific
11 intelligence matter a national intelligence task force has
12 been convened to support has not concluded within 540
13 days after the establishment of the task force, the Director
14 shall transfer responsibility for supporting the intelligence
15 matter to a specific element of the intelligence community.
16 ‘‘(d) COMPENSATION.—Employees of elements of the
17 intelligence community participating in a national intel-
18 ligence task force pursuant to subsection (b)(1) shall con-
19 tinue to receive compensation from their agency of employ-
20 ment.
21 ‘‘(e) CONGRESSIONAL NOTIFICATION.—
22 ‘‘(1) NOTIFICATION REQUIRED.—In any case in
23 which a national intelligence task force convened
24 under subsection (a) is in effect for a period of more
25 than 60 days, the Director of National Intelligence
†S 2296 ES

2133
1 shall, not later than 61 days after the date of the
2 convening of the task force, submit to the congres-
3 sional intelligence committees notice regarding the
4 task force.
5 ‘‘(2) CONTENTS.—A notice regarding a national
6 intelligence task force submitted pursuant to para-
7 graph (1) shall include the following:
8 ‘‘(A) The number of personnel of the intel-
9 ligence community participating in the task
10 force.
11 ‘‘(B) A list of the elements of the intel-
12 ligence community that are employing the per-
13 sonnel described in subparagraph (A).
14 ‘‘(C) Identification of the specific intel-
15 ligence matter the task force was convened to
16 support.
17 ‘‘(D) An approximate date by which the
18 task force will be dissolved.’’.

SEC. 502. ENHANCED INTELLIGENCE SHARING RELATING
4
TO FOREIGN ADVERSARY BIOTECHNO-
5
LOGICAL THREATS.
6 (a) IN GENERAL.—Not later than 90 days after the
7 date of the enactment of this Act, the Director of National
8 Intelligence, in consultation with such other heads of ele-
9 ments of the intelligence community as the Director con-
10 siders appropriate, shall establish and submit to the con-
11 gressional intelligence committees, the Committee on
12 Homeland Security and Governmental Affairs of the Sen-
13 ate, and the Committee on Homeland Security of the
14 House of Representatives a policy for streamlining the de-
15 classification or downgrading and sharing of intelligence
16 information relating to biotechnological developments and
17 threats in order to counter efforts by foreign adversaries
18 to weaponize biotechnologies and biological weapons, in-
19 cluding threats relating to military, industrial, agricul-
20 tural, and health applications of biotechnology.
21 (b) ELEMENTS.—The plan required by subsection (a)
22 shall include mechanisms for sharing the information de-
23 scribed in such subsection—
24 (1) with allies and partners;
25 (2) with private sector partners; and
†S 2296 ES

2140
1 (3) across the Federal Government.
2 (c) REPORTING.— Not later than 1 year after the
3 date of the enactment of this Act, and annually thereafter
4 for 2 years, the Director shall submit to the committees
5 specified in subsection (a) a report on progress sharing
6 information with recipients under subsection (b).

SEC. 511. COUNTERING CHINESE COMMUNIST PARTY EF-
4
FORTS THAT THREATEN EUROPE.
5 (a) STRATEGY REQUIRED.—Not later than 120 days
6 after the date of the enactment of this Act, the President,
7 acting through the National Security Council, shall de-
8 velop an interagency strategy to counter the efforts of the
9 Chinese Communist Party to expand its economic, mili-
10 tary, and ideological influence in Europe.
11 (b) ELEMENTS.—The strategy required by subsection
12 (a) shall include the following:
13 (1) An assessment of the current efforts by the
14 intelligence community to brief members of the
15 North Atlantic Treaty Organization on intelligence
16 and influence activities by the Chinese Communist
17 Party in Europe, including the following:
18 (A) Any support by the Chinese Com-
19 munist Party to the economy and defense in-
20 dustrial base of the Russian Federation.
21 (B) Any provision of lethal assistance to
22 the Russian army by the Chinese Communist
23 Party.
24 (C) Any cyber operations by the Chinese
25 Communist Party to gain the ability to re-
†S 2296 ES

2147
1 motely shut down critical infrastructure in Eu-
2 rope.
3 (D) Any influence operations by the Chi-
4 nese Communist Party to sway European public
5 opinion.
6 (E) Any use by the Chinese Communist
7 Party of economic coercion and weaponization
8 of economic ties to members of the North At-
9 lantic Treaty Organization for political gain.
10 (2) A strategic plan to counter the influence of
11 the Chinese Communist Party in Europe that in-
12 cludes proposals for actions by the United States, in-
13 cluding the following:
14 (A) Robust intelligence sharing with Euro-
15 pean allies in the areas described in paragraph
16 (1), and an identification of additional capabili-
17 ties and resources needed for such intelligence
18 sharing.
19 (B) Engagement with European allies re-
20 garding coordinated sanctions and export con-
21 trol actions, including compliance with existing
22 and future sanctions and export controls, de-
23 signed to deter and undermine the ongoing sup-
24 port of the People’s Republic of China for the
†S 2296 ES

2148
1 defense industrial base of the Russian Federa-
2 tion.
3 (C) Actions required by the United States
4 Government to support United States and allied
5 country businesses to provide competitive alter-
6 natives to Chinese bids in the following Euro-
7 pean sectors:
8 (i) Energy
9 (ii) Telecommunications.
10 (iii) Defense
11 (iv) Finance.
12 (v) Ports and other critical infrastruc-
13 ture.
14 (D) Assistance to European governments
15 in passing legislation or enforcing regulations
16 that protect European academic institutions,
17 think tanks, research entities, and nongovern-
18 mental organizations from efforts by the United
19 Front Work Department of the Chinese Com-
20 munist Party to normalize talking points and
21 propaganda of the Chinese Communist Party.
22 (E) Any other action the President deter-
23 mines is necessary to counter the Chinese Com-
24 munist Party in Europe.
25 (c) SUBMISSION TO CONGRESS.—

SEC. 512. PROHIBITION ON INTELLIGENCE COMMUNITY
2
CONTRACTING WITH CHINESE MILITARY
3
COMPANIES ENGAGED IN BIOTECHNOLOGY
4
RESEARCH, DEVELOPMENT, OR MANUFAC-
5
TURING.
6 (a) DEFINITIONS.—In this section:
7 (1) 1260H LIST.—The term ‘‘1260H list’’
8 means the list of Chinese military companies oper-
9 ating in the United States most recently submitted
10 under section 1260H(b)(1) of the William M. (Mac)
11 Thornberry National Defense Authorization Act for
12 Fiscal Year 2021 (10 U.S.C. 113 note; Public Law
13 116–283).
14 (2) AFFILIATE.—The term ‘‘affiliate’’ means an
15 entity that directly or indirectly controls, is con-
16 trolled by, or is under common control with another
17 entity.
18 (3) BIOTECHNOLOGY.—The term ‘‘bio-
19 technology’’ means the use of biological processes,
20 organisms, or systems for manufacturing, research,
21 or medical purposes, including genetic engineering,
22 synthetic biology, and bioinformatics.
23 (b) PROHIBITION.—Subject to subsections (d) and
24 (e), a head of an element of the intelligence community
25 may not enter into, renew, or extend any contract for a
26 good or service with—
†S 2296 ES

2151
1 (1) any entity listed on the 1260H list that is
2 engaged in biotechnology research, development,
3 manufacturing, or related activities;
4 (2) any entity that is an affiliate, subsidiary, or
5 parent company of a biotechnology company in-
6 cluded on the 1260H list;
7 (3) any entity that has a known joint venture,
8 partnership, or contractual relationship with a bio-
9 technology company included on the 1260H list,
10 where such relationship presents a risk to national
11 security as determined by the Director of National
12 Intelligence; or
13 (4) any entity that is engaged in biotechnology
14 research, development, manufacturing, or related ac-
15 tivities and deemed to be a threat to national secu-
16 rity as determined by the Director.
17 (c) IMPLEMENTATION AND COMPLIANCE.—The Di-
18 rector of National Intelligence shall—
19 (1) establish guidelines for determining affili-
20 ation and contractual relationships under this sec-
21 tion;
22 (2) maintain a publicly available list of bio-
23 technology companies and affiliates with whom con-
24 tracting is prohibited under subsection (b);
†S 2296 ES

2152
1 (3) require that each head of an element of the
2 intelligence community ensure that the contractors
3 and subcontractors engaged by the element certify
4 that they are not engaged in a contract for a good
5 or service with an entity included on the 1260H list
6 that is engaged in biotechnology research, develop-
7 ment, manufacturing, or a related activity; and
8 (4) conduct regular audits to ensure compliance
9 with subsection (b).
10 (d) WAIVER AUTHORITY.—
11 (1) IN GENERAL.—The Director of National In-
12 telligence may waive the prohibition under sub-
13 section (b) for a procurement on a case-by-case basis
14 if the Director determines, in writing, that—
15 (A) the procurement is essential for na-
16 tional security and no reasonable alternative
17 source exists; and
18 (B) appropriate measures are in place to
19 mitigate risks associated with the procurement.
20 (2) CONGRESSIONAL NOTIFICATION.—For each
21 waiver for a procurement issued under subsection
22 (b), the Director shall, not later than 30 days after
23 issuing the waiver, submit to the congressional intel-
24 ligence committees, the Committee on Appropria-
25 tions of the Senate, and the Committee on Appro-
†S 2296 ES

2153
1 priations of the House of Representatives a notice of
2 the waiver, which shall include a justification for the
3 waiver and a description of the risk mitigation meas-
4 ures implemented for the procurement.
5 (e) EXCEPTIONS.—The prohibitions under subsection
6 (b) shall not apply to—
7 (1) the acquisition or provision of health care
8 services overseas for—
9 (A) employees of the United States, includ-
10 ing members of the uniformed services (as de-
11 fined in section 101(a) of title 10, United
12 States Code), whose official duty stations are
13 located overseas or who are on permissive tem-
14 porary duty travel overseas; or
15 (B) employees of contractors or sub-
16 contractors of the United States—
17 (i) who are performing under a con-
18 tract that directly supports the missions or
19 activities of individuals described in sub-
20 paragraph (A); and
21 (ii) whose primary duty stations are
22 located overseas or who are on permissive
23 temporary duty travel overseas; or
†S 2296 ES

2154
1 (2) the acquisition, use, or distribution of
2 human multiomic data, lawfully compiled, that is
3 commercially or publicly available.
4 (f) EFFECTIVE DATE.—This section shall take effect
5 on the date that is 60 days after the date of the enactment
6 of this Act.
7 (g) SUNSET.—The provisions of this section shall ter-
8 minate on the date that is 10 years after the date of the
9 enactment of this Act.

10 Committee.

1 (C) an alien lawfully admitted for perma-

4 ible and specific information indicating an impending

7 Republic of Iran or an Iranian proxy, an element of the
8 intelligence community must immediately notify the Direc-
9 tor of the Federal Bureau of Investigation and, if the in-
10 tended victim is under protection of a government entity,
11 any persons responsible for protecting that individual of
12 such information.
13 (c) WARNING; TRANSMISSION TO CONGRESS.—Not
14 later than 48 hours after receiving a notification pursuant
15 to subsection (b), the Director of the Federal Bureau of
16 Investigation shall—
17 (1) warn the intended victim, or any persons re-
18 sponsible for protecting the intended victim, of the
19 impending threat;

21 sion of the information, consistent with the protec-
22 tion of sources and methods; and
23 (3) provide the information received pursuant
24 to subsection (b) to the appropriate congressional

SEC. 601. INTELLIGENCE COMMUNITY TECHNOLOGY
11

12 (a) DEFINITIONS.—In this section:

17 under section 501(a) of such Code.
18 (2) WORK PROGRAM.—The term ‘‘work pro-
19 gram’’ means any agreement between In-Q-Tel and
20 a third-party company, where such third-party com-
21 pany furnishes or is furnishing a product or service
22 for use by any government customer of In-Q-Tel to
23 address the technology needs or requirements of
24 such customer.
†S 2296 ES

2175
1 (b) ESTABLISHMENT OF PROGRAM.—There is estab-
2 lished in the Office of the Director of National Intelligence
3 a program to be known as the ‘‘Intelligence Community
4 Technology Bridge Program’’ (in this subsection referred
5 to as the ‘‘Program’’) to assist in the transitioning of
6 products or services from the research and development
7 phase to the prototype or production phase, subject to the
8 extent and in such amounts as specifically provided in ad-
9 vance in appropriations Acts for such purposes .
10 (c) PROVISION OF ASSISTANCE.—

12 the Director shall, in consultation with In-Q-Tel,
13 carry out the Program by providing assistance to a

15 transitioning a product or service to the prototype or
16 production phase, as a means of advancing govern-
17 ment acquisitions of the product or service.
18 (2) TYPES OF ASSISTANCE.—Assistance under
19 paragraph (1) may be provided in the form of a
20 grant or a payment for a product or service.
21 (3) REQUIREMENTS FOR ASSISTANCE.—Assist-

21

†S 2296 ES

2184
1 siders appropriate, shall establish a policy to ensure that
2 elements of the intelligence community may not contract
3 with Chinese biotechnology suppliers that are determined
4 by the Director to pose a security threat.
5 (b) ELEMENTS.—The policy required by subsection
6 (a) shall include that an element of the intelligence com-
7 munity may not procure or obtain any product made using
8 synthetic DNA or RNA unless—

11 (2) all significant processing of the product oc-
12 curs in the United States; and
13 (3) all or nearly all ingredients or components
14 of the product are made and sourced in the United
15 States.
16 (c) WAIVER.—The Director of National Intelligence
17 may waive the application of the policy required by sub-
18 section (a) to allow purchases prohibited by such policy
19 if the purpose of such a purchase fulfills a national secu-
20 rity need.

10 tection of intelligence sources and methods, for any artifi-
11 cial intelligence system or function identified pursuant to

14 icy to promote the sharing of any custom-developed code,

18 tems or functions.

2192
1 rights to all Federal data and the retention of the

6 FORMATION.—Each head of an element of the intel-
7 ligence community shall consider contractual terms
8 that protect Federal information used by vendors in
9 the development and operation of artificial intel-
10 ligence products and services procured by the ele-
11 ment, including limitations on the re-use of derived
12 information for products or services sold to foreign
13 governments by such vendors.
14 (3) LIMITATIONS ON USE OF DATA TO TRAIN

17 clude terms in the contracts in which the elements
18 are parties to protect intelligence community data
19 from being used to train or improve the functionality
20 of a vendor’s commercial offerings without express
21 permission from the head.

23 tion Officer of the Intelligence Community shall provide

†S 2296 ES

2193
1 elements to prevent vendor lock-in, as well as the adoption
2 of procurement practices that encourage competition to
3 sustain a robust marketplace for artificial intelligence
4 products and services, including through contractual pref-
5 erences for interoperable artificial intelligence products
6 and services.
7 (e) TRACKING AND EVALUATING PERFORMANCE.—
8 Each head of an element of the intelligence community
9 shall track and evaluate performance of procured and ele-
10 ment-developed artificial intelligence by—
11 (1) documenting known capabilities and limita-
12 tions of the artificial intelligence system and any
13 guidelines on how the artificial intelligence is in-
14 tended to be used;
15 (2) documenting provenance of the data used to

17 system;
18 (3) conducting ongoing testing and validation
19 on artificial intelligence system performance, the ef-
20 fectiveness of vendor artificial intelligence offerings,

22 by testing in real-world conditions;
23 (4) assessing for overfitting to known test data,
24 ensuring that artificial intelligence developers or ven-
†S 2296 ES

2194
1 dors are not directly relying on the test data to train
2 their artificial intelligence systems;
3 (5) considering contractual terms that prioritize

5 toring, and evaluation of effectiveness of procured

7 (6) stipulating conditions for retraining or de-
8 commissioning artificial intelligence models; and
9 (7) requiring sufficient post-award monitoring
10 and evaluation of effectiveness of the artificial intel-
11 ligence system, where appropriate in the context of

SEC. 609. HIGH-IMPACT ARTIFICIAL INTELLIGENCE SYS-
14
TEMS.
15 (a) DEFINITION OF USE CASE.—In this section, the
16 term ‘‘use case’’, with respect to an artificial intelligence
17 system, means the specific mission being performed
18 through the use of an artificial intelligence system.
19 (b) GUIDANCE REGARDING DEFINITIONS OF HIGH-
20 IMPACT ARTIFICIAL INTELLIGENCE.—Not later than 30
21 days after the date of the enactment of this Act, the Direc-
22 tor of National Intelligence shall issue guidance to the
23 heads of elements of the intelligence community to ensure
24 consistency and accuracy in each element’s interpretation
25 of the definition of high-impact artificial intelligence sys-
†S 2296 ES

2195
1 tems and high-impact artificial intelligence use cases to
2 apply to each element’s respective missions.
3 (c) INVENTORY OF HIGH-IMPACT ARTIFICIAL INTEL-
4 LIGENCE USE CASES.—
5 (1) IN GENERAL.—Each head of an element of
6 the intelligence community shall maintain an annual
7 inventory of high-impact artificial intelligence use
8 cases, including detailed information on the specific
9 artificial intelligence systems associated with such
10 uses.
11 (2) SUBMITTAL TO CONGRESS.—Not less fre-
12 quently than once each year, each head of an ele-
13 ment of the intelligence community shall submit to
14 the congressional intelligence committees the inven-
15 tory maintained by the head pursuant to paragraph
16 (1).
17 (d) GUIDANCE TO MAINTAIN MINIMUM STAND-
18 ARDS.—The Director of National Intelligence shall, in co-
19 ordination with the heads of the elements of the intel-
20 ligence community, issue guidance to ensure elements of
21 the intelligence community utilizing high-impact artificial
22 intelligence systems or executing high-impact artificial in-
23 telligence use cases maintain minimum standards for the
24 following:
25 (1) Whistleblower protections.
†S 2296 ES

2196
1 (2) Risk management practices and policies.
2 (3) Performance expectations to ensure high-
3 impact artificial intelligence systems or high-impact
4 artificial intelligence use cases are subject to policies
5 that ensure they continue to perform as expected
6 over time or be discontinued, including—
7 (A) continuous monitoring;
8 (B) independent testing by a reviewer or
9 team of reviewers within the element that have
10 not been involved in the development or pro-
11 curement of such artificial intelligence system;
12 and
13 (C) cost analyses, supported by a summary
14 of direct costs associated and expected savings,
15 if applicable, relative to existing or feasible
16 human-led alternatives.
17 (4) Pre-deployment requirements to ensure
18 high-impact artificial intelligence systems or high-
19 impact artificial intelligence use cases document—
20 (A) the advantages and risks of using such
21 capability, to include appropriate legal and pol-
22 icy safeguards;
23 (B) the cost of operating such a capability;
†S 2296 ES

2197
1 (C) a schedule to ensure such capability is
2 periodically reevaluated for efficacy and per-
3 formance; and
4 (D) the oversight and compliance mecha-
5 nisms in place for reviewing the use and output
6 of such capability.
7 (5) Policies to ensure appropriate human over-
8 sight and training.

SEC. 611. REVISION OF INTERIM GUIDANCE REGARDING
8
ACQUISITION AND USE OF FOUNDATION
9
MODELS.
10 (a) SENSE OF CONGRESS.—It is the sense of Con-
11 gress that the evaluation of training data, methods of la-
12 beling data, and model weights pertaining to artificial in-
13 telligence systems being considered for use by an element
14 of the intelligence community does not constitute collec-
15 tion by such element of the intelligence community.
16 (b) IN GENERAL.—The Director of National Intel-
17 ligence, in coordination with the Attorney General, shall
18 revise the interim guidance of the intelligence community
19 entitled ‘‘Regarding the Acquisition and Use of Founda-
20 tion Models’’ to include the following:
21 (1) Guidance stipulating that the consideration
22 by an element of the intelligence community of ac-
23 quisition of a foundation model should involve con-
24 sideration of the data upon which the model was
25 trained on. Any element of the intelligence commu-
†S 2296 ES

2201
1 nity evaluating whether to acquire a foundation
2 model for a potential intelligence use shall request or
3 otherwise lawfully gather pertinent information on
4 sources of training data and methods of data label-
5 ing, including any functions carried out by third
6 party vendors, in order to make informed decisions
7 on what mitigation practices or other relevant dis-
8 semination, usage, or retention measures may be ap-
9 plicable to that element’s future adoption of the
10 foundation model under consideration.
11 (2) Guidance stipulating that each element of
12 the intelligence community shall to the greatest ex-
13 tent practicable avoid use of publicly available mod-
14 els found to contain information obtained unlawfully
15 by a model vendor.

12 CLEARANCES.—The Director of National Intelligence

22 nity for a period of not more than 5 years and who was
23 eligible to access classified information on the day before
24 the individual retired or otherwise separated, could, as a
25 matter of policy, be granted eligibility by the Director to
26 access classified information as long as—
†S 2296 ES

2206
1 (1) there is no indication the individual no
2 longer satisfies the standards established for access
3 to classified information;
4 (2) the individual certifies in writing to an ap-
5 propriate security professional that there has been
6 no change in the relevant information provided for
7 the last background investigation of the individual;
8 and
9 (3) an appropriate record check reveals no un-
10 favorable information.

21 Intelligence shall, in coordination with such heads of ele-
22 ments of the intelligence community as the Director con-
23 siders appropriate, develop and issue standard guidelines
24 for personnel of the intelligence community to report and
25 properly document anomalous health incidents.
†S 2296 ES

2213

3 quired by subsection (a), the Director shall ensure that
4 such standard guidelines are as similar as practicable to
5 guidelines issued by the Secretary of Defense for personnel
6 of the Department of Defense to report and properly docu-
7 ment anomalous health incidents.
8 (c) SUBMISSION.—Not later than 10 days after the
9 date on which the Director issues the standard guidelines
10 required by subsection (a), the Director shall provide the
11 congressional intelligence committees with the standard
12 guidelines, including a statement describing the implemen-
13 tation of such standard guidelines, how the standard
14 guidelines differ from those issued by the Secretary, and
15 the justifications for such differences.

SEC. 802. REVIEW AND DECLASSIFICATION OF INTEL-
17
LIGENCE RELATING TO ANOMALOUS HEALTH
18
INCIDENTS.
19 (a) REVIEW.—
20 (1) IN GENERAL.—Not later than 90 days after
21 the date of the enactment of this Act, the Director
22 of National Intelligence, in consultation with the
23 Secretary of Defense, shall initiate a review of hold-
24 ings of the intelligence community regarding anoma-
25 lous health incidents.
†S 2296 ES

2214
1 (2) ELEMENTS.—The review initiated pursuant
2 to paragraph (1) shall cover the following:
3 (A) Reports of anomalous health incidents
4 affecting personnel of the United States Gov-
5 ernment and dependents of such personnel.
6 (B) Reports of other incidents affecting
7 personnel of the United States Government that
8 have known causes that result in symptoms
9 similar to those observed in anomalous health
10 incidents.
11 (C) Information regarding efforts by for-
12 eign governments to covertly develop or deploy
13 weapons and technology that could cause any or
14 all symptoms observed in reported anomalous
15 health incidents.
16 (D) Assessment of the success of the intel-
17 ligence community in detecting clandestine
18 weapons programs of foreign governments.
19 (b) DECLASSIFICATION.—Not later than 180 days
20 after the date of the enactment of this Act, the Director
21 shall perform a declassification review of all intelligence
22 relating to anomalous health incidents reviewed pursuant
23 to subsection (a).
24 (c) PUBLICATION.—
†S 2296 ES

2215
1 (1) IN GENERAL.—The Director shall provide
2 for public release of a declassified report that con-

4 classification review required by subsection (b) on

6 Intelligence.
7 (2) FORM OF REPORT.—The report required by
8 paragraph (1) may include only such redactions as
9 the Director determines necessary to protect sources
10 and methods and information of United States per-
11 sons.

†S 2296 ES

5 CERN.—The term ‘‘governments or companies of
6 concern’’ means a government described in subpara-
7 graph (A) of section 989(h)(2) of title 10, United
8 States Code, or a company, entity, or other person
9 described in subparagraph (B) of such section.

11 for Intelligence and Security shall issue appropriate policy
12 to require the military departments to conduct counter-
13 intelligence briefings for members of the Armed Forces as
14 part of the process required by section 989(c) of title 10,
15 United States Code.
16 (c) ELEMENTS.—Each briefing provided under sub-
17 section (b) shall provide members of the Armed Forces—
18 (1) with awareness of methods commonly used
19 by governments and companies of concern to solicit
20 and learn from covered individuals sensitive military
21 techniques, tactics, and procedures of the Armed
22 Forces;
23 (2) recommended practices for covered individ-
24 uals to avoid a covered activity that could subject
25 the members to civil or criminal penalties;
†S 2296 ES

2220
1 (3) the contact information for the counterintel-
2 ligence authorities to whom covered individuals
3 should report attempted recruitment or a related
4 suspicious contact; and
5 (4) an overview of the prohibition and penalties
6 under subsections (a) and (c) of section 989 of title
7 10, United States Code.
8 (d) PROVISION OF BRIEFINGS AT CERTAIN
9 TRAININGS.—The Under Secretary may mandate the
10 briefings required by subsection (b) during the trainings
11 required by Department of Defense Directive 5240.06 (re-
12 lating to counterintelligence awareness and reporting), or
13 successor document.
