SEC. 5106. PROMOTING REUTILIZATION OF LANGUAGE
15
SKILLS IN THE FOREIGN SERVICE.
16 (a) SENSE OF CONGRESS.—It is the sense of Con-
17 gress that—
18 (1) foreign language skills are essential to effec-
19 tive diplomacy, particularly in high-priority posi-
20 tions, such as Chinese- and Russian-language des-
21 ignated positions focused on the People’s Republic of
22 China and Russia;
23 (2) reutilization of acquired language skills cre-
24 ates efficiencies through the reduction of language
25 training overall and increases regional expertise;
†S 2296 ES

3039
1 (3) often, investments in language skills are not
2 sufficiently utilized and maintained throughout the
3 careers of members of the Foreign Service following
4 an initial assignment after language training;
5 (4) providing incentives or requirements to se-
6 lect ‘‘out-year bidders’’ for priority language-des-
7 ignated assignments would decrease training costs
8 overall and encourage more expertise in relevant pri-
9 ority areas; and
10 (5) incentives for members of the Foreign Serv-
11 ice to not only acquire and retain, but reuse, foreign
12 language skills in priority assignments would reduce
13 training costs in terms of both time and money and
14 increase regional expertise to improve abilities in
15 those areas deemed high priority by the Secretary.
16 (b) INCENTIVES TO REUTILIZE LANGUAGE
17 SKILLS.—Section 704(b)(3) of the Foreign Service Act of
18 1980 (22 U.S.C. 4024(b)(3)) is amended by inserting
19 ‘‘and reutilize’’ after ‘‘to acquire or retain proficiency in’’.

SEC. 5202. SUPPORT FOR CONGRESSIONAL DELEGATIONS.
2 (a) SENSE OF CONGRESS.—It is the sense of Con-
3 gress that—
4 (1) congressional travel is essential to fostering
5 international relations, understanding global issues
6 first-hand, and jointly advancing United States in-
7 terests abroad; and
8 (2) only in close coordination and thanks to the
9 dedication of personnel at United States embassies,
10 consulates, and other missions abroad can the suc-
11 cess of these vital trips be possible.
12 (b) IN GENERAL.—Consistent with applicable laws
13 and the Secretary of State’s security responsibilities, the
14 Secretary shall reaffirm to all diplomatic posts the impor-
15 tance of congressional travel and shall direct all such posts
16 to support congressional travel by members and staff of
17 the appropriate congressional committees to the extent
18 feasible considering capacity and security considerations,
19 when authorized by applicable congressional travel proce-
20 dures to include the congressional authorization letter and
21 congressional travel legislation and policies. The Secretary
22 shall reaffirm the Department’s policies to support such
23 travel by members and staff of the appropriate congres-
24 sional committees, by making such support available on
25 any day of the week, including Federal and local holidays
26 when required to complete congressional responsibilities
†S 2296 ES

3042
1 and, to the extent practical, requiring the direct involve-
2 ment of mid-level or senior officers.
3 (c) EXCEPTION FOR SIMULTANEOUS HIGH-LEVEL
4 VISITS.—The requirement under subsection (b) does not
5 apply in the case of a simultaneous visit from the Presi-
6 dent, the First Lady or First Gentleman, the Vice Presi-
7 dent, the Secretary of State, or the Secretary of Defense.
8 (d) TRAINING.—The Secretary shall require all des-
9 ignated control officers to have been trained on supporting
10 congressional travel at posts abroad prior to the assigned

SEC. 5207. NOTIFICATION OF INTENT TO REDUCE PER-
23

25 (b), not later than 30 days before the date on which the
†S 2296 ES

3047
1 Secretary of State carries out a reduction in United States
2 Foreign Service personnel of at least 10 percent at a cov-

4 propriate Congressional committees a notification of the
5 intent to carry out such a reduction, which shall include
6 a certification by the Secretary that such reduction will
7 not negatively impact the ability of the United States to
8 compete with the People’s Republic of China or the Rus-
9 sian Federation.
10 (b) EXCEPTION.—Subsection (a) shall not apply in
11 the case of a security risk to personnel at a covered diplo-
12 matic post.
13 (c) COVERED DIPLOMATIC POST DEFINED.—In this
14 section, the term ‘‘covered diplomatic post’’ means a
15 United States diplomatic post in a country in which the
16 People’s Republic of China or the Russian Federation also
17 have a diplomatic post.

SEC. 5305. COMMERCIAL SPYWARE.
20 (a) SENSE OF CONGRESS.—It is the sense of Con-
21 gress that—
22 (1) there is a national security need for the le-
23 gitimate and responsible procurement and applica-
24 tion of cyber intrusion capabilities, including efforts
†S 2296 ES

3058
1 related to counterterrorism, counternarcotics, and
2 countertrafficking;
3 (2) the growing commercial market for sophisti-
4 cated cyber intrusion capabilities has enhanced state
5 and non-state actors’ abilities to target and track for
6 nefarious purposes individuals, such as journalists,
7 human rights defenders, members of civil society
8 groups, members of ethnic or religious minority
9 groups, and others for exercising their human rights
10 and fundamental freedoms, or the family members
11 of these targeted individuals;
12 (3) the proliferation of commercial spyware pre-
13 sents significant and growing risks to United States
14 national security, including to the safety and secu-
15 rity of United States Government personnel; and
16 (4) ease of access into and lack of transparency
17 in the commercial spyware market raises the prob-
18 ability of spreading potentially destructive or disrup-
19 tive cyber capabilities to a wider range of malicious
20 actors.
21 (b) STATEMENT OF POLICY.—It is the policy of the
22 United States—
23 (1) to oppose the misuse of commercial spyware
24 to target individuals, including journalists, defenders
25 of internationally recognized human rights, and
†S 2296 ES

3059
1 members of civil society groups, members of ethnic
2 or religious minority groups, and others for exer-
3 cising their internationally recognized human rights
4 and fundamental freedoms, or the family members
5 of these targeted individuals;
6 (2) to coordinate with allies and partners to
7 prevent the export of commercial spyware tools to
8 end-users likely to use them for malicious activities;
9 (3) to maintain robust information-sharing with
10 trusted allies and partners on commercial spyware
11 proliferation and misuse, including to better identify
12 and track these tools; and
13 (4) to work with private industry to identify
14 and counter the abuse and misuse of commercial
15 spyware technology; and
16 (5) to work with allies and partners to establish
17 robust guardrails to ensure that the use of commer-
18 cial spyware tools are consistent with respect for
19 internationally recognized human rights, and the
20 rule of law.
21

SEC. 5401. FOREIGN INFORMATION MANIPULATION AND IN-
4
TERFERENCE STRATEGY.
5 (a) IN GENERAL.—Not later than 90 days after the
6 date of the enactment of this Act, the Secretary, in con-
7 sultation with other relevant agencies, shall submit to the
8 appropriate committees of Congress a comprehensive
9 strategy to combat foreign information manipulation and
10 interference, which shall be carried out by the Depart-
11 ment.
12 (b) ELEMENTS.—The strategy required under sub-
13 section (a) shall include the following elements:
14 (1) Conducting analysis of foreign state and
15 non-state actors’ foreign malign influence narratives,
16 tactics, and techniques, including those originating
17 from United States nation-state adversaries, includ-
18 ing the Russian Federation, the People’s Republic of
19 China, North Korea, and Iran.
20 (2) Working together with allies and partners
21 to expose and counter foreign malign influence nar-
22 ratives, tactics, and techniques, including those orig-
23 inating in the Russian Federation, the People’s Re-
24 public of China, North Korea, and Iran.
†S 2296 ES

3064
1 (3) Supporting non-state actors abroad, includ-
2 ing independent media and civil society groups,
3 which are working to expose and counter foreign
4 malign influence narratives, tactics, and techniques,
5 including those originating in the Russian Federa-
6 tion, the People’s Republic of China, North Korea,
7 or Iran.
8 (4) Coordinating efforts to expose and counter
9 foreign information manipulation and interference
10 across Federal departments and agencies.
11 (5) Protecting the First Amendment rights of
12 United States citizens.
13 (6) Creating guardrails to ensure the Depart-
14 ment of State does not provide grants to organiza-
15 tions engaging in partisan political activity in the
16 United States.
17 (c) COORDINATION.—The strategy required under
18 subsection (a) shall be led and implemented by the Under
19 Secretary for Public Diplomacy and Public Affairs in co-
20 ordination with relevant bureaus and offices at the De-
21 partment of State.
22 (d) REPORT.—Not later than 30 days after the enact-
23 ment of this Act, the Secretary shall submit to the appro-
24 priate committees of Congress a report that includes—
†S 2296 ES

3065
1 (1) actions the Department has taken to pre-
2 serve the institutional capability to counter foreign
3 nation-state influence operations from the People’s
4 Republic of China, Iran, and the Russian Federation

18 (1) Australia is one of the closest allies of the

20 security interests in the Indo-Pacific;
21 (2) the United States-Australia alliance has
22 seen tremendous growth, including through AUKUS,
23 as part of which, the United States plans to rotate
24 up to four Virginia-class attack submarines out of
25 the Australian port of Perth by 2027; and
†S 2296 ES

3081
1 (3) current United States staffing and facilities
2 across United States Mission Australia do not ap-

4 mission set and are no longer commensurate with

6 need to station many more United States civilian
7 and military personnel in western Australia to sup-
8 port the maintenance and supply of these vessels.

10 (1) IN GENERAL.—Not later than 90 days after
11 the enactment of this Act, the Secretary shall submit
12 to the appropriate committees of Congress a report

14 United States Mission Australia.

16 paragraph (1) shall include—
17 (A) an assessment of how many United
18 States civilian and military personnel and their
19 dependents the Department of State expects in
20 the Perth area and across Australia in the next
21 two years;
22 (B) an assessment of what requirements
23 those United States personnel will have, includ-
24 ing housing, schooling, and office space;
†S 2296 ES

3082

2 States personnel are currently working in the

8 to increase staffing in Perth and the tradeoffs
9 of such personnel moves;
10 (E) a status update on the interagency

12 Mission Australia;

15 (a) IN GENERAL.—The Secretary, in coordination

17 agencies, should establish and develop a voluntary pro-

19 tween interested United States Government regulatory
20 and technical agencies and their counterpart organizations
21 in allied and partner countries, both bilaterally and in rel-
22 evant multilateral institutions and organizations—
23 (1) to promote best practices in regulatory for-
24 mation and implementation;
†S 2296 ES

3084
1 (2) to collaborate to achieve optimal regulatory
2 outcomes based on scientific, technical, and other
3 relevant principles;
4 (3) to seek better harmonization and alignment
5 of regulations and regulatory practices; and
6 (4) to build consensus around industry and
7 technical standards in emerging sectors that will
8 drive future global economic growth and commerce.
9 (b) PRIORITIZATION OF ACTIVITIES.—In facilitating
10 expert exchanges under subsection (a), the Secretary
11 should prioritize—
12 (1) bilateral coordination and collaboration with
13 countries where greater regulatory coherence, har-
14 monization of standards, or communication and dia-
15 logue between technical agencies is achievable and
16 best advances the economic and national security in-
17 terests of the United States;
18 (2) multilateral coordination and collaboration
19 where greater regulatory coherence, harmonization
20 of standards, or dialogue on other relevant regu-
21 latory matters is achievable and best advances the
22 economic and national security interests of the
23 United States, including with the members of—
24 (A) the European Union;
†S 2296 ES

3085
1 (B) the Asia-Pacific Economic Coopera-
2 tion;
3 (C) the Association of Southeast Asian Na-
4 tions (ASEAN);
5 (D) the Organization for Economic Co-
6 operation and Development (OECD);
7 (E) the Pacific Alliance; and
8 (F) multilateral development banks; and
9 (3) regulatory practices and standards-setting
10 bodies focused on key economic sectors and emerg-
11 ing technologies.
12 (c) PARTICIPATION BY NONGOVERNMENTAL ENTI-
13 TIES.—With regard to the program described in sub-
14 section (a), the Secretary may facilitate the participation
15 of relevant organizations and individuals with relevant ex-
16 pertise, as appropriate and to the extent that such partici-
17 pation advances the goals of such program.
18 (d) RULE OF CONSTRUCTION.—The authorities pro-
19 vided by this section are intended solely to provide United

4
MERCE IN DEVELOPING PARTNER COUN-
5
TRIES.
6 (a) ESTABLISHMENT.—The Secretary, in coordina-

9 pilot program—
10 (1) to identify and evaluate barriers to com-
11 merce in developing countries that are allies and
12 partners of the United States; and
13 (2) to provide assistance to promote economic
14 development and commerce to those countries.
15 (b) PURPOSES.—Under the pilot program established
16 under subsection (a), the Secretary shall, in partnership
17 with the countries selected under subsection (c)(1)—
18 (1) seek to identify possible barriers in those
19 countries that limit international commerce with the
20 goal of setting priorities for the efficient use of
21 United States economic assistance;
22 (2) focus relevant United States economic as-
23 sistance on building self-sustaining institutional ca-
24 pacity for expanding commerce with those countries,
†S 2296 ES

3087
1 consistent with their international obligations and
2 commitments; and
3 (3) further the national interests of the United
4 States by—
5 (A) expanding prosperity through the
6 elimination of foreign barriers to commercial
7 exchange;
8 (B) assisting such countries to identify and
9 reduce commercial restrictions, including
10 through the deployment of targeted foreign as-
11 sistance, as appropriate, to increase inter-
12 national commerce and investment;
13 (C) assisting each selected country in un-
14 dertaking reforms that will promote economic
15 growth, and promote conditions favorable for
16 business and commercial development and job
17 growth in the country; and
18 (D) assisting, as appropriate, private sec-
19 tor entities in those countries to engage in re-
20 form efforts and enhance productive global sup-
21 ply chain partnerships with the United States
22 and allies and partners of the United States.

VERSIFICATION.

†S 2296 ES

3093

7 efforts by governments, multilateral develop-
8 ment banks, and the private sector to attract
9 investment by private entities who are seeking
10 to diversify from reliance on the People’s Re-
11 public of China;
12 (B) major challenges hindering those ef-
13 forts; and
14 (C) how the United States can strengthen
15 the effectiveness of those efforts;

17 with comparative advantages for sourcing and manu-
18 facturing critical goods and countries with the great-

20 values;

†S 2296 ES
